story:
Short Summary

It is no accident that we, in our time, have been called to tell this story. Our generation is the first to have the tools in place to connect to the entire world. With a post, a click, a tweet - we have the attention of people around the globe. What we have seen, even in our limited outreach so far, is that Sacajawea has an impact on hearts, and it is astounding.  She was a 12-year old Shoshone girl, but we still remember her. Many have wondered what happened in her life - it is a journey yet UNTOLD in a feature film.

We have been called for many years to tell this story. It is an enormous project and it will take a global awareness. So here we are as a creative team, lifted to new heights and on the brink of bringing this magnificent and powerful film to fruition. What we know, it is the Spiritual energy, the infinite vibration and the transparent awakening of hearts that ignites this production! People from all walks of life have commented and left messages of support and love on our social media outlets. Many have asked, “What can I do?" "How can I get involved?”

 

What We Need & What You Get

Over this last year, we have made great strides toward producing Sacajawea's film. In fact, we have the pieces in place to pursue our final push to major investors. This moment in time is critical to meeting our production goals. And, we also see a dynamic opportunity for you to help us over the next couple of months.

Your contribution will give us the support we need to expand our promotional efforts on social media, our websites and blogs by partnering with a social media marketing firm. From Facebook to LinkedIn, Instagram to Twitter, we want to spread the word about this life-changing, epic film project. 

In addition, the Warrior Woman Spirit Campaign is a vital part of Sacajawea's story, as it brings awareness to women's issues. We can never forget the lost, stolen, abused and murdered Indigenous women from around the world. We want to use these crowdfunding contributions to connect and invite influential women on a "Grand Scale," to inspire everyone by posting their stories on the warrior woman website.

We know that achieving the goal is only possible when we realize and recognize the "value of the journey.” For the journey itself is the teacher, and in order to share the true story of Sacajawea, the lessons of Belief and Gratitude must be embraced. This is a path we have walked for many years and we invite you to come with us.

We have developed unique products and collectibles that are available to you as “perks," based on the level of your contribution.

Some of our perks include:

Warrior Woman Spirit and Sacajawea, The Windcatcher T-shirts, mugs and hats. We also offer totes, posters, flyers, collectible mugs, card sets, jewelry and inspiration.

 

The Impact

How can we connect to the entire world? It is no accident that Sacajawea's spirit has chosen this time to claim her voice. Social media and website/blog outreach is the most important element to bring the awareness she needs. Even with the small amount of posting through friends and family to date, a miraculous wonder has taken place over the years. People from nearly every continent have been moved to contact us from Italy and Brazil, from The Netherlands and Australia, from Norway and the United Kingdom, from Ireland and the Middle East, on and on... with a love for this little, Shoshone girl who stood on the edge of chaos in 1805. Somehow her sweet energy continues to infiltrate the earth!

You can help us share this magical journey with the hearts of people everywhere. Indeed, it is time to awaken the world to the story of Sacajawea! This is her destiny. This is our Calling. And, because you are reading this, you are part of this movement right now!

 

Risks & Challenges

The popularity of social media, websites and blogs, and the way the Internet works to connect with people everywhere within a short period of time gives true credibility to what we plan to do through this campaign. It will only be successful if we have the staff to maintain our posting schedules and marketing goals. We are committed to whatever it takes and we stand behind our Internet experience and lifetime devotion to Sacajawea, her spirit, her story and this production. Our focus is on this project and bringing Sacajawea's story to film and we will make every effort to do that, though it is not guaranteed quite yet.  *Local showings and Red Carpet events have not been selected as yet. All ticket perks will be issued only when/if the film is completed. With your help, we can get there!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand some people cannot contribute to this campaign, but sharing our posts, visiting our websites, reading our blogs, submitting a story for the Warrior Woman Spirit blog,  commenting and lifting us up with your inspiration is valued beyond words. With these contributions in full force, you will also have more tools to give Sacajawea a voice!

In gratitude and thanksgiving,

Sacajawea's Production Team

story:
About "Curtain Call"

We are casting professional actors from Chicago and the Huntington area in September, with the filming taking place in October at locations around Huntington, Indiana plus we have plans to run our short film through the festival circuit once completed. Our crew is eager to make a film that audiences of all ages will enjoy.

Summary

Molly, an entitled person yet talented actress receives an overdue rent notice, before heading to her acting class, where it is announced that their Acting Instructor, Tracy, will be directing a show and at the end of their classes they will hire a performer to be the lead. So, when working on the scene for class Molly, hits Sabrina, a mediocre actress, causing her to become the character, a better actress, and person, Molly attempts to turn her back, in order to have a shot at a paid role. In befriending Sabrina, Molly learns Sabrina is also overdue on her rent, leading Molly to realize her selfishness had been driving her and it had been hurting others while taking her further from her goal. When she is given the part she decides to give it up to Sabrina leading to a real friendship.

Goal

We’re asking for your help to make this project the best quality possible, and sincerely appreciated any donations that will help us achieve our goal in make our film great. We are looking to raise $2,000 towards the film, with the contributions going towards expenses the film will acquire during the pre-production process, the production process, the post-production process and the film festival process.

The $2,000 would ensure that Curtain Call would have a high production value in every respect and help us create the quality film our crew can make. 

Please Share!

If you can not directly contribute to our film, we would love your help spreading the news about our film! Please, share this page with your friends using the Indiegogo share tools, as we want to get as many people as possible as excited about Curtain Call as we are.

Thank you for your contributions, your shares and your support in helping us make the best film possible.

story:
My name is Justin Neiswander, and I have had a burning passion for the art of film since middle school. Since then I've made several short films, including "Neighbour", "Guinea Pig," and "Parasite," starring Oliver Horsfall (Amazon Prime's Carnival Row.)  I am now in my final year at Prague Film School and am looking for funds for my final/diploma project. The script for "Apology Accepted" is still in development and more details about the plot will be revealed in time, yet I can easily say I've never been more excited to make any film than this one. I'm pouring my heart out into this story, and the final product will definitely be my best film yet. 

As you may know, film production is quite costly even on a small, independent level. "Parasite" is twelve minutes long and only features three characters and two locations, yet it ended up costing about $1000 to make. Since "Apology Accepted" is so much longer and larger in scale, I am hoping to raise $5000 for the project. Every dollar of this 5000 will go towards hiring actors, securing locations, renting equipment, catering for the cast and crew, and various other production expenses necessary for making this the best film it can possibly be. Donating to the project will not only mean the world to me and the pursuit of my passion, but it will also provide you with various perks, including the opportunity to have a character in the film named after you and exclusive access to "Parasite," which has not been released to the public. 

This is my final student film before I enter the professional industry. My goal is to make it so that when I do, I will have a film worthy of distributing, submitting to festivals, and getting my name out there. By donating to this campaign and spreading the word, you will be providing me the means necessary to make that possible. Even if what you can spare does not seem like a significant amount, every cent will help me pursue what I know I was put on this Earth to do. 

Thank you all so much, and God bless you.

story:
TEAM:

Director

Casiano Roman Hamer is a recent graduate of Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, New York with a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Film and a minor in Creative Writing.

Through his experience in film he has been able to support a scholarship program through a narrative thesis film, contribute to an educational curriculum in Harlem, and create video content for fashion, documentary, and music entertainment companies (RevoltTV/PublicRecord/TechRow,etc.). He values the combination of filmmaking for entertainment and for philanthropy and will continue to do so in his future of narrative filmmaking.

 

Designer

Ryu is a graduate of Pratt Institute with a Bachelor of Fine Arts in Fashion Design. He is an avid news reader from the age of 10. Ryu's inspirations and concepts derived from politics, society, and culture. He is currently living in Brooklyn, NY. He also feels extremely uncomfortable referring to himself in the third person. 

Cinematographer

 

Agustina Biasutto is an Argentina born, Miami raised, and Brooklyn based Director of Photography, Assistant Camera and Grip. She is a current junior film major at Pratt Institute, having shot a variety of shorts, music videos, and branded projects. Since entering college, she has worked on various commercials, branded content spots, shorts, and features.

As a female, latin immigrant she is interested in portraying the challenges and general stories revolving around underrepresented groups or topics. Agustina strives to create images that compliment story in a vivid, honest and engaging way. Her passion for light, color, and movement makes her time behind the viewfinder her most cherished moment.

 

Campaign

Our team is asking for your help to make this film a reality. We are a diverse team of creatives, mixed in ethnicities, genders, races, and perspectives. 

Through fashion, we are looking to break a standard in visual and material culture by pushing boundaries. We want to this film to be a project that can be featured in publications and media outlets (i-d, Vogue, NOWNESS, etc.) that can show a new eccentric perspective of fashion but one that is influenced from a personal struggle.

We ultimately see a value in our story coming to life in a way that is both aesthetically motivated and socially compelling.  We want to portray an abstract insight into the experience of not fitting in or being stuck in a society that does not serve one's best interests.

The completion of this project will allow us to reach a level of filmmaking and design we have aspired to achieve our whole lives. But more importantly, it will allow us to represent a voice uncommon and undervalued in our visual culture.

 

What We Need

We are asking for $1,000 to kick off our project which would partially fund for: 

  • Camera equipment
  • Grip and electric
  • Talent/models/choreogapher
  • Amenities
 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can not contribute to our fund don't worry there is more than one way to help:

  • Share our campaign on social media
  • Follow us on Instagram (@theamericandialecticfilm)
  • Tell your friends and email us at theamericandialecticfilm@gmail.com if you are interested in lending a hand or know someone who is.

THANK YOU!!!!!!!

story:
About us

I'm Akhil Deva, a Creative Producer/Director based in Atlanta, Georgia. In the past couple of years, my experiences with people from different nationalities, cultures, and paths trying to get by in the United States, halfway across the world from their families has fascinated me.  It motivated me to learn more about them, and my observations made me realize that a shiny cover of success seemed to always mask the rougher, darker interior of sacrifice, struggle, and loneliness that almost every immigrant experiences for a better life. The complexities of weighing the good and bad of living in a diaspora can weigh someone down - and while the traditional image of success in the land of promise is what most sell, I felt the need to depict the opposite side of this on screen.

 

Distant is therefore a film that aims to exemplify the lesser known side of an immigrant's life. The film revolves around Richie, a misfit illegal immigrant living a marginal life, as he forced to choose between a surreal love affair and a dying mother back home, as he fights through life in America. 

Set in two contrasting visual styles to mirror the state of mind of the protagonist, with teals and cyans imitating the feeling of isolation in America, and dull shaded of brown and red representing the helpless and deprived state of Richie's mother in India.

 

Distant is a film that aims to represent immigrants from across the world in the land of opportunities as they pursue the American dream. It is a film that strives to give hope and keep faith in immigrant's hearts - that they are not alone, that their struggle can be seen, and their voice can be heard, loud and clear.

 

Below, we have provided a detailed pie chart with the allocation of the asked funds, for complete transparency with our backers!

 

BREAKING DOWN OUR TARGET AMOUNT OF $10,000

 

 

Since we were on the topic of transparency, and trust - here's a little more on the film's incredibly talented crew! 

 

OUR TEAM

 

Each of us represents different cultures, coming from different countries we are bringing the diverse understanding of the craft of filmmaking onto one creative table to collaborate and stand as a whole for what this project believes in. Here's a little insight in our lives.

Director

Akhil Dev: A Computer Science Engineer, and an Independent Photographer, Akhil’s childhood dream of becoming a film-maker perpetually motivated his choices in life and career. After co-founding an Import Export firm and a stint with real estate in India, he worked as a creative director with a film studio in his hometown of Hyderabad. In 2016, he began his education at Savannah College of Arts and Design, pursuing an M.F.A in Film and Television.

On this boundless journey, his aesthetic sense of mise-en-scène and cinematography took charge to delve into many independent projects as a Director of Photography. In the academic year of 2018-19 alone, he has been credited as a Director of a SCAD produced fashion film, Editor of two MFA thesis projects, Producer and Cinematographer of two MFA thesis projects. He is currently a Creative Producer at 3rd Fathom Films Inc. and Editor at the SCAD FASH Museum, Atlanta.

 

 

 

Producer:

Natasha Sequeira: Natasha Sequeira is an Indian writer, director and producer. She graduated from M.O.P. Vaishnav College for Women, Chennai, India with a bachelor’s degree in Electronic Media. Natasha has previously worked in the Kollywood television industry, and as an editor for a children’s educational publishing company. Her passion for all things film and television led her to pursue her M.F.A. in Film and Television Broadcasting at the Savannah College of Art and Design in Atlanta, Georgia. Since her enrollment in Fall 2017, she has written, directed and produced (in varying capacities) over twenty short films, brand films, music videos, fashion films, and more.

 

 

 

 

Erik Francisco Medina is a Puerto Rican filmmaker, writer, and journalism. He's currently pursuing an MFA in Film and Television at Savannah College of Art & Design. Throughout his career, Erik worked on different projects as a Director, Writer, Producer, and 1st AD that eventually found his niche in Development. One of his passion is creating stories that highlight underrepresented communities and cultures. Erik has proven a resourceful crew member that has incredible interpersonal abilities and excellent good ethic. He has developed, written, produced and directed films, documentaries, music videos, and branded films.

 

 

 

 

Jinsol Kim is a Korean American Cinematographer who graduated from University of North Carolina School of Arts in 2016, with a BFA Degree in Cinematography. He currently dabbles between commercial and Narrative cinematography based in Atlanta, Georgia. Few of his inspirations are Wong Kar Wai and Terrence Malick.

story:
Jeannie Becomes A Star Cast

Lead - Jeannie - Tammy Perks

 

Alex - Andrew Foster

 

Young Jeannie - Megan Raitano

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

 As a film student project been made in partnership with the Valencia College Film Program we are receiving a budget of $500. This will be able to cover food costs and part of the art department costs. With your support we would be able to have enough funding to bring to life the film, also we would have a cushion fund that can be used when we run out of budget to cover the costs. If we have leftover funds they will be used for festivals & Post Production to get the movie to as many people as possible. 

  • Set Dressing - $250 - 
  • Food - $250 - 
  • Wardrobe - $100 -
  • Makeup & Hair - $100 -
  • Publicity & Festivals - $100 -
  • Cushion - $200 -
  • Total - $1,000

Risks & Challenges

  • First, In moviemaking you always run the risk of not finishing the film, so by contributing to this campaign you do so with the understading that the final product may never materialize.
  • In regards to perks we can't guarantee all will meet the stated deadlines.
  • Also certain perks may not be provided based on availability and resources at the time.
  • Depending on the rules of festivals it may be a while before you get to see the film at all.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share the link of this campaign to get the word out
  • Follow the updates on our social media channels to see when the film will be releeased or any news regarding the film.

And That's all there is to it for now. From me, the director, all the producers & the whole crew we thank you for your support and let's do this.

story:
In Short

This movie has been on my mind for several years, now I'm done waiting for it to happen. We are already a full crew and cast onboard to start filming in July, post production will then start in August, We are all excited to see this movie premiere in October. Funds will go to:

  • Make sure the actors and crew gets paid during the production of the movie
  • Have the right gear to make the movie justice
  • Be able to afford the professional post production needed

 

What We Need & What You Get

  • To make this movie perfect we wanna land on around $95,000
  • At $45,000 we can make this movie great but with lots of compromises
  • Top Donates will appear as Producers of the movie
  • Everyone who donates to this fundraiser will have their name in the end credits (if they want)
  • Our entire crew and cast wants to make several movies after this as well
  • We will host a special screening in Los Angeles prior to release (for pledgers only)
  • We are selling the actual one piece swing made for the movie

 

The Story

This movie is about the lives of a boy and girl growing up in a small town. They have very different homes and families. The girl lives with her abusive dad whereas the boy is fortunate to live with his loving parents and younger brother. She desperately needs to leave this town as soon as possible, but he can't. Will they find each other again?

 

Risks & Challenges

Many times while making a low budget movie, the cast and crew suffers financially due to the sacrifices during filming, We do not want this. 

  • With this fundraiser we hopefully make sure everyone can focus entirely on their part instead of worrying about how to pay their rent or putting food on the table.
  • We will be filming mostly in Montana and use the amazing scenery there, which also comes with he expenses of traveling, living and eating.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you feel like you want to be a part of this movie, feel free to contact us and we'll gladly see you on the team or maybe just the end credits of that's preferred.

  • We need extras (you?) for our filming locations in Los Angeles in late July, early August
  • Please Share this fundraiser or even talk about this movie with other
  • You can share here right on this page with all your friends

Thank you for any contribution!

story:
Story

Peter Battles has been a drug addict for the past two decades and when he is sexually assaulted, he wants the people responsible to pay. He forms a plan, but in order to make it work, he needs resources. The only person still in his life is his lifelong friend, Titus Jones. Titus reluctantly allows Pete into his home when he arrives, in the middle of the night, wearing soiled clothes and an unpleasant odor. Pete soon makes a demand for money, which Titus rejects, resulting in an exchange of words and blows; forcing one of them to make an irrevocable decision.

 

Who We Are

Like Minds Productions is an alliance of writers, producers, directors, actors, composers, musicians, singers, choreographers, dancers, and visual artists all banded together for a common cause... creating real ART!

 

How You Can Help

 

Let's break down the logistics:

We need $10,000 to properly fund our short by paying for the following...

  • Cast - None of that "it's great exposure" poopoo. Artists have bills to pay. 
  • Crew - The skilled company of people behind the scenes that make everything possible.
  • Locations/Permits - You know the old adage.
  • Insurance - Making sure our people and places are covered in case of an emergency.
  • SAG-AFTRA contributions - We are proud to be working with union performers!
  • Costumes, props, set decoration, etc... - The devil is in the details.
  • Post Production - Editing, color correction, sound mixing, etc...
  • Music - The audible blood that keeps the dramatic tension flowing.
  • Film Festival Submissions - Entrance fees so we can share this film with audiences.
  • Food - We gotta eat, y'all. Days on set are long.
  • Miscellaneous expenses - Things come up and we want to be prepared to move forward!

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't afford to donate? We get it! You can still help by spreading the word. Use the Indiegogo share tools at the top right of this page to tell your family, friends, and colleagues about our project. This is one of the best ways to build traction and ensure we reach our goal. The more shares, the better! 

Follow, Like & Share on Social Media: 

http://Facebook.com/FragileLikeConcreteTheMovie

https://www.instagram.com/fragilelikeconcretefilm

https://www.fragilelikeconcretefilm.com

story:
We're almost there!

Thanks to some newly acquired outside funding and a careful reduction of our budget (which we managed to do without compromising our desire to pay, house, and feed our cast and crew), we only need $1,500 more to produce Signal to Noise. 

We have the cast, the crew, the equipment, and all of our primary locations lined up. We are so close to the finish line here and we would absolutely love your help getting there.

Thank you again (and again and again) for checking out our campaign and we cannot wait for you to see Signal to Noise!

Let’s get right to it.

We’re asking you for money. And if you do decide to contribute, no matter how much you give, you will receive a digital copy of the finished film.

We know what we’re asking for and we know what we have to offer. There won’t be any pins or posters or T-shirts. Given the team that we have, the one thing we know we can deliver is the film itself. Because of that, we’ve tried our best to be totally transparent with you. 

If you want to know who you’d be giving your money to, check out our bios and pitch video. 

If you want to know where your money would be going, check out our budget breakdown. 

And if you want to know what the movie’s gonna be like, you can read the whole script.

Every person on the Signal to Noise team wants to make this Santa Cruz set, slow-burning, somewhat fantastical, absolutely queer romance more than anything. And we can’t do it without your help.

Thank you for stopping by and please check out the rest of our campaign.

What is Signal to Noise?

Signal to Noise is an independent feature film written and directed by Tyler Milles, set to shoot out of Santa Cruz, California in the summer of 2019. Let’s call it a stoner bromance romance with a magical-realist twist.

It follows a stoner whose hazy, solitary life is interrupted by the arrival of an old friend who claims to have gained the ability to experience the dreams of those he sleeps near.

Aiming to test the limits of this bizarre, new ability, they decide to run an experiment. And as they dream together night-after-night, a passion blurring the lines between friendship and romance awakens.

If that's not enough, feel free to read the entire script.

Who's making it?

Tyler Milles - Writer / Director / Cinematographer / Editor

When I graduated from UC Berkeley’s film studies program, I started calling myself an indie filmmaker. Sure, I had yet to make anything more than a couple shorts, but I wanted to make my intentions clear. No matter what job I took, that was my headline. Whatever money I made was getting dumped into building a filmmaking rig so that if need be, I could take a movie from pre-to-post-production. For as long as I’ve had access to a camera, I’ve been writing, shooting, and editing stuff. And now, with the help of one of my oldest friends whom I’ve been making things with since I met him, I have the chance to make my first feature and I couldn’t be more thrilled.

Adam Frey - Producer / Assistant Camera

Growing up just outside of Los Angeles, I've always had a distinct love of movies. Ever since elementary school, when my dad let me use his camera and gave me a copy of Final Cut Express, I've been making short films with my friends. After high school, I got a degree in Economics from Chapman University, hoping that I could combine my knowledge of business and economics with my love of film in order to produce the sort of movie that Hollywood wouldn't normally take a chance on. And now, with Signal to Noise, I have the opportunity to do just that.

Cristian Caridad - "Vince Santos"

When I was young, I would always get sucked in to watching my favorite movies over and over again. And once I got bored of that, I found myself starting to re-enact scenes from those movies myself. A personal favorite was that scene in Jurassic Park when Sam Neil first sees the brachiosaurus. As I grew older and started to pursue acting professionally, I realized that my passion for acting also applied to the rest of the filmmaking process. I wanted to learn how to be behind and in front of the camera. Being able to work on an indie film like this gives me opportunity to take on all of my passions at once. I'm very proud to take on the role of Vince and can't wait to share Signal to Noise with you.

Nico Yasko - "Henry Marquez"

Since Henry and I are both Latinos and members of the LGBTQ+ community, telling his story is something I'm incredibly passionate about. While I am from Uruguay, I was born in Japan and have lived in places like Conakry, Bangkok, Montevideo, and Grenoble. It's safe to say I was raised all over the world. Right now, I'm studying acting at UCLA's School of Theater, Film, and Television and plan on working on Signal to Noise between quarters. I hope you enjoy what we're all about to make!

Eden Bailey - Producer / Assistant Director

Eden is a filmmaker from Surf City, California. He is currently finishing up his bachelor's degree in film direction at Chapman University, and has several short films to his name. Non-film related interests include music, bowling, and just a good round of laser tag.

Matt Somogyi - Sound Mixer / Sound Designer

Matt was born in Burbank, CA and has always been interested and infatuated with film, having been surrounded by the entertainment industry and various studios throughout his childhood. After becoming intensely involved in his high school’s media program, Matt went on to receive his B.F.A. in film production from Dodge College at Chapman University with an emphasis in directing, as well as his M.A. in film studies in an accelerated graduate program. Since graduating, he has been fortunate enough to direct a few commercials and short films but primarily makes his living doing production sound and post-production sound mixing. Matt is incredibly excited to be a creative member of Signal to Noise and looks forward to all of the coming adventures with the cast and crew!

What do we have?

Equipment

Nearly all of the necessary camera and sound equipment is accounted for by my personal rig. We will be shooting the film primarily on a Panasonic GH5s with another Panasonic GH4 backing it up. Post-production equipment is also accounted for here as I've built a computer expressly for that purpose. You can see my equipment in action in our pitch video in addition to the two last shorts I made Now What? and A Day in the Life of the Passenger.

Microbudget Experience

Everything we've made before has been made on a budget of zero dollars with incredibly tight shooting schedules (and I'd like to think it doesn't show). We know how to make the most out of limited resources, which is why we're asking only for what we absolutely need. 

From its conception, Signal to Noise was intended to be shot on a microbudget. This isn't a story that got hemmed in to be made cheaply. Every aspect of the script, from its limited number of locations, to its two-hander structure, to the fact that the dreams are only talked about rather than depicted, was designed with a small-scale production in mind.

What do we need?

Well--money. But more specifically, money for...

...wages,

I’m not interested in anyone involved in this film (me and Adam excluded) working for free. This is my highest priority. The cast and crew should be paid for each day that they work. “Exposure,” especially for a film of this small a scale is not enough.

...food,

People need fuel to perform and I’d rather the cast and crew did not need to pack their own lunches for a 13 day shoot.

...locations and housing.

There are a limited number of locations featured in the film, the most important of which is the studio apartment where the majority of the film takes place. These private locations will need to be rented. Additionally, because the shoot will be based in Santa Cruz, the majority of the cast and crew will need to be housed for length of the shoot.

For a more detailed overview, check out our Budget Breakdown. 

Why should you give us money?

Because you want to see the movie we’re trying to make. Plain and simple.

There aren’t going to be pins or posters or T-shirts. We do not want to promise things that we cannot deliver or raise our budget to attempt to expand beyond our reach.

Given the talent that we have, the one thing we know we can deliver is the film itself. Because of that, contributions of any size will let you see the film for free. All that the tiers determine is when you get to see it.

For inquiries about becoming a financier of the film, or about seeing more of our work, email us here: signaltonoisemovie@gmail.com

If you've gotten all the way down here, we want to thank you for taking the time to check out our campaign. Please consider donating to Signal to Noise and helping us make this movie a reality. Any amount goes a long way. Thank you.

And if you want to keep up with what we're doing, follow us on Instagram, Facebook, and Twitter.

story:
The Tribe Story

Tribes tells the story of Ronin, a wanderer in the desolate aftermath of a cataclysmic event. His journey has no beginning and no end but it does have some twists and a great payoff. With a subtle nod to todays xenophobic times this action/adventure film takes after films such as Mad Max and I am Legend, however with its own style.

Our past films have dealt with the topics that move us. "Vemana" was an award winning experimental/fantasy film that dealt with the oneness of all people. "Blue Skies" was another award winning film about the topic of addiction and its devastating effects on relationships. Our last project "Sickness" was a sci-fi film and concerned one mans experience with a world on the cusp of environmental ruin.  It premiered at SAIFF as part of the HBO Short Film Competition in December. 

This project deals with complicated issues such as gender dynamics and exploitation in a world with few rules and fewer institutions.  It is far from a polemic however and we never lose sight of what a good film has to be - entertaining!  Incorporating fight choreography and beautiful locations as well as talented FX artists this will be our most ambitious project to date. We thank you for taking the time to read our campaign. 

My wife Chelsea & I have been funding our own films simply because it is our passion. This time we wanted to give others the opportunity to produce with us.  Our topics are socially relevant and our message comes from the heart.  Not only will you help create the narrative that shapes our world, be a part of an entertaining art form, but you will also be immortalized forever in our IMDB page as a producer or contributor! 

For example my work is listed HERE.  

Theme, Tech and Synopsis

Tribe deals with dark issues such as predation by the strong upon the weak, sexual exploitation, greed, sadism and does this by using the foil of love, heroism and sacrifice. 
 
As Ronin wanders the wasteland on a mysterious mission he is captured by suspicious and territorial survivors.  Recounting his desire to be reunited with his lost wife only amuses the hardened group.  As he delves deeper into his past and we learn more about how this particular "Tribe" operates we find reflections of our current tribalism.  
 
In a land where might makes right can someone with humanity survive?  If so... how?
 
This film uses top notch talent for practical FX (Gene Mazza), costume design (Chelsea Roth) and is blessed with fight choreography by Dr. Kacem Zoughari!  Using the latest professional broadcast quality equipment gives us a 4K UHD, 10 bit, 4:2:2 workflow!  
 

The Team

We have a great group of passionate players and technicians doing their utmost to create an excellent final product.  A small sampling of which are:

Ken Kecevar

Maria Tsuguriya

Hamza Zaman

Sample Work

Vemana

 

 

Blue Skies (Full length available on Amazon at:  www.amazon.com/v/film/) 

Thank you!

If you cannot make a financial contribution to art at this time its okay!  We appreciate you reading this campaign and if you would like to still help please do share it using the INdieGoGo tools!  Thanks again!

-Chelsea & Hamza
story_txt:
The Tribe Story
Tribes tells the story of Ronin, a wanderer in the desolate aftermath of a cataclysmic event. His journey has no beginning and no end but it does have some twists and a great payoff. With a subtle nod to todays xenophobic times this action/adventure film takes after films such as Mad Max and I am Legend, however with its own style.
Our past films have dealt with the topics that move us. "Vemana" was an award winning experimental/fantasy film that dealt with the oneness of all people. "Blue Skies" was another award winning film about the topic of addiction and its devastating effects on relationships. Our last project "Sickness" was a sci-fi film and concerned one mans experience with a world on the cusp of environmental ruin.  It premiered at SAIFF as part of the HBO Short Film Competition in December. 
This project deals with complicated issues such as gender dynamics and exploitation in a world with few rules and fewer institutions.  It is far from a polemic however and we never lose sight of what a good film has to be - entertaining!  Incorporating fight choreography and beautiful locations as well as talented FX artists this will be our most ambitious project to date. We thank you for taking the time to read our campaign. 
My wife Chelsea & I have been funding our own films simply because it is our passion. This time we wanted to give others the opportunity to produce with us.  Our topics are socially relevant and our message comes from the heart.  Not only will you help create the narrative that shapes our world, be a part of an entertaining art form, but you will also be immortalized forever in our IMDB page as a producer or contributor! 
For example my work is listed HERE.  
Theme, Tech and Synopsis

Tribe deals with dark issues such as predation by the strong upon the weak, sexual exploitation, greed, sadism and does this by using the foil of love, heroism and sacrifice. 
 
As Ronin wanders the wasteland on a mysterious mission he is captured by suspicious and territorial survivors.  Recounting his desire to be reunited with his lost wife only amuses the hardened group.  As he delves deeper into his past and we learn more about how this particular "Tribe" operates we find reflections of our current tribalism.  
 
In a land where might makes right can someone with humanity survive?  If so... how?
 
This film uses top notch talent for practical FX (Gene Mazza), costume design (Chelsea Roth) and is blessed with fight choreography by Dr. Kacem Zoughari!  Using the latest professional broadcast quality equipment gives us a 4K UHD, 10 bit, 4:2:2 workflow!  
 


The Team
We have a great group of passionate players and technicians doing their utmost to create an excellent final product.  A small sampling of which are:

Ken Kecevar

Maria Tsuguriya

Hamza Zaman

Sample Work

Vemana

story:
Who is this guy?

Hi, my name is Jesse Sanchez and I'm writing and directing Koreatown. After spending a few years trying to produce this story out of pocket it has become apparent that the best way to make this idea so that it meets its full potential is by crowd funding. I've been passionate about filmmaking since I was in my early teens, making a feature when I was 16, and then studying  filmmaking at USC. After freelancing as an editor and DIT through my 20's I realized it was time to write an idea that was something I could make in my own neighborhood without a lot of money. Then the recession hit. As I rewrote the script I found that to really meet the full potential of the premise I would need do more than just shoot three guys tripping in an apartment with a cop for 90 minutes. At the same time I was witnessing the slow creep of gentrification all around me, rising like a crescendo until it was obvious that that would need to be part of the movie.

Recently things have been changing so rapidly that it became apparent that I couldn't keep up with changing face of the neighborhood and if I wanted to capture it for what it was I would need help. This campaign represents a chance for me apply and the talent and experience I have had and truly make something unique and entertaining, while also socially relevant. It is a culmination of all the things I have learned about filmmaking, a love letter to the community I've spent 10+ years living and learning in, and a chance to make something entertaining with a diverse world view that doesn't ring false like some college brochure photoshoot. Anyone who's ever met me knows I've trained my brain to be a movie machine and it's time put that machine to work. To make dreams a reality.

How big are these dreams, exactly?

The scale of the movie is entirely dependent on what I can raise via this campaign. Whether it be a short film, a feature length movie, or a feature with great tripping visuals and killer soundtrack all comes down to who believe in me and this idea.

Growing up watching Indies in the 90's I was always thrown off by how under populated the worlds of those movies felt. I want this movie to be teeming with life the same way the real streets of Koreatown are, where overheard conversations and multiple languages are part of the background noise. When I say I want a densely diverse film I mean it, I want as many languages and ethnicities represented as possible.

Some of the perks in the campaign include featured extra and single line parts. Overhearing out of context bits of conversation while walking around the neighborhood is exactly the kind of comedy I want this movie to be, especially when those lines are in different languages so that, depending on how multilingual you are, each person experiencing the movie will hear different things in it.

If the campaign falls short of the goal the funds raised will be used to complete the short version that I've been self financing for the last few years, completing a few more days of shooting, paying for the sound mix and color correction and if there's anything left after that using the remainder to pay for application fees to various film festivals. Regardless of how it goes the movie is getting made in one form or another.

 

When I was editing the short and noticing the changes to buildings and other details in the background (because shoot days were always months if not a year apart) I realized just how quickly the neighborhood was changing. In the same way the the original 'She's Gotta Have It' is a time capsule of the what 80's Brooklyn looked like I want to the same to be true for Koreatown. Los Angeles is very much about the new and part of the fun of living there was seeing old movies shot there and how things used to look.

In Boots Riley's 'Sorry to Bother You' he managed to shoot the Oakland he knew while also covering themes of labor organizing/exploitation and code switching, I'd like to do the same for Koreatown while looking at the LA housing crisis, community and bad allies. I think these are worthy topics and that movies have a way of speaking to us as people that no other medium can, a way of seeping into our subconscious the same way dreams do. 

 

Risks & Challenges

Any kind of film making is a challenge: time, resources and the unforeseen come with the territory. This is also the stuff that 'happy accidents' are made of-which if you've ever been on a film set is one of the true joys of the filmmaking process.

Since I have already shot a few days with the cast and crew making the short I know our collective strengths and weaknesses. Shooting with permits and proper equipment will make all the difference. If you think the stills and shots from look good just wait until you see what we can do with some real backing this time.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Something that isn't common knowledge about these crowd funding campaigns is that the number of backers participating can be just as, if not more important, than the total funds raised. You may not have much spare income, but people that do will see those small contributions as an acknowledgment that there is a demand for this idea. Even as a little a $1 helps, because every backer matters. Beyond that, the standard like/share/subscribe also contributes to the numbers that will ultimately define how important this project will be seen by other investors and micro-budget studios. Every little bit helps.

story:
Summary

We are a group of second year Media Production: Film and Television students from York St John University.

A mother, broken and defeated, searches her son Andrew’s room for signs of where it all went wrong. She repeatedly plays the news report of her son’s tragic acts on a tape recorder, listening again and again how he committed the murders of ten of his peers at his school earlier that day.

She thinks back to memories where he had shown disapproving behaviour. It was all starting to make sense, she begins to believe it was her fault. She resorts to filming a video explaining her side of the story and apologising for her son’s actions. She decides that she is just as much to blame as her son so plans to take her own life.

Motivation

We want this production to highlight how much one event, such as a school stabbing, can affect so many lives, not just those of the victims. In particular, we want to emphasize how a mother feels when her only son is taken from her and how she can only blame herself.

In the last year, the number of teenage and young adult stabbings has reached its highest level in 8 years, according to The Guardian. Because of this we wanted to raise awareness of knife crime in this country and hopefully increase prevention of such attacks. We want this film to be hard-hitting yet grounded and resonate with our audience.  

Please Donate!

We are hoping to raise around £500 in this campaign. This will be spent on travel expenses for the cast and crew, catering on set, props, costumes and anything else we might need. We have a variety of perks depending on the level at which you donate. These range from a digital download of the film to and Executive Producer credit and invitation to a private screening and wrap party. Have a look at all our rewards and see if there is anything you fancy!

Any contribution will be greatly appreciated. Even if you cannot donate anything to our projects, please share and help us reach a wider audience.

story:
Welcome!! My name is Kyle Hester. Just a bit about me. I have been acting since I was in the 7th grade. Film is a life long passion of mine. Some past films that you may recognize are "Andersonville"," Last Dance" and more recently "The Chair" with Roddy Piper!
We have a film in post production now called "Preacher Six"! The goal is to bring "A" list type films to you on an independent film budget! Thank you for joining us on this journey!! My wife Tracy Ray is the screenwriter and I bring them to life!
  Buried bodies, secrets and legends. Even the bad guy is a hero. Set in the modern American West. What is going on at Ghost Rider Ranch is not all that it seams.
  Grady Earls from "Preacher Six" is our prolific director! WE will be using much of the same film team from "Preacher Six" including our awesome director of photography Lisa Tomm!
Lets check out the amazing talent that we have in our film!!
Kyle Hester from "The Chair" and "Preacher Six".
Peter Murnik from "Jag"
David Banks from "Cut"!
Tomas Boykin from "Voodoo Possession"!
Lawrence Chau from Ghostly Encounters"!
Mary Le Gault from "Death Factory"!
Jeremy Fultz from "Zombie With a Shotgun"!
Brooke Lewis from "Dead Slate"
 

Plus many more!! This cast is still being announced!

The only way all those actors will work is with your help!

Independent film only happens because of people like you! This Indiegogo campaign is what will make this film happen. Everything from paying the cast and crew to the Insurance and film permits that make filming possible. The food that they eat on set is made possible because of you. Bottom line here is  without you and your support all of this is a blank screen...................

We are the new wave in Independent film and now....... So are you!!

Risks & Challenges

What are the risks here? That no one contributes anything and this film does not get finished.

That......... will NOT happen! Our community is strong and the need for Independent film is strong. We will keep going until this film is made. You know the expresssion "No plan B"?

Well that is the case here! Come on board and be a part of something special!

How else can you help?

Please use the tools on this page to share the campaign on Twitter and your facebook! This is grass roots my friends and everything helps!!

Thank you for taking the time to read this. Now......

Lets get this sucker done!!!!!

story:
Short Summary

New York City is lively and dynamic but have you noticed an overwhelming amount of "For Rent" signs and empty storefronts in Manhattan lately? Well, we have too. The Tiny Apple takes a look at the disappearing face of New York's small businesses by profiling them and the people who run them. Through their personal anecdotes and experiences these small business owners provide a unique and rare look at the cultural and socioeconomic shift NYC has been undergoing. It's heartbreaking how most of these people, if not all, are struggling to keep their doors open. 

Local businesses filled with personality and history are quickly being replaced by big corporations and we hope to capture a vestige of how it used to be before it's completely gone.

It's so important to give places like these a voice because their stories are unique and honest and contribute to the New York we all know and love.

What We Need & What You Get

We really believe in this project and our ability to bring it to life but in order to achieve the quality we envisioned we need your help. Not only would you be contributing to an important project but we have also put together rewards to show our appreciation!

We are asking for $15,000 in order to complete this series. Your money will go towards a variety of elements that together will help us make this project a reality. 

We've separated our costs in three categories (which are color coded below)

Pre-Production in green and yellow

Production in purple 

Post Production red and orange

Our Team

Tiny Apple is our debut project with Opposite Sea Productions. We are a small but resourceful team. Meet those involved:


Nina Thomas - Producer/Editor 

Thomas is a French/Spanish Film Editor and Documentary Producer based in NYC. She  is currently a Junior Editor at the post-production company House of Trim in NYC, where she has worked on commercial, branded content and documentary projects for well-known companies such as TOYOTA, ESPN, The New Yorker, Herman Miller and D.S. & Durga. Some of her branded content work was featured in GQ Magazine, Condé Nast Traveller and Esquire.  She has worked as an editor on the short documentary “The Jerome Project”, which premiered at BAM in NYC, and in 2018 she edited and produced the documentary Love From Afar, which has been selected for multiple film festivals in the US. (@transoceanicgirl)

Joanna Aliano - Producer/Director 

Aliano is a Brazilian Digital Media Producer based in NYC who focuses on non-fiction storytelling through a variety of forms. She expanded into video production while obtaining her Masters in Media Studies at the New School in NYC, where she developed projects that focus on personal narratives. The Tiny Apple is her debut as a director (@itsjpa)

Arnaud Richou - Associate Producer/Still Photographer

Richou is a French street photographer that splits his time between France, Spain and New York. He specializes in B&W portraits and analog photography. (@les_mains_grises) 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute with $$$ you can still support us by:

  • Sharing this video with everyone and anyone 
  • Liking our Instragram and Facebook page

ig: @oppositeseaproductions

fb: https://www.facebook.com/oppositeseaproductions

story:
Why does this project matter?

Today, one in three seniors dies with Alzheimer's or another dementia. But it will be even worse in the future. The number of people developing Alzheimer's is increasing.

Chances are that even if you don’t get the disease, you will know someone who has it. And chances are that you will end up caring for someone with the disease.

This is what happened to me.

Five years ago, I was living in Los Angeles when I received a call that my mother, Love, had wandered away from home. I made the monumental decision to leave my life in LA to move across the country to my childhood home in New Jersey to care her. With no previous caregiving experience, I was confronted with the grim reality of what it actually means to be the caregiver of someone with dementia in the USA.

Every person suffering from Alzheimer’s needs at least one person to take on the responsibility for their well-being, but too often that person’s sacrifice is under-rated or taken for granted. 

 

Alzheimer’s is the sixth leading cause of death in the USA. It is the only disease among the top ten killers without any treatment or cure.

But we are not without hope.

I know now what I did not know then: that what matters is having the best life possible in the present. Because we don’t have the past or the future. We just have now. 

We are making this film because we want to affect change. Love (yes, that is her real name) was a nurse. Her whole life was dedicated to helping others. She would not have wanted her suffering to be in vain. She would be so proud to know that because of her, other peoples’ lives were made better. 

There is no cure and no treatment YET for Alzheimer’s disease. Someday there will be. But in the meantime, there is so much that we can do to improve the lives of those suffering from dementia as well as their caregivers.

I am a storyteller and a filmmaker. With this film, SHELTERING LOVE, my goal is to bring awareness to the plight of the caregiver, and to offer hope that even though a cure does not currently exist, there is much that can improve the lives of everyone affected by the disease—patients and caregivers alike. SHELTERING LOVE is one family’s story of finding courage, hope—even joy—while facing this devastating disease.

By donating today, the future you might be changing could very easily be your own.

 

How does Norway fit into the story?

Our team is planning to travel to Norway in November 2018 for filming. Love grew up in Norway and moved to the USA when she was a young woman. She still has many family members in Norway. Her story starts there. But this is not the only reason that Norway is important to us. Love's older brother and his wife both developed and ultimately died from dementia and Alzheimer's. Their experience colored Love's own understanding of the disease and had a tremendous impact on her reaction to her own illness. We want to travel to Norway to interview the people there who can talk about what happened. 

Also, we will answer the question, what if Love had never left Norway? How would her care have been different there?

Norway has one of the most advanced healthcare systems in the world and is on the forefront of care for dementia patients through the use of technology, living solutions, and innovations in management techniques. We want to talk with Norwegian caregivers and experts to learn about their approaches to this epidemic.

 

What we need & What you get

Because of scheduling conflicts, it is urgent that we get the Norway segment done now, and so with this campaign we hope to be able to raise the funds necessary for this first stage of production.

Right now we are seeking $12,000 to finance the filming in Norway. 

The $12,000 goal will fund the following:

$4300 - Crew stipends (including interpreters and drone operator in Norway)
$1800 - Airfare NYC to Norway for the team
$300   - Travel insurance and extra baggage fees for equipment
$1140 - Local transportation
$2320 - Lodging and food in Norway
$560   - Hard drives
$1580 - Administrative and legal costs

When you support us, along with our immensely deep gratitude, you’ll also receive some fabulous perks! To that end, we’ve designed custom-made items such as high quality sweatshirts, t-shirts and tote bags. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you’re unable to make a monetary donation at this time, but still want to help us, please reach out to us. There's so much that you can do!

  • Spread the word! Tell everyone you know, especially through social media (Note that Indiegogo has some built-in share tools next to the "Back it" button at the top of the page)
  • We also appreciate in-kind donations (i.e. any goods or services that you might be able to offer us either for free or for a discount!)
  • Just knowing that you care means a lot. Drop us a line and say hello!

 

 

The Team

Dawn Green (Director/Producer) is a filmmaker and producer based in New York. She has worked on narrative and documentary film and television projects. Her work as a producer in television has included shows for the SyFy Channel and the Oxygen Network. Dawn worked as a Lecturer at Stanford University. She has a Ph.D. from the University of Wisconsin-Madison, and a BA from Brandeis University. She received her MA in film producing from the American Film Institute Conservatory

Mira Lew (Producer) is a documentary filmmaker and producer who lives in Brooklyn.  She has worked on a wide range of projects, including Tig on Netflix, Intervention, and a short film for Time’s Up.  She is currently finishing a documentary about the Taiwanese hip-hop dance scene.  She received her master’s degree in directing at UCLA and her bachelor’s degree in American History from Columbia University.

Jonathan Schwarz (Director of Photography) is a cinematographer of commercials, television, and non-fiction film. He has worked with clients and brands including:  Nat Geo, Vice, A&E, Netflix, The New York Times, Lifetime, CBS, Sundance Channel, MTV, VH1, Bravo, Headline News, Oxygen, Discovery ID, Hallmark Channel, Esquire, UNICEF, Viacom, ACLU, BMW, Mercedes Benz, Jeep, Cosmopolitan, KFC, and PBS. Jonathan shot the award-winning film documentary THE GREAT SASUKI and was one of the cinematographers on TIG, the Netflix doc about comedian Tig Notaro. Jonathan received his MFA in Cinematography from UCLA.

Yaron Sokolov (Additional Camera) Yaron Sokolov is a Berlin-based video-artist, writer, and cinematographer. As a freelancer, he produces promotional videos for local businesses as well as music videos. He has a Ph.D. in Musical Arts from Stanford University and brings his expertise in sound to every project he’s involved with. Yaron has worked as a cinematographer for the Jerusalem Music Centre - working closely with world renown musicians such as Itzhak Perlman and Andreas School - in addition to serving as a lecturer at several colleges in Israel, such as the Holon Institute of Technology (HIT).

Colin Fitzpatrick (Editor) is an editor and producer living in Brooklyn. Prior to pursuing film editing, Colin worked as an interactive and short form producer for 12 years, honing his storytelling skills working in newsrooms at outlets such as Al Jazeera and The Guardian and at WNET where he created interactive programming for PBS series such as American Masters, Great Performances, Secrets of the Dead, and Religion & Ethics Newsweekly. He is currently working as an assistant editor on an HBO docuseries which will be announced later this year.
story_txt:
Why does this project matter?Today, one in three seniors dies with Alzheimer's or another dementia. But it will be even worse in the future. The number of people developing Alzheimer's is increasing.Chances are that even if you don’t get the disease, you will know someone who has it. And chances are that you will end up caring for someone with the disease.This is what happened to me.Five years ago, I was living in Los Angeles when I received a call that my mother, Love, had wandered away from home. I made the monumental decision to leave my life in LA to move across the country to my childhood home in New Jersey to care her. With no previous caregiving experience, I was confronted with the grim reality of what it actually means to be the caregiver of someone with dementia in the USA.Every person suffering from Alzheimer’s needs at least one person to take on the responsibility for their well-being, but too often that person’s sacrifice is under-rated or taken for granted.  Alzheimer’s is the sixth leading cause of death in the USA. It is the only disease among the top ten killers without any treatment or cure.But we are not without hope.I know now what I did not know then: that what matters is having the best life possible in the present. Because we don’t have the past or the future. We just have now. We are making this film because we want to affect change. Love (yes, that is her real name) was a nurse. Her whole life was dedicated to helping others. She would not have wanted her suffering to be in vain. She would be so proud to know that because of her, other peoples’ lives were made better. There is no cure and no treatment YET for Alzheimer’s disease. Someday there will be. But in the meantime, there is so much that we can do to improve the lives of those suffering from dementia as well as their caregivers.I am a storyteller and a filmmaker. With this film, SHELTERING LOVE, my goal is to bring awareness to the plight of the caregiver, and to offer hope that even though a cure does not currently exist, there is much that can improve the lives of everyone affected by the disease—patients and caregivers alike. SHELTERING LOVE is one family’s story of finding courage, hope—even joy—while facing this devastating disease.By donating today, the future you might be changing could very easily be your own. How does Norway fit into the story?Our team is planning to travel to Norway in November 2018 for filming. Love grew up in Norway and moved to the USA when she was a young woman. She still has many family members in Norway. Her story starts there. But this is not the only reason that Norway is important to us. Love's older brother and his wife both developed and ultimately died from dementia and Alzheimer's. Their experience colored Love's own understanding of the disease and had a tremendous impact on her reaction to her own illness. We want to travel to Norway to interview the people there who can talk about what happened. Also, we will answer the question, what if Love had never left Norway? How would her care have been different there?Norway has one of the most advanced healthcare systems in the world and is on the forefront of care for dementia patients through the use of technology, living solutions, and innovations in management techniques. We want to talk with Norwegian caregivers and experts to learn about their approaches to this epidemic. What we need & What you getBecause of scheduling conflicts, it is urgent that we get the Norway segment done now, and so with this campaign we hope to be able to raise the funds necessary for this first stage of production.Right now we are seeking $12,000 to finance the filming in Norway. The $12,000 goal will fund the following:$4300 - Crew stipends (including interpreters and drone operator in Norway)$1800 - Airfare NYC to Norway for the team$300   - Travel insurance and extra baggage fees for equipment$1140 - Local transportation$2320 - Lodging and food in Norway$560   - Hard drives$1580 - Administrative and legal costsWhen you support us, along with our immensely deep gratitude, you’ll also receive some fabulous perks! To that end, we’ve designed custom-made items such as high quality sweatshirts, t-shirts and tote bags. Other Ways You Can HelpIf you’re unable to make a monetary donation at this time, but still want to help us, please reach out to us. There's so much that you can do!
Spread the word! Tell everyone you know, especially through social media (Note that Indiegogo has some built-in share tools next to the "Back it" button at the top of the page)
We also appreciate in-kind donations (i.e. any goods or services that you might be able to offer us either for free or for a discount!)
Just knowing that you care means a lot. Drop us a line and say hello!

story:
We are emerging filmmakers currently enrolled in Vancouver Film School, pursuing a career in the film industry. Looking to tell and portrait unique stories that can leave a message and give our audience a special experience of watching a film. This is our first big project, where we are looking to reach out for an audience that will support us, for further projects and can helps us grow our careers, in order for us to keep telling our new stories and ideas.

 

PRODUCER - DAVID YAEL

Aspirant Mexican Producer started his film making career as a free lancer in Mexico working with Starbucks Mexico doing advertising videos, nowadays he is studying at Vancouver Film School.

He directed his first short film “Nothing Last Forever”and he has experience being a 1st Assistant Director on 3 different productions. Now he’s looking to reach a producing career in the film industry.

 

DIRECTOR - PABLO ARTEAGA

Born and raised in Mexico city. Graduated as a Communications mayor by Universidad Anáhuac. Has a background experience as an actor and director for both theater and film.

Specializes in dark toned stories, from drama to comedy. A dark sense of humor surrounds him. He is always looking for the contrast in life.

And seeks to be a professional director for  multiple projects, such as music videos, short films and feature films.

 

WRITER - JOKIN URQUIOLA

Was born in Mexico City in 1986. He studied Audio Engineering in London Focusing in sound design for films. After graduating he began working in short films and later on as a sound editor of Netflix series and other films.

After developing a bigger interest in films and its production he went on to study Film Production to Vancouver Film School in 2018.

 

DIRECTOR OF PHOTOGRAPHY - NAOMI GONZALEZ

Mexican filmmaker born in the city of Guadalajara on February 3rd of 1998. She graduated high school at the American School of Guadalajara on June 2017 and moved to Barcelona for four months to study Audio Visuals at SAE Institute.

There she became interested in filmmaking, and is currently studying Film Production at the Vancouver Film School. Here she is specializing in cinematography and post-production.

 

PRODUCTION DESIGNER - DANIEL "SITH" DEL CASTILLO

Started studies on Mechatronic engineering but carried on as a graphic designer/animator at Universidad de las Americas Puebla; now studying at Vancouver Film School.

Daniel specializes on acrylic painting and illustrating on adobe illustrator, his work firstly reached the insurance
company Aserta where he worked for a year as a graphic designer and teaching new computer design techniques such as 3D and Photoshop, now hoping to expand on his art he is reaching to become a Design Producer.

 

1ST ASSISTANT DIRECTOR - ZARINA VASQUEZ

A former student from Educational Unit Experimental Institute “Simon Bolivar” Apucito, located on Valencia, Venezuela, which is a semi-private school for the descendants of Professors of the University of Carabobo.

Through the years, she has shown plenty of talent in many artistic ways as well as keeping good interpersonal relationships. She has emotional intelligence, as well as creativity and she is a good team worker.

 

EDITOR - PAMELA LECHUGA

Born in Mexico City, Mexico. She started working in the Television Industry in 2011 as an assistant editor for “La Academia” reality show in Tv Azteca Mexico. The same year she worked for Canal 40 as music provider for “Red Angel” a live streaming television program.

From 2012 to 2014 she worked in daily episodes of “A cada quien su santo” and “Lo que callamos las mujeres” where every chapter takes a different story.

By the end of 2014 she became a junior editor in Teleset Mexico for a television game show called “Escape Perfecto” and later she edited the soap operas “Las Bravo” y “Tanto Amor”. At 2016 she logged material for Telemundo Series “La Querida del Centauro” Season 2, while doing that she edited a daily series called “Un dia cualquiera”.

In 2017 she worked as a junior editor for MTV in the reality show “Acapulco Shore” and later as senior editor for Endemol Shine Latino “Master Chef” reality show. She went back to Teleset Mexico as postproduction coordinator until April 2018 when she went to Vancouver Film School in Vancouver where she is currently studying.

 

Our film will be a period piece, so most of our budget will be designated to the production design department, in order to increase our production value and be able to recreate the era our story is set in. We will accomplish this by building two different sets and bringing more credibility to our characters with unique make up and costume design.

We will hire a professional sound design team, because sound is a very important asset in order to bring value to a film. Also, we want to create a new score that will distinguish our project and make it stand out.

Keeping a good working environment among our crew and cast is very important for us and to accomplish this, we need to buy food to feed all the people working on this project, as we will be working several hours on the creation of this project.

 

 

PERKS

$5 CAD - With perk we will film and send you a personalized and creative thank you video by one of the member on our crew, because you are contributing to our project and you want to see it moving forward.

$10 CAD - All of the above and we will give you an "Special Thanks" credit in our film, because your contribution is very important for us and we will be able to make this project come true. Also we will give you a Social Media Shout out, in our social media pages.

$20 CAD - All of the above and you will receive (When available) a link to watch the film online or download it. So that you can see and have the film you helped to create.

$50 CAD - All of the above and you will receive a personalized digital poster signed by the crew and cast, thanking you, with your name written on it.

$100 CAD - All of the above and you will receive a video and production photos, that will show the making of "The Gallery". This material will show all the behind the scenes and process we went through to make this project.

$200 CAD - All of the above and you will receive the concept art and visual statements, the director and production designer used to make this project come to live.

 

Like all film projects, there will be unexpected variables and obstacles that will arise trough out the process of making this, but with your help we can overcome any problem and  make this project come true, because at the end of the day, we are creating this for our audience.

And with the skills of our team and the help of our audience, we know that we can create a great film.

 

We understand not everyone has the spare cash to donate, but do not worry about it.

You can help us spread the word by sharing our campaign and social media pages, where we will be updating our followers and supporters on how the production is going, as well as letting them know the process we will be going through, in order to make this project come true.

Instagram - @TheGallery_ShortFilm

Facebook Page - The Gallery - Short film

The Gallery Team, thank you for your help.

story: ?

Short Summary

The Movie... Naked If Want To  is a true story about Jim McGuire who went from being a Hippie at the "Summer of Love" in San Francisco to a combat infantry sergeant on the DMZ in Korea.   The movie tells about combat, more importantly is also tells the story of a young man who did not care about anything or anyone learning importance of love, compassion and courage in the performance of his duties.

The movie also explains by  including recently declassified information the geo-political triumph of the Korean and Vietnam wars and how the service of the men and women who participated changed the word forever.

What We Need & What You Get

We have a producer.  The funds will be used for attaching a director who has already approved the project, produce the final production screenplay and hire a casting director to begin the process of casting the movie. Once that is done this project will be financed like any other film for distribution. The total for those items including legal fees and travel should be approximately 75 to ideally 125 thousand.  Once that is done the film  will be budgeted and begin the process of producing a film  The producer has done over 60 movies.

Perks will include tickets to the premier, opportunities to apply first to work on the film, signed copies of the screenplay(digital) and of course a thank you letter from the producer of the film.

The Impact

This story was written by two disabled veteran's of Vietnam and Korea and discloses new information that the writers  feel will not only tell the cost in human terms but the effect those two wars had on the world as we know it today.

Risks & Challenge

The film like any movie might not be completed and/or once completed released as planed.  The producer estimated the risk of either of those events was less than ten percent.

We have many experienced people in the entertainment field that have experience to solve most problems that arise  the production process.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:   

We understand people may want to help but not be in a position to contribute funds.  But of one the most important things contributed to project such as this if word of mouth.  Please tell your friends and acquaintances about or movie.  There are Indiegogo tools to help share the information.  And that's all there is to it to produce a very good movie.

story:
I am writing to you on behalf of the creative team at Curesa O-Eight Productions, a black owned and woman led organization, that is working to Tell Stories that NEED To Be Told! Our current project presents an opportunity to tell a story of the often-overlooked marginalized groups in America and the importance of mental health in the community.
The Project: Is about three sisters that are bound together by a dark secret, refusing to let the outside world in. The secret is dirty and full of disease, it’s evil, it’s what made their mom paranoid. So paranoid that sometimes her own children were her enemies and the target of her deeply embedded pain, hence the horrible abuse they suffered growing up. In their still innocent eyes, it was something “out there”, that made her crazy. 
Due to its subject matter I am keen to use the film to raise awareness for the often-unspoken impact of abuse on children and the painful mental health effects when it goes unaddressed from generation to generation.
Some people still do not think of film making as an art form because of its mass entertainment qualities. Though we envision glamorous movie stars accepting awards for their exceptional performances at lavish ceremonies, an entire world of film exists outside of that notion. This is where independent film exists…It is a bridge that merges people and ideas.
Donate now and join us on this incredible journey. You have the option of making your donation, while at the same time helping to create a feature film by and about amazing women. What an exciting opportunity to be able to contribute DIRECTLY to the making of a moving, entertaining, beautiful, transformational piece of art that will be seen by audiences all over the world. We look forward to you joining our Circle of Partners!
I would like to thank you for considering this opportunity to partner with our organization for raising funds. If you have any queries regarding our organization, our fund management policy, or the project itself, please feel free to contact me at curesacure@gmail.com. Your donation will bring us closer to our goal of $150,000.
Many business and community leaders are on board as well as hundreds of individuals. Our community is clearly excited and eager to see this project succeed. You can be a part of the excitement and support our project by donating now using the link below.


Warm regards,
Curesa Clark
Writer / Director/ Producer

story:
Summary:

Shakespeare’s Othello, perhaps the finest work of tragedy ever composed, brought to the big screen. Act 3 scene 3 and act 5 scene 2 intercut into a single scene; distraught and paranoid, Othello falls prey to Iago’s vile machinations and turns on her wife, seeing the violent future with oracular vision. 

 

Goal: 

In creating this film, we aim to:

  • Deliver a faithful, compelling depiction of this brilliant scene.
  • Share our love of Shakespeare and bring the scene to a new audience.
  • Open up the character of Othello to a woman and experiment with how that changes the drama.
 

What we need:

  • Production design: we’re using a modernized military setting to foreground the trust our characters are supposed to share. If we want to do this and hold to the script, we need costumes and set decoration.
  • Props: at the apex of our scene, we have Othello throwing a bottle against a wall out of pure rage. To do this, we need multiple sugar glass bottles to ensure we get the shot.
  • Crew quality: we’re working with some incredibly talented crew who we would love to be able to compensate for their labor and expenses.
 

What you get:

  • Behind the scenes look at our production and rehearsal process; you’ll be right here beside us from start to finish.
  • Be the first to see the final cut when we release.
  • Our undying gratitude!
 

Risks and Challenges

During times like these, risks and challenges are always involved so we must be prepared for them. Here are a few ways we are preparing to take on these challenges:

  • To keep all our crew and cast safe, we will follow the regional governments regulations and employ COVID Safety Officers on set who will make sure that everything is safe and sound.
  • The text: Shakespeare is of course public domain, which means we can use and edit it as we need. Normally in film the rehearsal process takes place mainly on the day of shooting. Because of the text we’re using and how performance focused this piece is, we’re holding a whole rehearsal process in advance to make sure we get it right.
 

Other ways to help

There are more ways to help than just funding! Here are some examples:

  • Watch our film once it's available!
  • Keep an eye out for films featuring underrepresented persons in the media! 
  • Spread the word! Share the campaign with the sharing buttons at the top of the page!
 

Thanks and regards,

The Green Eyed Monster Production Team
