story:
After receiving an urgent phone call, private investigator, Gordon Walsh, arrives at the trailer-home of Shelly Grove who begs for Gordon to re-open a local cold case regarding her missing husband, Charlie. After all these years, Shelly claims that that her husband never called her again after passing through the intersection of the locally-infamous Wayward Road, an old and decrepit pathway that all the townspeople spreads ghost stories about. After accepting the case, Gordon agrees to tread into the bowels of Wayward Road in order to find Mr. Grove. The deeper he goes, the greater sense he feels that he's being watched by something... something not quite normal.

It's a modern take on American folklore. It is a reflection of modern day struggles mixed with old terrors. 

There is plenty of folklore in America, but one of the most prominent creatures is the wendigo. A wendigo is never born a monster, they are human before they commit the horrific sin of cannibalism. When this story was developed, the idea of the corrupted man was incredibly important to the writer. He wanted to create a terrifying and equally fascinating rendition of this beast while showing it parallel to a man who has also sinned. Both these characters have sinned, but one is the monstrous version of the other.

Though this is a horror movie with plenty of focus on a terrifying creature, it is also a story about human nature and the will to survive.

If you love films that focus heavily on monster horror and folklore, you will love this film. Many things about this film originate from American folklore and modern day lore. This is a story that send chills up your spine and leaves you wondering what is out there in the dark.

If you want to support filmmaking, you should support the filmmakers. 

If you’ve ever found yourself tired of Hollywood’s constant remakes and reboot and want to see new content we encourage you to support us, the next generation of filmmakers.

We are making new stories for a new era. Stories that are reflective of the world we live in.

If you are interested in this story, if it captures your attention. If you just want to know a bit more about it and what it entails, we encourage you to support us. Every penny donated is put into making sure that we create the best film possible.

story:
Campaign has ended but you can still donate through Pay Pal at torasanfilms@yahoo.com

My name is Burt Takeuchi, the film projects producer and director. My background is in film and history. Have produced a documentary film about the 442nd called Valor With Honor (2010). Also have worked on several small independent films and some Hollywood productions as an actor. The  sacrifices and heroism of Japanese American soldiers in WW2 has only been recently acknowledged. The Japanese American "Nisei" 442nd Regimental Combat Team is the most decorated unit for its size and length of service in the history of the US military. The 100th Battalion, 442nd Regimental Combat Team, and the MIS received the 2010 Congressional Gold Medal for outstanding service to the country during WW2. 

The main goals of this crowdfunding campaign are:

 

A) Upgrading editing computers and software.  More WW2 era costumes and props. Funding for food and supplies to keep our production running.

B) Unique perks include: Early release of pilot and episodes. Personal or Zoom coffee meeting with director and actors. Thank you videos and extras clips. 

C) Associate producers will receive: Zoom or personal meeting with director and actors. Credit on pilot episode and the making of video production. Invite to local screening parties.

 

The story of the Japanese American soldiers that served in WW2 has become more well known in recent years. More books and documentary films are being released on this important historical subject. An independent or Hollywood film that dramatized the story of this famous unit has only been done a few times in the last 70 years. This will be the very first web series produced on this heroic American unit. A web series will have a several short episodes per season like a television show. The project can be seen online on computers, laptops, and even cell phones.

Please contact all of your friends and family to help with our online crowdfunding campaign.

The crowdfunding campaign has been completed however you can still donate online through this site or via Pay Pal at torasanfilms@yahoo.com

Thank you, Mahalo, and Go for Broke!

 

Burt Takeuchi

Torasan Films USA

story:
The Story: High Noon — With Balloons!

Two rival balloon twisters engage in an epic duel at a children's party with incredible, magical results!

Mike, a shy entertainer who considers the balloon animals filling his apartment as his friends, is thrilled to get booked by affable dad Conner for Avery's 10th birthday party. A big kid at heart, Mike loves inspiring joy and awe in kids with his impressive balloon creations; he's also in dire need of a paycheck.

To Mike's chagrin, his nemesis Steve, a pompous showman who craves the spotlight, has been double booked by Karen, Avery's prim mom. Karen's inclined to let the two twisters vie for the coveted paycheck by competing for it. A battle of wits, talent, and creativity, the twisters' duel produces hilarious, hazardous, and reality-bending results.

Our hero realizes he must rise to the challenge in order to best his opponent in the showdown of his life. It's high noon — with balloons!


The Project: A Visually-Rich, Comedic Short

Written and directed by Kevin Murray, produced by Chip White, and based on a story developed with Ted Patterson and Zade Patterson, "A Twistful of Dollars" is intended to be a quirky comedy centered around a magical, reality-bending balloon duel. The film also incorporates themes relating to self confidence, rising to challenges and overcoming obstacles, and being true to and believing in one's self no matter what others may say or think.

The premise also highlights a unique and under-appreciated field of entertainment — balloon twisting. Just as the two twisters endeavor to bring joy to their audience of children, this short intends to bring a little joy to its audience, as well.

As balloon twisters twist, tie, combine, and form unique shapes and creations, the film's narrative and visual style will evoke that same spirit and creativity by utilizing:
- traditional with bold and fluid camera movements
- unconventional editing techniques
- a cinematic yet vibrant lighting and wardrobe palette
- whimsical original music and sound design


The Balloon Battle: We Want It to Pop!

The goal is to do most, if not all, of the balloon battle practically in camera, utilizing actual balloon weaponry props and visual gags/stunts in conjunction with clever camera movements, editing, sound effects/design, and minimal VFX flourishes.

Some preliminary pics from our early balloon props/effects tests:


A comparison to the look/feel of the final product might be the battle sequences in Edgar Wright's "Scott Pilgrim Vs. the World."

 


The Team: Collaborative Creatives


Kevin Murray - writer/director
Founder of Thingamajig Media, Kevin is an award-winning filmmaker who's been crafting and sharing stories since childhood. After working on films in New York, Kevin relocated to North Carolina where he delved into the local filmmaking scene. Named the Carolina Film Community’s 2018 Filmmaker of the Year, Kevin also earned the 2017 Director’s Award from the North Carolina Film Awards for his short film “For Love,” which achieved a lengthy award-winning national and international festival run before streaming on Amazon Prime. His previous short films “Practice” and “Little Angel” both garnered numerous awards during their festival runs, and Kevin’s screenplay for his short film “Hope” was a top-3 finalist in the 2017 Scripted Charlotte competition. In August 2020, Kevin directed the pitch pilot episode of “My Generations,” a family-centric competition show for the Magnolia Network.
 


Chip White - producer
Originally from South Carolina, Chip is the younger brother of Wheel of Fortune’s famous letter-turner Vanna White. He has more than 30 years experience in the film, TV, and video industry. Chip moved to Los Angels in the early 1980s and spent the next 20 years working for some of Hollywood’s biggest companies, including King World, Sony, MTV, VH1, Nickelodeon, and Discovery. In 2005, Chip relocated back to the Carolinas where he continues to produce and develop projects under the Stack 3 Productions banner. Producing credits include the award-winning shorts “Crab Trap,” “My Luchador,” “Black Dispatch,” and “A Chessplayer,” and the features “Electric Jesus,” “Bygone Billy,” and “Country Line.” He currently is the director of the 12th annual Joedance Film Festival.
 


Ted Patterson - “Mike”/balloon twisting supervisor
Ted is a professional balloon twister, entertainer, artist, and Charlotte-based actor who’s had roles in numerous theater productions, including Henry in William Shakespeare's "Henry V," Autolycus in Shakespeare's "The Winter's Tale," Oronte and Du Bois in Molière's "Misanthrope," Basil in "The Picture of Dorian Grey," David in "Closets Are for Clothes," and Clarin in "Life is a Dream." Ted helped develop the original story for “A Twistful of Dollars” with writer/director Kevin Murray and his brother and fellow actor Zade Patterson, and will portray the protagonist Mike in the film.
 


Zade Patterson - "Steve"
Zade is an accomplished actor, voice actor, singer, dancer, and hypnotist. His varied roles in film, television, and theater productions include the lead in writer/director Kevin Murray's award-winning "For Love" short film; characters in Fox's "Shots Fired" and Cinemax's "Outcast"; popular character Bobby Ganousch at the Carolina Renaissance Festival; and Demons in "Faust," Disciple in "Godspell," and Johnny and Tom in "Night of the Living Dead Live." Zade helped develop the original story for “A Twistful of Dollars” with writer/director Kevin Murray and his brother and fellow actor Ted Patterson, and will portray the antagonist Steve in the film.


The Goals: Inflating Dreams

Our main goal is to tell a good story, to tell it well, and for as many people as possible to see and enjoy it.

Primary distribution will target top-tier film festivals — Sundance, Tribeca, TIFF, etc. — but also regional and local fests suitable to the genre. After, we will explore distribution and/or streaming options to share the film with a wider audience.

We intend "A Twistful of Dollars" to be a "calling card" for all involved — a stellar example of our work that will garner the attention of industry professionals and serve as a stepping stone to more ambitious film projects.

We aim to roll cameras in August 2021.


The Budget: Covering the Costs

An ambitious short film with ambitious goals necessitates an ambitious budget to cover the following:

Pre-Production Costs
Rehearsals, balloon props and special effects testing, location and tech scouts.

Production Costs
Cast and crew compensation, gear rentals, location and permit fees, craft services and meals, travel, wardrobe and props, miscellaneous expenses.

Post-Production Costs
Editing, coloring, sound design, music composition, visual effects, marketing collateral.

Of our $23,000 budget, we have already secured some funding in part through the support of private donors and a grant from the Footcandle Film Society. But we need your help in order to meet our budget and complete the project! Our $12,000 crowdfunding goal will primarily go toward our cast and crew — compensation, gear rental, meals, travel, etc. — as well as other production costs.


Supporting the Cause, Reaping the Rewards
Others have already shown their support, by joining the team and/or offering financial or other assistance, but we still need YOU!

We have various support tiers and perks from which you can choose — any amount is helpful and very much appreciated!

Whether or not you can make a financial pledge at the moment, we'd still really appreciate your help in spreading the word about this campaign — you can do this by sharing this page via social media, or mentioning the project to your friends.

Or, if you have other ways to offer support (e.g., meals, props, gear, etc.), please let us know.

Thank you!


The Contact: Let's Chat!

For more info, questions, or other ways to support "A Twistful of Dollars," contact producer Chip White at chip@stack3productions.com or 704-577-3200.

story:
OVERVIEW: ABOUT THE FILM

Bad Seed is at its heart a riveting short thriller about revenge. Our story follows a seemingly sweet elderly woman named Dot. This woman replants her garden after it is destroyed by her neighbor's son Charlie. Throughout the story DOT talks to herself and her flowers, touching on themes of life, death, and regrowth. Our film takes a deadly turn when it’s revealed that Dot’s hole is much deeper than is required for gardening. 

 

BAD SEED

Our short film is told through the antagonists’ lens, portraying DOT as an innocent elderly woman. As the story twists the audience is clued into Dot’s evil nature through her poetic dialogue. Dot’s dialogue is meant to be read as a free verse poem. We were originally inspired by the ‘100 words film festival’ to create our short film series within a 100 word dialogue limit! This constraint has positively impacted our writing process by causing us to be very cautious with the words and symbols we express! After writing our fourth draft, we got into a flow, realizing that simplicity was the key to our project! Another aspect of this project that sets us apart from other productions is the time duration of our short film series. Each episode is going to take up 3 to 5 minutes of screen time so that it can be easily shared across all social media platforms. While posting to social media we will create smaller teaser trailers, and promotional videos for Tik Tok and Instagram. The idea of our promotional content is to surmise media attention, then route audiences to YouTube for the full length premiere. 

 

OUR STORY

Our writing duo first met in a 6th grade environmental science class. Even as children, Cora and I would repeatedly race against each other to finish copying our class notes so that we could have more time to; talk about our favorite movies, what our moms packed for lunch, and whatever else our ten year old minds found important at the time. Over the years we became tied to the hip, as we each found our love for art through the exploration of various mediums. The next addition to our production team was Sean Killion (DOP). We first met Sean in our Junior year of high school through mutual friends. Sean was very influential in opening my eyes to the possibilities of film, and how we could use the medium to inform, gather attention, and help those in need. Together in our Senior year of high school we did what all young filmmakers do… We made a psychological thriller about a girl struggling with addiction, who is haunted by a ghost. Yeah… While the film lacked substance, we learned a lot about ourselves, and how we work together. Most notably, we bonded. We found our passion, and realized that we wanted to pursue the film industry as a team. 

After leaving for college we each headed in different directions but still found time to; FaceTime, keep up with each other’s lives, and plan projects for when we could see each other. It was at this point that we met Michael Rodgers (Cinematography, Grip & Jack of all trades). Mike is the guy. That’s all you need to know. Together we have embarked on this journey and we hope you come along for the ride!

 

OUR TEAM

Jake Lindsay 

Jake Lindsay is one of our screenwriters, producers, and swingman for ‘Bad Seed’. Jake’s attention to detail can be seen throughout his; abstract paintings, ceramics, metal sculptures, screenwriting abilities, musical pursuits, and on set management. Jake is largely inspired by artists similar to; Salvador Dali, Claude Monet, Henry David Thoreau, Edgar Allan Poe, Andrew Bird, The Beatles, Whitney, and Fleetwood Mac. Jake is a recent graduate of Temple University where he earned his Bachelor's Degree in Media and Communications, with a concentration in Film Production. During college Jake took a wide variety of; Video & Audio Production, Visual Art, Graphic Design, Communication Theory, Advertising and Business courses. Such areas of study offered Jake the ability to understand the; time, labor, and costs associated with producing a short film from conception to distribution. Jake has applied what he's learned to his own startup art business where he sells his abstract art pieces on instagram (and can be seen at @Philly_AbstractArt). Other activities that catch Jake's attention are; this short film series, his and Cora's’ musical pursuits, hiking, live music, and managing Spruce Live content! (@ SpruceMediatv on Instagram).

 

Cora Sfida

Cora Sfida is one of our writers and producers for ‘Bad Seed’. She has also been an actor, dancer, musician, and visual artist since she was a kid. Cora takes her inspiration from artists such as; Phoebe Waller-Bridge, Alexander Ekamn, Greta Gurwig, Rainer Maria Rilke, and Elizabeth Gilbert.  She has studied at University of Wisconsin Stevens Point for a brief time studying for a BFA in Acting and a BA in Dance. Before deciding that she needed to take a leap of faith and move to her dream city, to go after the artistic life she wanted. This Spring Cora graduated from the Maggie Flanigan Studio in New York from a 2 year Professional Actor Training Program. These past two years Cora has indulged in her writing skills and has been working on 3 full length plays, screenwriting nightly with Jake, selling paintings, and becoming a certified reiki practitioner, and writing and producing music. This is Cora’s first production as a co-writer and producer for a short film. It has been her lifelong dream to create art that brings perspective to people's everyday lives.  

 

Sean Killion

Sean Killion is our Director of Photography and Concept Artist. Sean’s passion for film can be seen throughout his 3D art, screenwriting, and music. He is inspired by Kurosawa and Cubrick, who have each aided in furthering Sean’s storytelling ability. Sean is a co-founder of Spruce Media and has directed music videos for Bless Watson ‘Coastal Twist’, Tree Theatre ‘Flowers’, and Monster Energy’s ‘Up and Up’ Festival. As a concept artist Sean primarily creates environments, buildings, spaceships, and other concepts to be used in VFX post production. Sean is also a musician, and has been playing guitar and piano since he was a child. We are very lucky to have Sean as our director, and friend!

 

Mike Rogers

Mike Rogers is our Cinematography, Grip & Jack of all trades. As a Co-founder of Spruce Media Mike manages all of Spruce Media’s video content during each stage of production. Before starting Spruce Media Mike was a freelance photographer; Sporting events, Weddings, Real Estate, Modeling Photography, Portrait Photography, etc. Eventually Mike started to make videos for Rap, Hip Hop, Alternative Rock bands & solo artists. Mike has worked with Bless Watson to create ‘Blue Notes’ & ‘Coastal Twist’, Tree Theatre ‘Flowers’, and all Spruce Live content. Not only is Mike a great filmmaker, but he is a very talented musician. Mike has been playing guitar and piano since the age of 6 and taught himself by ear. Coincidentally Mike has been playing in Alternative Rock & Psychedelic Indie bands ever since middle school. Mike has helped create albums with Messin Around and Entropy. Mike has also been an event coordinator for music festivals such as; ‘Launch Music Festival’, ‘Summer of Love’, and ‘Electric Halloween’. Mike’s taste in music has been influenced by many artists such as Jim Carrey’s and Will Ferrell films, Foo Fighters, Red Hot Chili Peppers, Led Zeppelin and Greenday. For all of these reasons and more Mike is a great asset to our team and we’re very lucky to have him. 

 

RISKS and CHALLENGES

One of the biggest challenges to our production was coordinating our schedules while living in two different states. Quickly Cora and I figured out that the most efficient way to work was through drafting multiple scripts. Throughout the day we would each write drafts and idea fragments. Then later on in the evenings, we would review each of our drafts together night after night. Over time we started to pick up on each other’s writing flow, and gained speed. This system worked very well during our writing process and afforded us with a plethora of episode ideas for the series! 

Another challenge we’re faced with during our production are strict Covid compliance guidelines. This will dramatically affect how our production runs, in order to keep our cast and crew safe. We will do this by taking all the necessary steps we can without infringing on people's right to be wary of a new Covid vaccine. 

The last challenge we have learned to traverse is our communication! We repeatedly learned this, as we each struggled to let go of our original script ideas, as they matured throughout the redrafting process. We combated this by reading each of our drafts one by one, until we found the perfect layout. Through discussion we came together to mold our ideas into one cohesive piece. As a result we created something we were not only proud of, but that spoke to each of our talents. 

 

Budget breakdown:

Set Construction Cost: $1200

Construction of the garden, labor, and flowers. 

 

Location cost $600

Renting, Permits, and compensation for the owners of the location for the 3-5 days of shooting. 

 

Cast and Crew, Catering, and Travel Costs’ $4100

Total compensation for all crew: $3000 

Catering: $700

Travel: $400

 

Wardrobe and Props: $900

Will afford our Production Designer the freedom to acquire all dressing needed to create an accurate depiction of life. Props and Costumes will play a large role in telling our story accurately.

 

Covid Precautions $300

We will be following the CDC guidelines, including testing as a requirement before being on set. In addition we will have  masks, hand sanitizer, and equipment sanitation on hand, during the entire shoot. This is to protect our cast and crew who may have a auto immune deficiency, or family member with an auto immune deficiency. 

 

Festival Submissions $400

We will be submitting our short film to multiple festivals such as; . 

Web Series Festival GlobaL, Raindance WebFest, Tribeca Film Festival New Online Works (N.O.W), Austin Film Festival: Produced Digital Series Program, Catalyst Contest Festival, Chicago Indie Film Awards, New York Television Festival: Independent Pilot Program, HollyWeb Fest, LA Sci-Fi Film Festival/ LA Indie Film Festival (Web Series Program)*, Miami Web Fest

 

Total Bad Seed Budget: $7,500

 

 

FUNDING STRETCH GOALS

 

$10,000- This would allow us to cover all production costs, making sure that our cast and crew are heavily compensated for their hard work. Exceeding our goal by this amount would allow us to buy more flowers, make a larger garden, order higher quality catering, and create a safe and loving environment for our cast and crew!

 

$15,000- $20,000- This amount would allow us to really expand our horizons on the set of ‘Bad Seed’. Achieving this goal would enable our team to; hire professionals for sound design, & video editing. This goal would also provide the funds needed to rent an edelkrone, Jib One, and a larger lighting package. 

 

 

THE IMPACT AND CONTRIBUTION

While each of these pre production tasks require time and energy, nothing compares to asking YOU for help in achieving our artistic vision. With your support, we will be able to; buy more flowers to fill the entire garden, pay our actors, purchase higher quality food, and purchase additional wardrobe. In exchange for your generosity, check out our perks to see if they interest you! Our perks include; stickers, paintings, a self care bundle, T-Shirt, special thanks video, Film Trivia Night, Exclusive Premieres, BTS footage, Script Consultation, and an Executive Producer credit. Thank you to everyone who has read thus far, we appreciate you!
story_txt: OVERVIEW: ABOUT THE FILMBad Seed is at its heart a riveting short thriller about revenge. Our story follows a seemingly sweet elderly woman named Dot. This woman replants her garden after it is destroyed by her neighbor's son Charlie. Throughout the story DOT talks to herself and her flowers, touching on themes of life, death, and regrowth. Our film takes a deadly turn when it’s revealed that Dot’s hole is much deeper than is required for gardening.  BAD SEEDOur short film is told through the antagonists’ lens, portraying DOT as an innocent elderly woman. As the story twists the audience is clued into Dot’s evil nature through her poetic dialogue. Dot’s dialogue is meant to be read as a free verse poem. We were originally inspired by the ‘100 words film festival’ to create our short film series within a 100 word dialogue limit! This constraint has positively impacted our writing process by causing us to be very cautious with the words and symbols we express! After writing our fourth draft, we got into a flow, realizing that simplicity was the key to our project! Another aspect of this project that sets us apart from other productions is the time duration of our short film series. Each episode is going to take up 3 to 5 minutes of screen time so that it can be easily shared across all social media platforms. While posting to social media we will create smaller teaser trailers, and promotional videos for Tik Tok and Instagram. The idea of our promotional content is to surmise media attention, then route audiences to YouTube for the full length premiere.  OUR STORYOur writing duo first met in a 6th grade environmental science class. Even as children, Cora and I would repeatedly race against each other to finish copying our class notes so that we could have more time to; talk about our favorite movies, what our moms packed for lunch, and whatever else our ten year old minds found important at the time. Over the years we became tied to the hip, as we each found our love for art through the exploration of various mediums. The next addition to our production team was Sean Killion (DOP). We first met Sean in our Junior year of high school through mutual friends. Sean was very influential in opening my eyes to the possibilities of film, and how we could use the medium to inform, gather attention, and help those in need. Together in our Senior year of high school we did what all young filmmakers do… We made a psychological thriller about a girl struggling with addiction, who is haunted by a ghost. Yeah… While the film lacked substance, we learned a lot about ourselves, and how we work together. Most notably, we bonded. We found our passion, and realized that we wanted to pursue the film industry as a team. After leaving for college we each headed in different directions but still found time to; FaceTime, keep up with each other’s lives, and plan projects for when we could see each other. It was at this point that we met Michael Rodgers (Cinematography, Grip & Jack of all trades). Mike is the guy. That’s all you need to know. Together we have embarked on this journey and we hope you come along for the ride! OUR TEAMJake Lindsay Jake Lindsay is one of our screenwriters, producers, and swingman for ‘Bad Seed’. Jake’s attention to detail can be seen throughout his; abstract paintings, ceramics, metal sculptures, screenwriting abilities, musical pursuits, and on set management. Jake is largely inspired by artists similar to; Salvador Dali, Claude Monet, Henry David Thoreau, Edgar Allan Poe, Andrew Bird, The Beatles, Whitney, and Fleetwood Mac. Jake is a recent graduate of Temple University where he earned his Bachelor's Degree in Media and Communications, with a concentration in Film Production. During college Jake took a wide variety of; Video & Audio Production, Visual Art, Graphic Design, Communication Theory, Advertising and Business courses. Such areas of study offered Jake the ability to understand the; time, labor, and costs associated with producing a short film from conception to distribution. Jake has applied what he's learned to his own startup art business where he sells his abstract art pieces on instagram (and can be seen at @Philly_AbstractArt). Other activities that catch Jake's attention are; this short film series, his and Cora's’ musical pursuits, hiking, live music, and managing Spruce Live content! (@ SpruceMediatv on Instagram). Cora SfidaCora Sfida is one of our writers and producers for ‘Bad Seed’. She has also been an actor, dancer, musician, and visual artist since she was a kid. story:
Our Story

 

In “Closed Seams,” a newly single seamstress has to salvage a disastrous photoshoot; during the shoot, however, she finds more than just loose threads.  A quiet 16mm drama following moments of natural, human texture accompanied by grandiose photoshoot montages.  With a short 5-to-6-minute runtime, we hope to make every second pointed and impactful.  

 

Our Goals

 

Every love story begins with a brief encounter.  While they don’t always go on to mean something - see, David Lean’s Brief Encounter (1945) - they almost always begin with the same thing: friendship.  In “Closed Seams,” we’re telling the story of the meeting of two young women - both in relationships of rocky status and varying happiness.  It’s the story of how the briefest meetings, the simplest acts of kindness, have the ability to transform into life long love.   The ﬁlm leaves the latter part of that hypothesis unanswered, but we want the audience to leave feeling some sort of (right or wrong) idealized happiness - like they could ﬁnd lifelong love at any moment and any time. 

While the story follows two bisexual women, this is very much not a “lesbian” ﬁlm.  There is a place for stories of trauma and angst in minority communities, but this is not that.  It’s a love story that just so happens to follow two women - using the universal language of longing and love, and it’s our responsibility to normalize relationships and attitudes about sexuality that should have been normalized long ago.  “Closed Seams” is not a progressive romance; it’s a romance.  It’s the year 2021 and as has been screamed from rooftops for years, love is love. 

With “Closed Seams,” we’re hoping to bring a little happiness to a world plagued, at least in this year, by tragedy and depression.  We’re targeting both young and old people.  It’s not a volatile or excessively inappropriate ﬁlm.  By many metrics, it could even be labeled as inconsequential.  While that’s normally a death knell for art, maybe that’s what we need right now.  A ﬁve minute love story that will make people think, and leave them happier for the rest of their day - maybe even their week. 

 

Core Crew

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

 

While our target goal may seem like a tall order, here’s why every penny we can raise counts: As “Closed Seams” will be a post-graduation film for our director, we’ll need funds for locations, camera department, G&E equipment, and feeding our crew.  Our primary studio location will play an important part in telling our story, as it primarily takes place during a high art fashion photoshoot.  While the studio we currently have booked will provide us the room and light needed for a shoot of such caliber, our art department will play a key role in setting the scene and bringing the viewer into the world.  Similarly, we’ve chosen to shoot our story on 16mm film.  It’s an unusual choice on short films (or any film) these days, but the texture, colors, and workflow is something that is essential to our film’s aesthetic.  Finally, as many short films never see the light of day, we want to ensure that “Closed Seams” is different.  With high hopes for various festival runs upon completion, we’ve budgeted for festival submissions with intentions of presenting our film to the right audiences. 

 

Because every donation gets us closer and closer to our goal, every individual contributor will be added under a, “Special Thanks” credit of our film.  Of course, the more you donate, the more involved your perk will be, building off of previous rewards.  All digital perks will be sent out by the end of the campaign, and all physical perks will be sent out by the end of August, 2021.

 

Risks & Challenges

 

Our primary challenges for this shoot lie in safety-complications brought about by COVID 19.  Because this is our director’s first post-Covid film, we want to ensure the health and safety of all cast and crew involved during production.  While the entirety of our team is to be vaccinated by our shoot days in July, “Closed Seams” intends on providing proper safety and sanitation tools to our cast and crew at all points of production, hence our budget for sanitation and safety materials.  As the entirety of this film takes place inside, our team will wear masks during production with the exception of actors on camera during takes.  Of course, during all points of production, “Closed Seams” will be closely following CDC guidelines to provide a safe shooting environment for all involved.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t make a financial contribution to Closed Seams- we completely understand!  Here are some other valuable ways you can help bring our project to life:

  • Share this campaign with friends and family on social media!
  • Visit our website here!
  • Follow us on Instagram or Tiktok for fun BTS and pre-production teasers!
  • Support us during our film festival run!

Regardless of your contribution, we sincerely appreciate you taking the time to read through our Indiegogo and hope you consider supporting our film.

story:
Short Summary

Edison Creative has been around since 2005 and has produced 5 short films to date, three of which have received awards including Best Short Film at the Omaha Film Festival.

With your help, we are so excited to get our sixth film off the ground! Our team for this project consists of Shawn Gourley (Director), Luke Bolin (Co-Director/Executive Producer), Joel Miranda (Writer) Chad Dodd (Line Producer),  Kristin Zahra (Cinematographer), Jacob Willis (Gaffer), William Abrego (Boom Op & Sound Mixer) and Jimm Wagner (3D Visual Effects). 

In 2020, during the height of Covid19, Joel wrote a one-page short story about finding the hope in the face of a fragile and uncertain future. Shawn read it and immediately saw the story come to life in his head and asked Joel if he could make it into a short film. Joel was just as excited to see it come to life on screen. Fast forward to now and we are looking to make this vision a reality!

We are doing this campaign to raise funds for actors, an anamorphic lens rental and hopefully have enough after that to pay our crew. 

Once we complete this film, we will enter it into a few festivals and will hopefully use it as a proof of concept for a feature and possibly even a TV series. 

 

What We Need

 

Here's a breakdown of priority of how we will distribute the funding as it comes in:

  1. Talent
  2. Lens Rental
  3. Gaffer & Boom
  4. 3D Visual Effects
  5. Line Producer
  6. Music & Audio Mixing
  7. Filming, Editing & Post

 

Here's What You Get

Tier #1 "Mariner" $20

  1.  Weekly progress updates 

Tier #2 "Viking" $50

  1. Everything from "Mariner"
  2. Movie Poster 

Tier #3 "Odyssey" $100 (50 available)

  1. Everything from "Viking"
  2. Coffee table booklet of script and storyboard

Tier #4 "Maven" $500 (20 available)

  1. Everything from "Odyssey"
  2. Signed and numbered anamorphic print of still from movie
  3. Invitation to the virtual premiere of the movie

Tier #5 "Perseverance" $1000 (5 available)

  1. Everything from "Maven"
  2. Executive Producer Credit (appears on Movie Poster, Title Credits & Booklet)
 
 

Risks & Challenges

We love our clients! We also love our passion projects! They have become such an integral part of Edison Creative and have helped us scratch that creative itch of making something that we can call our own. However, like anything worth doing, passion projects are risks. In order for us to continue doing them, we need financial support. So, we are asking for your help to bring this dream to life. 

 

Spread the word for a chance to win a free gift!

If you can't contribute financially, that's OK!  If you would be willing to spread the word though, that would be awesome. Share our IndieGoGo page on Instagram and hashtag it with #ANewWorldShortFilm for a chance to win 1 of 5 coffee table books of the film.  It will contain a copy of the script, storyboards, behind the scenes photos and select frames from the movie itself!

3D Visual Effects
Line Producer
Music & Audio Mixing
Filming, Editing & Post

 
Here's What You Get
Tier #1 "Mariner" $20
 Weekly progress updates 
Tier #2 "Viking" $50

Everything from "Mariner"
Movie Poster 



Tier #3 "Odyssey" $100 (50 available)

Everything from "Viking"
Coffee table booklet of script and storyboard




Tier #4 "Maven" $500 (20 available)

Everything from "Odyssey"
Signed and numbered anamorphic print of still from movie
Invitation to the virtual premiere of the movie




Tier #5 "Perseverance" $1000 (5 available)

Everything from "Maven"
Executive Producer Credit (appears on Movie Poster, Title Credits & Booklet)


 
 



Risks & Challenges
We love our clients! We also love our passion projects! They have become such an integral part of Edison Creative and have helped us scratch that creative itch of making something that we can call our own. However, like anything worth doing, passion projects are risks. In order for us to continue doing them, we need financial support. So, we are asking for your help to bring this dream to life. 
 

Spread the word for a chance to win a free gift!
If you can't contribute financially, that's OK!  If you would be willing to spread the word though, that would be awesome. Share our IndieGoGo page on Instagram and hashtag it with #ANewWorldShortFilm for a chance to win 1 of 5 coffee table books of the film.  It will contain a copy of the script, storyboards, behind the scenes photos and select frames from the movie itself!

story:
Bienvenidos a la campaña de recaudación del cortometraje: Se busca habitacion. / Welcome to the crowdfunding page of the shortfilm: Se busca habitacion.

Conformamos un equipo de cinco jóvenes estudiantes de cine y siete actores que desean hacer realidad un proyecto de diez días de rodaje. Necesitamos tu ayuda para poder hacer posible la producción de esta tesis estudiantil.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

We are a team of five young film students and seven actors who want to make this ten day project come true. We need your help to make the production of this final project possible.

Historia / Story

Augusto es un actor desempleado y con problemas de adicción que se queda sin casa y se muda con su mama Gloria a su casa de la infancia. Augusto va a un casting para una adaptación de Hamlet y consigue una segunda oportunidad para optar por el papel protagónico, Gloria descubre que Augusto sigue consumiendo drogas a sus espaldas y lo echa de su casa. Augusto deambula por la calle en la noche y conoce a Gustavo, un indigente drogadicto que lo ayuda a preparar el personaje para el casting y lo invita a dormir con el en una montaña. Augusto consigue el papel protagónico de la obra y una habitación donde dormir, dentro del teatro.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

Augusto is an unemployed actor with addiction problems who is left homeless and moves in with his mother Gloria to his childhood home. Augusto goes to a casting for an adaptation of Hamlet and gets a chance to opt for the leading role, Gloria discovers that Augusto continues to use drugs behind her back and kicks him out. Augusto wanders down the street at night and meets Gustavo, a homeless drug addict who helps him prepare the character for the casting and invites him to stay with him on a mountain. Augusto gets the leading role in the play and a room to sleep inside the theater.

Necesitamos tu ayuda para contar esta historia / We need your help to tell this story

Con tu contribución podremos cubrir las siguientes necesidades básicas de producción:

  • Comida: 250$

Para la alimentación de un equipo técnico de cinco personas y un elenco de siete actores durante diez días de rodaje. La distribución de este dinero esta pensada para desayunos, almuerzos, cenas y meriendas durante jornadas de trabajo que pueden variar entre ocho y diez horas.

  • Transporte: 200$

Considerando la situación que se vive en Venezuela con la escasez de gasolina debido a la pandemia, el equipo técnico se mantendrá junto en un solo lugar durante todo el proceso, de manera que este dinero será distribuido exclusivamente para el transporte de los actores, en busca del ahorro debido a los elevados precios de la gasolina. Una parte será destinada a el pago de taxis de algunos de los actores y la otra parte será destinada a la compra de suficiente gasolina regulada para las personas con carro que nos ayuden a realizar el transporte de los demás actores.

  • Artículos de producción de campo: 20$

​Herramientas desechables pero de uso constante y de suma importancia para el cómodo y efectivo desarrollo de la producción, como lo son la cinta adhesiva y las baterías alcalinas.

  • Primeros auxilios: 40$

Es común que durante los rodajes ocurran accidentes y malestares debido al agotamiento. Considerando que en este caso, muchas de las locaciones son exteriores en una montaña, debemos estar preparados para enfrentar el clima, la fauna y en especial estar preparados ante cualquier accidente que pueda amenazar la integridad física del equipo.

  • Honorario de actores: 240$

​El criterio de elección del elenco que interpretara  a los personajes principales esta determinado por una propuesta de dirección que requiere cierto nivel de experiencia actoral y conocimiento teatral . En este proyecto queremos tomar en cuenta el valor del tiempo de los actores experimentados que han invertido parte de su vida en el desarrollo de su arte. Es por eso que consultamos con cada uno de los actores, la posibilidad de un acuerdo con respecto al pago de sus honorarios.  Pero siempre tomando en cuenta que el presupuesto de este proyecto y el nivel de producción es estudiantil .

  • Cámara: 150$

​La mayor parte de los equipos de iluminación y registro que se usaran para la grabación son propiedad de la Escuela nacional de cine, a la cual pertenecemos como estudiantes. Estos equipos serán prestados a nosotros como parte del acuerdo de proyecto estudiantil. Pero para que se pueda lograr la propuesta estética y visual pensada por el director y el director de fotografía, es necesario el alquiler de una cámara Sony alpha debido al rango dinámico que posee, muy distinto al que puede alcanzar una DSLR Canon ofrecida por la escuela de cine.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

With your contribution we can cover the following basic production needs:

  • Food: $ 250

For the feeding a crew of five people and a cast of seven actors during ten days of filming. The distribution of this money is for breakfasts, lunches, dinners and snacks during work days that can vary between eight and ten hours long.

  • Transportation: $ 200

Considering the situation in Venezuela with the shortage of gasoline due to the pandemic, the crew will stay together in one place throughout the process, so that this money will be distributed exclusively for the transport of the actors, in search of savings due to high gasoline prices. One part will be destined to the payment of taxis for the transportation of some of the actors and the other part will be destined to the purchase of enough regulated gasoline for people with cars that can help us transport the other actors.

  • Logistic production items: $ 20

Disposable tools of constant use and of huge importance for the comfortable and effective development of the production, such as adhesive tape and alkaline batteries.

  • First aid: $ 40

Accidents, discomfort or sickness due to exhaustion are common during filming. Considering that  many of the locations are outside on a mountain, we must be prepared to face the weather, the fauna and especially be prepared for any accident that could threaten the physical integrity of the team.

  • Actors Fee: $ 240

The criteria for choosing the cast that will play the main characters is determined by a direction proposal that requires a certain level of acting experience and theatrical knowledge. In this project we want to take into account the value of the time of experienced actors who have invested part of their lives in the development of their art. That is why we consult with each of the actors, the possibility of an agreement regarding the payment of their fees. But always taking into account that the budget for this project and the level of production It's from a student movie.

  • Camera: $ 150

Most of the lighting and recording equipment that will be used is property of the Escuela nacional de cine, to which we belong as students. These kits will be loaned to us as part of the student project agreement. But, to achieve the aesthetic and visual proposal thought by the director and cinematographer, it is necessary to rent a Sony alpha camera due to its dynamic range, which is very different than the one offered by the film school, a Canon DSLR.

Visión del director / Director's vision

Este es un proyecto creado con la motivación de dedicárselo a todas las personas que necesitan expresarse y crear para vivir, pero que no lo consiguen o les cuesta mantenerse económicamente haciendo lo que les gusta.

Para el desarrollo de esta idea pensé en combinar lo que me mueve a crear como artista y lo que se me opone para lograrlo. En mi caso, lo que me mueve es expresar mi visión del mundo y comunicar lo que siento de una forma hermosa a través de una historia. Lo que se me opone es el poco tiempo que tengo para hacerlo, ya que si quiero pagar las cuentas, en la mayoría de los casos debo trabajar en cosas que no me permiten expresarme como quiero. Por otro lado, la única manera de hacerlo es dejar de poner excusas y hacer todo lo que esté en mi poder por equilibrar mi tiempo, pero esto suele convertirse en una situación tan estresante que me lleva a recurrir al auto saboteo y a manejar el estrés con distracciones que solo hacen que pierda más tiempo.

Como estudiante de una escuela de cine en la última etapa de sus estudios, son constantes los pensamientos de miedo y las interrogantes sin respuesta acerca de la sustentabilidad económica de mi profesión en Venezuela, un país sin una industria de cine establecida y con pocas esperanzas de que eso cambie en un tiempo cercano. Por otro lado, creo que este tema sobre el desarrollo profesional y la incertidumbre, se combinan con la manera en que veo como los jóvenes lidiamos con los problemas. La experimentación con drogas y alcohol suele ser algo común durante la juventud y más si se trata de un ambiente creativo. Pero esto también representa un riesgo muy real, ya que cuando las adicciones nacen en la juventud es posible que una persona pase por varios estadios, desde etapas de auto sabotaje para su desarrollo como persona, hasta llevarlo a una total decadencia en la toma de decisiones y que terminan por arruinar la vida de alguien con talento y potencial.

Esa es la historia que quiero contar, la de una persona con talento que no superó sus etapas de experimentación adolescente y que nunca llegó a alcanzar su máximo potencial por el auto sabotaje, alguien que por miedo a no lograrlo, no hizo lo necesario para superarse y encontrar su lugar en el mundo haciendo lo que le gusta, pero que ahora la vida le brinda una nueva oportunidad de lograrlo y empezar de nuevo.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

This is a project created with the motivation of dedicating it to all the people who need to express themselves and craft in order to live, but do not succeed at it, or find difficult to maintain themselves economically doing what they love.

For the development of this idea, I thought about combining what moves me as an artist to create and what is against me to achieve it. What moves me is expressing my vision of the world and communicating what I feel in a beautiful way through a story. What is against me is the little time I have to do it, because if I want to pay the bills, in most cases I have to work on things that don't allow me to express myself as I wish I could. On the other hand, the only way to do that is to stop making excuses and do everything in my power to balance my time, but this often becomes such a stressful situation that it leads me to self-sabotage and to manage stress with distractions that only waste more time.

As a film student in the last stage of my studies, the thoughts of fear and unanswered questions about the economic sustainability of my profession in Venezuela are constant, in a country without an established film industry and with little hope of this changing in the near future. I think this subjects about professional development and the uncertainty of the future is combined with the way I see young people dealing with their problems. Experimentation with drugs and alcohol is something common during youth and can be even closer if it's a creative environment. This also represents a very real risk, because if addictions are born during youth it's possible that they go through multiple stages, from stages of self-sabotage, to leading a person to a total decline in decision-making that ends up ruining the life of someone with talent and potential.

The story I want to tell is about a talented person who did not overcome his stages of adolescent experimentation because of self-sabotage and never reached his full potential, someone who because of fear of never making it, did not do what it takes to improve himself and find his place in the world doing what he loves. But now life gives him a new opportunity to achieve that and start over.

Otras formas de ayudar / Other Ways You Can Help Us

  • Comparte esta campaña en tus redes sociales o con cualquier persona que nos pueda ayudar, amigos o familia.
  • Síguenos en instagram @Sebuscahabitacion

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

  • Share this campaign on your social networks or with anyone who can help us, friends or family.

  • Follow us on instagram @Sebuscahabitacion

story:
The Shed Overview

The Shed is a short film that deals with complicated relationships, family drama, and coming to terms with the past. Following the death of their father, two middle aged brothers, David and Mark, return to their hometown to find closure for the past. As they rummage through heir father's possessions they find that the only way they can learn more about their deceased father's past is by looking in his toolshed. Will the brother's find the secrets behind their father's alcoholism and abuse, or will he remain the enigma he was during their childhood?  

The Team

Director - Curtis Patsiga. Writer and Director of The Shed. I've Previously worked on short films like The Curse of the Creature and Stories of the End of the World. I've also worked on music videos for songs such as:  We Used to Vacation by Cold War Kids and Mr. Clean by Young Gravy. I'm extremely passionate about film, I love filmmaking and critical studies. I'm a huge fan of slow cinema with some of my favorite films being: Nebraska (2013), Kaili Blues (2015), and There Will Be Blood (2007).  

Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCekeV0JhbJnqWb...

Producer - Dillon Tavitian. Director of short films like The Last Stream, Hide & Sleep, Isolation, and A Portrait of  Cats. I love all genres, especially horror and sci-fi, and I am really excited to work on this project. Some of my favorite films include Pulp Fiction, Let Me In, and Office Space. I've never really worked on a slow drama before and I know this will be a learning experience, as well as a great one.

Producer -  Coleen Finn. Director of short films like The Hair, Lonely, What Lies Behind The Closet, The Kid, The Sandwich, and Chips, and What Is Beauty.  Edited films like Halloweenie, The Hair, What Lies behind the closet, The Kid, The sandwich and Chips, and What is Beauty. has written the screenplay for The Red Line. Some of my favorite films include Psycho, Marnie, The Shining, Star Wars, Back to the Future, and The Money Pit. This is my first drama and I am excited to work and learn with the rest of the group. I was drawn to the film because the story has elements that are very familiar to my own experiences.

Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCbeRgP0CZOIGJJ... 

Cinematographer - Nicholas Capers.  DP of short films such as Visions, Scoob, and Silenced. As an image-based creator, my main goal is to make your project as pretty as possible. I have been working with DSLR/Mirrorless cameras for 8 years now and typically lean more towards darker, more deliberate psychological stories. I am super excited by the pace of this project and how it will enable me to practice long shots and really test my cinematography endurance.

Website: https://capers-videography.webnode.com

*We will employ additional crew (PA's, sound, etc.)

The Budget 

Like all movie productions, we need money for food, costumes, sets, travel, fees, equipment, rentals, production design, and lodging, along with other essential needs. 

The Shed cost - $3,000

  • Even if we don't make our budget, we will adapt, like any filmmaker. Things might be changed but we will carry on.
  • We appreciate any and all donations!

Risks & Challenges

Filmmaking is tough and challenging, we're not gonna lie. No one can predict the future so we are prepared for anything to happen, from scheduling changes, to technical difficulties, to bad weather. 

BUT...

  • We will work things out, like any professional filmmaker does.
  • We will think outside the box and not be constrained by anything.
  • We will adjust accordingly.

COVID-19

We understand that this is a difficult time but we will take every precaution to keep people safe and healthy.

  • Provide hand sanitizer and cleaning materials.
  • Provide extra masks. 
  • Social distance.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute financially, you can at least help by letting the world know!

  • Share on social media!
  • Get the word out! 

Thank you very much!

-The Crew

The Shed is a short film that deals with complicated relationships, family drama, and coming to terms with the past. Following the death of their father, two middle aged brothers, David and Mark, return to their hometown to find closure for the past. As they rummage through heir father's possessions they find that the only way they can learn more about their deceased father's past is by looking in his toolshed. Will the brother's find the secrets behind their father's alcoholism and abuse, or will he remain the enigma he was during their childhood?  

The Team

Director - Curtis Patsiga. Writer and Director of The Shed. I've Previously worked on short films like The Curse of the Creature and Stories of the End of the World. I've also worked on music videos for songs such as:  We Used to Vacation by Cold War Kids and Mr. Clean by Young Gravy. I'm extremely passionate about film, I love filmmaking and critical studies. I'm a huge fan of slow cinema with some of my favorite films being: Nebraska (2013), Kaili Blues (2015), and There Will Be Blood (2007).  
Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCekeV0JhbJnqWb...

Producer - Dillon Tavitian. Director of short films like The Last Stream, Hide & Sleep, Isolation, and A Portrait of  Cats. I love all genres, especially horror and sci-fi, and I am really excited to work on this project. Some of my favorite films include Pulp Fiction, Let Me In, and Office Space. I've never really worked on a slow drama before and I know this will be a learning experience, as well as a great one.

Producer -  Coleen Finn. Director of short films like The Hair, Lonely, What Lies Behind The Closet, The Kid, The Sandwich, and Chips, and What Is Beauty.  Edited films like Halloweenie, The Hair, What Lies behind the closet, The Kid, The sandwich and Chips, and What is Beauty. has written the screenplay for The Red Line. Some of my favorite films include Psycho, Marnie, The Shining, Star Wars, Back to the Future, and The Money Pit. This is my first drama and I am excited to work and learn with the rest of the group. I was drawn to the film because the story has elements that are very familiar to my own experiences.
Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCbeRgP0CZOIGJJ... 
Cinematographer - Nicholas Capers.  DP of short films such as Visions, Scoob, and Silenced. As an image-based creator, my main goal is to make your project as pretty as possible. I have been working with DSLR/Mirrorless cameras for 8 years now and typically lean more towards darker, more deliberate psychological stories. I am super excited by the pace of this project and how it will enable me to practice long shots and really test my cinematography endurance.
Website: https://capers-videography.webnode.com
*We will employ additional crew (PA's, sound, etc.)

The Budget 
Like all movie productions, we need money for food, costumes, sets, travel, fees, equipment, rentals, production design, and lodging, along with other essential needs. 
The Shed cost - $3,000

Even if we don't make our budget, we will adapt, like any filmmaker. Things might be changed but we will carry on.
We appreciate any and all donations!



Risks & Challenges
Filmmaking is tough and challenging, we're not gonna lie. No one can predict the future so we are prepared for anything to happen, from scheduling changes, to technical difficulties, to bad weather. 
BUT...

We will work things out, like any professional filmmaker does.
We will think outside the box and not be constrained by anything.
We will adjust accordingly.

COVID-19
We understand that this is a difficult time but we will take every precaution to keep people safe and healthy.

Provide hand sanitizer and cleaning materials.
Provide extra masks. 
Social distance.


Other Ways You Can Help
If you cannot contribute financially, you can at least help by letting the world know!

Share on social media!
Get the word out! 

Thank you very much!-The Crew

story:
“Somewhere up there on the hill, there's a screeching roar. A mechanical, unearthly gargle. A sound that would wake up the dead and silence the living.”

 

 

THE STORY

Skinjacker a sci-fi/horror tale that features a lesser-known creature from Scottish mythology. It brings to life a dark and mysterious beast, but when mixed with a sci-fi element, it adds to the horror and suspense of the story with an approach rarely seen in films coming out of Scotland.

This is a story that focuses on the escape and survival of the characters within it, yet it is the stunning, bleak Scottish landscapes and the unpredictability of the story which play the biggest parts.

 

CINEMATOGRAPHY

We will be looking towards the use of a shallow depth of field when we are amongst the cast to contrast the wide expansive landscapes that Scotland has to offer, but we won’t be restricted to this. When the moment presents itself, we will engage with their surroundings as the shadows around them grow long.

Both cinematographer Thomas Dobbie and Director David Izatt have dark, moody styles, so expect a very atmospheric film (Skinjacker being their 8th film project together).

"We see shots of the hills, shadows are deep and long now and the light is fading fast. Clouds swarm across the sky like they are in a hurry to escape the approaching night and the cold, bitter and unrelenting bite that it offers."

 

WRITER / DIRECTOR

The film was written by and will be directed by David Izatt.

In 2018 his debut feature film (as director) ‘A Christmas Carol’ was released on Amazon Prime TV. Before that he worked as a cinematographer on the horror film ‘Plan Z’ which was released on Netflix and the Martin Scorsese produced film ‘Tomorrow’ as EPK Producer and the official stills photographer, working with Stephen Fry, James Cosmo and musician Joss Stone amongst others.

 

CREW

While David is also producing the film, our experienced team also includes:

  • Thomas Dobbie (The Necromancer) - Cinematographer
  • Keith Nicholl (Bannan) - Production Manager
  • Khaled Spiewak (Schemers) - Editor
  • Chris Capaldi (Tellurian) - Assistant Producer
     

 

 

CAST

Featuring a very large cast for a sci-fi/horror feature film, including:

Marcus Macleod (The Necromancer, Convergence) as 'Jimmy'.

 

Jacob Anderton (13 Graves, I Am Vengeance: Retaliation) as 'Trevor'.

 

Nicolette McKeown (Feel The Dead, Convergence) as 'Sarah'.

 

Richard Ashton (Vikings, Dr Who, The Fifth Element) as 'Myce'.

 

Reanne Farley (Schemers, Shetland) as 'Vivian'.

 

Gareth Morrison (Tommy's Honour, Outpost: Rise of the Spetsnaz) as 'Baz'.

 

The cast also includes, Eugene Horan, Rebecca Wyman, Ryan Livingstone, Sarah Meikle, Grant R Keelan, Chris Capaldi, Gordon J Millar, Scott Ironside and Vivien Taylor.

 

INFLUENCES

You can't make a film without an influence from another in some way, shape or form. We draw influences from classics such as Alien and The Thing as well as incredibly moody Scottish set sci-fi / horrors such as Under the Skin.

But we also draw inspiration from the likes of 'Stranger Things', the German sci-fi series 'Dark', Korean Monster movie 'The Host' and recently the Russian TV series 'To The Lake'.

 

THE MONSTER

No proper sci-fi / horror isn't complete without a brilliant 'monster' and Skinjacker certainly has this in it's locker.

You can grab the original concept design for The Mycelinid by artist John Cameron on a t-shirt or poster as one of our perks.

 

THE SET BUILD

Set building started in July 2020 at our Soundstage in Dunfermline, Fife.  It is a massive undertaking with several interior rooms being built along with a very sci-fi looking area. Some of our exciting perks will offer you an insight as to what's going on behind the scenes. With highly classified A4 posters available for those that purchase the signed script perk.

 

THE CAMPAIGN & WHAT WE NEED

We aim to create a feature film in Scotland which is topical, original and has the potential to expand into an entire franchise.  But we need your help in getting us there.

We are aiming to raise a minimum of £20,000.  With these additional funds we will be able to complete our amazing set build at our soundstage.  Funds will also go towards travel, accommodation, transport, location fees, equipment rentals, expenses, catering and more.

 

OTHER WAYS TO HELP

Can't contribute? That's ok, but if you could please help us by spreading the word and getting this crowdfunder shared around Social Media. The more people that hear about this sci-fi / horror feature film, the better the chance we have of reaching our goal!

THANK YOU!
Team Skinjacker :)



Perks:

 

 

Thank you!

story:
Short Summary

Welcome to the crowdfunding campaign for my incoming Public Service Announcement - “Ey! Don’t Pick”. My name is Lily Huang and I am a student film director at New York University. I came to the United States almost 8 years ago to pursue my education with fresh curiosity, keen determination on broadening my understanding of the world, and most importantly, full faith in making the world a better place where people from all walks of life comfortably hold respectful conversations with one another. All of these remain my deepest passion till this day. Yet, violence and distrust seems to have strangled us at the moment. You are mostly likely aware of the horrifying hate crimes against the AAPI community in the United States that spiked since the beginning of the COVID pandemic. Putting the pain into words at the moment even seems surreal to me, in the worst way possible. It is a feeling of unbearable anguish as if someone had wiped out my ability to form sentences — tell me, if you can, where and how do I begin to explain my humanity?
 

This piece is me bundling up my energy as a Chinese woman, a filmmaker, a resident of New York City,  and a human who simply cannot tolerate and stay quiet when innocent people, let alone elderlies, are being beaten up and smashed to the ground. This 30-second PSA might feel short and my influence as a filmmaker may not be big enough to beat the roaring monster of hate and prejudice instantly. But it is with your help that we might be able to do something. And at the end of the day, there is just something more significant than “usefulness”. This particularly goes out to my fellow AAPI brothers and sisters, uncles and aunties, grandmas and grandpas. I know it is hard for us to endorse our believe in things getting better at the moment, but I want you to know that together we are not alone. We do something, anything, one thing at a time. Doing is everything.

 

Mood Board

 

What We Need & What You Get

It means so much to know that people care. Historically, the society has been accustomed to the "quietness" of Asian population. Not talking or talking with many apologies and a small volume is always expected.

Please know that by contributing into this campaign, financially or not, you are amplifying and enhancing that voice. My deepest thankfulness to each and everyone of you.

Please refer to the following pie charts for more detailed funding delegations. All of the following numbers are estimates and a 10% contingency is planned. 

 

 

Risks & Challenges

One of the major concerns of the crew in terms of the production of our PSA is that safety of the set, COVID but mostly the more deadly virus - hate. The shoot is set to take place in Chinatown, Manhattan. We would really appreciate if you know any resources that could potentially help us build a plan around ensuring the safety of everybody involved in the production.

Please do not hesitate to reach out to my email with any information you think might help. My email address is: lilywenyihuang@nyu.edu 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

No amount is ever too small. If you can, by all means, please spread the word! Link this campaign page to your friends and families or anyone you think of. 

谢谢你，亲爱的陌生人。（Thank you, though I don't know who you are.）

story:
On a hot summer day, Faye and Dan are out on a drive. When Faye suddenly notices she is being watched by a figure, she falls into a series of supernatural events. In a harried sprint, Faye is forced to reckon with her emotions. Will this experience be an opportunity for growth or a descending spiral into further panic?

We are a team of young and inspired creatives brought together by our shared passion for filmmaking. Our goal is to tell a narrative that is universal but relatable at a deeply personal level. 

With Sprint, we want to tell the familiar story of getting lost in our thoughts and avoiding confronting difficult emotions. Sometimes we can be our greatest barrier to growth. Sometimes we need to sit through the discomfort to become our most authentic selves. Sometimes... it takes a sprint. 

Faye's introspective journey tells this story with a supernatural twist. Our vision for Sprint has challenged us to explore new filming, lighting, and editing techniques. With your support, we want to continue to push ourselves to share our best work!

SPRINT - Storyboard to Sketch

During pre-production we tediously go over our script, map out a storyboard and familiarize ourselves with our set location to put forth our best work!

 

SPRINT - Mood Board

We took inspiration from works such as Drive, Nomadland, Sleep on the Floor by the Lumineers, Waves, The Handmaiden and Into the Who Knows!

 

BUDGET BREAKDOWN

Filming Equipment - renting lens kits, lighting equipment, filming monitors from Ontario Camera.
Wardrobe & Design - so that our set and cast look fantastic!
Transportation - covering transportation (fuel, public transport) costs for our cast and crew.
Set Operations  - catering and set equipment to keep our cast and crew safe and healthy!
Contingency Plan - emergency fund for any unforeseen costs. 

This is a passion project and we will not be pocketing any of the money raised for this film. We have put our hearts into overseeing our growth in skills and ensuring that we can put forth our best work!

We have been monitoring and following COVID-19 safety regulations in Ontario to keep our cast and crew safe. This includes COVID screening before shoots and hosting production meetings online and outdoors. 

In the event that we do not meet our fundraising goal we plan to reduce our equipment budget in a way that will not affect the overall quality of our film.

If you have any questions or concerns please feel free to reach out to us through our campaign, email: studio.pavilion123@gmail.com, OR instagram: @studiopavilion.

You might be wondering: how can I show my support? 
We appreciate any support whether it be through donating or sharing our page!

Want to donate?

No amount is too little!
Every dollar counts and can help us take a step towards:

  • Securing filming equipment (lighting, monitor, camera) 
  • Making sure our cast looks amazing (wardrobe, makeup) 
  • Keeping our cast and crew safe and fed! (catering, transportation) 

Want to show some love to our page?

  • Share our page with your family and friends! 

We'd love to have you around for our journey. Follow us on IG: @studiopavilion to keep up with our progress.

story:
A British lone soldier’s plan to tell his family that he left the IDF becomes impossible when he arrives home to a surprise party in celebration of his service.

Our short film is based on Jonah’s and other’s personal experiences of being a lone soldier in the IDF and growing up in the British Jewish community. 

The film tells David's story, a Jewish boy who escapes to London after realising that the Israeli army was a lot more than just wearing a cool uniform and eating falafel. However, his plan to tell his family that he left the IDF becomes impossible when he arrives home to an outlandish surprise party in celebration of his service. David struggles to reveal his secret as his different family members ambush him - his crazy Uncle, who believes he served in the Six-Day War even though he's never stepped foot outside of Golders Green; his obnoxious cousin, who runs the local BDS campaign at her campus; and his proud mum, who is desperate to show off her "soldier boy". This leads to the question, will David be brave enough to tell his family the truth?

דויד, חייל בודד בצה"ל מחליט לברוח משירותו הצבאי בצה"ל אחרי שהבין שהצבא הרבה יותר מורכב ממה שהוא דמיין וחשב. הוא חוזר הביתה לבריטניה במטרה לספר את האמת למשפחתו אבל נתקל בקבלת פנים אוהדת במיוחד כשהמשפחה ארגנה לו - מסיבת הפתעה לחגוג את שירותו. הניסיון להסתיר את הסוד מול המשפחה הגאה, מוביל לסדרת מצבים משעשעת אל מול אמו הפטריוטית, הדוד "המורעל" ואחותו שמנהלת את קמפיין ה BDS בקמפוס. מה שמוביל לשאלה האם דויד יהיה מוכן לומר את האמת?

באמצעות הסרט וכלים סאטיריים אנחנו רוצים לעורר שיח על עיצוב הזהות של יהודים רבים ברחבי העולם, על החיבור למדינת ישראל ועל הפער הבין דורי שקיים כיום בקרב יהדות התפוצות.

 

Jonah Moore | Screenwriter 

Born and raised in North London, here in the UK. Passionate about stories that cover jewish experiences - anything from Israel, to Rabbis, to Kugel. Stand up comedian and Head of Screenwriting at Watch Network

Keren Shefet | Producer

Experienced Producer & Creator with expertise in theatre and screen sectors. Passionate about Israeli and Jewish culture. Created and produced a wide range of initiatives including theatre plays, marketing and social content, TV broadcasts and festivals.  Currently completing her Masters in film producing at the Met Film School in London

Tal Cicurel | Director

Director & Editor, with extensive experience in short-form media such as commercials, music videos and trailers, Tal is bringing his unique sensibilities to this project. His experience ranges from high fashion and international car commercials to sketch comedy and documentary.

Our short film is based on Jonah’s personal experiences of being a lone soldier in the IDF and growing up in the British Jewish community. Even though we are a tiny minority in the UK, people don’t realise how diverse we are in opinion. After all, we all know the saying: three Jews equals five opinions! 

Growing up in the Jewish community in London, everyone grows up being taught one thing by their school and their family, but when they go to university, start working or even like Jonah, join the army, you then learn that you need to form your own voice. However, the great thing about being Jewish is there is no right way to be a Jew. 

This short film does not attempt to debate any of the moral questions of the IDF. Instead, we aim to provide an amusing insight into the culture of British Jewry in the UK, which is an under-represented ethnic minority.  Therefore, we want to help bring more Jewish stories to the spotlight. Through the medium of humour, we hope this film will encourage all minority voices to be listened to within the Jewish community and raise meaningful discussions about Jewish identity around the diaspora.

We plan to shoot our short film this winter and we need the budget to cover all the production and marketing expenses, so that we can participate in short film festivals and broadcast this story infront of Jewish communities and organizations around the world.

All of our funding will go towards:

Locations fees 

Camera & Film Equipment Rentals 

Film Crew

Cast 

Traveling expenses

Set Design & Props 

Catering

Covid measures

Craft Services 

Contingency plan 

Ads & Marketing 

Film Editing 

Sound Design & Sound Mixing 

Film Festival Fees

Screening & Film Release 

Distribution

Taxes & Indiegogo Fees 

Other Miscellaneous Fees

 

We invite you to share this with your family and friends and ask them to do the same. Every little bit matters and helps us bring this story into the world.
