The film tells David's story, a Jewish boy who escapes to London after realising that the Israeli army was a lot more than just wearing a cool uniform and eating falafel. However, his plan to tell his family that he left the IDF becomes impossible when he arrives home to an outlandish surprise party in celebration of his service. David struggles to reveal his secret as his different family members ambush him - his crazy Uncle, who believes he served in the Six-Day War even though he's never stepped foot outside of Golders Green; his obnoxious cousin, who runs the local BDS campaign at her campus; and his proud mum, who is desperate to show off her "soldier boy". This leads to the question, will David be brave enough to tell his family the truth?
דויד, חייל בודד בצה"ל מחליט לברוח משירותו הצבאי בצה"ל אחרי שהבין שהצבא הרבה יותר מורכב ממה שהוא דמיין וחשב. הוא חוזר הביתה לבריטניה במטרה לספר את האמת למשפחתו אבל נתקל בקבלת פנים אוהדת במיוחד כשהמשפחה ארגנה לו - מסיבת הפתעה לחגוג את שירותו. הניסיון להסתיר את הסוד מול המשפחה הגאה, מוביל לסדרת מצבים משעשעת אל מול אמו הפטריוטית, הדוד "המורעל" ואחותו שמנהלת את קמפיין ה BDS בקמפוס. מה שמוביל לשאלה האם דויד יהיה מוכן לומר את האמת?
באמצעות הסרט וכלים סאטיריים אנחנו רוצים לעורר שיח על עיצוב הזהות של יהודים רבים ברחבי העולם, על החיבור למדינת ישראל ועל הפער הבין דורי שקיים כיום בקרב יהדות התפוצות.
 


Jonah Moore | Screenwriter 
Born and raised in North London, here in the UK. Passionate about stories that cover jewish experiences - anything from Israel, to Rabbis, to Kugel. Stand up comedian and Head of Screenwriting at Watch Network
Keren Shefet | Producer
Experienced Producer & Creator with expertise in theatre and screen sectors. Passionate about Israeli and Jewish culture. Created and produced a wide range of initiatives including theatre plays, marketing and social content, TV broadcasts and festivals.  Currently completing her Masters in film producing at the Met Film School in London
Tal Cicurel | Director
Director & Editor, with extensive experience in short-form media such as commercials, music videos and trailers, Tal is bringing his unique sensibilities to this project. His experience ranges from high fashion and international car commercials to sketch comedy and documentary.

Our short film is based on Jonah’s personal experiences of being a lone soldier in the IDF and growing up in the British Jewish community. Even though we are a tiny minority in the UK, people don’t realise how diverse we are in opinion. After all, we all know the saying: three Jews equals five opinions! 
Growing up in the Jewish community in London, everyone grows up being taught one thing by their school and their family, but when they go to university, start working or even like Jonah, join the army, you then learn that you need to form your own voice. However, the great thing about being Jewish is there is no right way to be a Jew. 
This short film does not attempt to debate any of the moral questions of the IDF. Instead, we aim to provide an amusing insight into the culture of British Jewry in the UK, which is an under-represented ethnic minority.  Therefore, we want to help bring more Jewish stories to the spotlight. Through the medium of humour, we hope this film will encourage all minority voices to be listened to within the Jewish community and raise meaningful discussions about Jewish identity around the diaspora.

We plan to shoot our short film this winter and we need the budget to cover all the production and marketing expenses, so that we can participate in short film festivals and broadcast this story infront of Jewish communities and organizations around the world.
All of our funding will go towards:
Locations fees 
Camera & Film Equipment Rentals 
Film Crew
Cast 
Traveling expenses
Set Design & Props 
Catering
Covid measures
Craft Services 
Contingency plan 
Ads & Marketing 
Film Editing 
Sound Design & Sound Mixing 
Film Festival Fees
Screening & Film Release 
Distribution
Taxes & Indiegogo Fees 
Other Miscellaneous Fees We invite you to share this with your family and friends and ask them to do the same. Every little bit matters and helps us bring this story into the world.

story:
€20,221.37 raised as of 1 February 2021 (incl. PayPal backers)! THANK YOU!

Principal photography on "Debutante" completed on 5th September 2020!

For updates on post-production, check out the updates page or click here,

 

Click on the language for: English | Deutsche | Français | Italiano | Polski 

 

Short Summary

My name is Kamila Dydyna and I'm a Polish filmmaker based in Dublin. I've wanted to make films for as long as I remember. 

When I was growing up though, I could have just as well wished to join NASA and visit the Moon. At the time, I was a member of the Jehovah's Witnesses community. My life revolved around regular preaching sessions, meetings with the congregation, studying the Bible and so on. Even dreaming about a career in anything else than being a stellar Jehovah's Witness was, technically speaking, forbidden.

Fast forward about 25 years, multiple metaphorical earthquakes later, I clawed my way out of the religious fervour, through an adventure with corporate life, and into a freelance filmmaking world. I avoided talking about my past as a Jehovah's Witness for many years after I had left the religion. I was ashamed, I felt like a victim, and I was angry. But now I'm at a point in my life where I realised I can't walk away from that aspect of my past completely, at least not before making this film.

In the past few years, I made two short films (more on that later), and I'm now ready to tell the story of Debutante, in partnership with Atheist Ireland, an advocacy group promoting secularism.

 

What is the film about?

Debutante is a short, contemporary drama set in the world of Irish Jehovah's Witnesses. It's a story of an 18-year-old Meg, who experiences, in a rather sever way, the overbearing religious control practiced by the members of this community. At its heart, it's a film about growing up.

My intention with Debutante is to avoid a demeaning, hateful or sensationalist approach (as one often used with the subject of Jehovah’s Witnesses) in favour of one more compassionate. 

There are over 8.5 million Jehovah's Witnesses in the world and they operate in exactly the same way in each of the 240 countries and territories where they live. As such, it felt natural to set this story in Dublin which has been my home for over 12 years now.

In the film, the exciting energy of young love and early experience of sexuality are met with the unforgiving and violating judgement by the religion elders. It’s a story of how receiving a mindf*ck of cognitive dissonance can shake loose the fundaments of who you think you are.

The title refers to the French origin of the word - "stepping out into the world for the first time" or being a beginner, a person that begins life as an adult.

 

    Why Support This Particular Film?

    It is commonly thought that Jehovah's Witnesses - and any issues surrounding them - are a minority subject, not necessarily warranting attention. Except, of course, the commonly known issues related to the refusal of blood transfusion and the protection of pedophiles within their ranks, highlighted recently by the Australian Royal Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Abuse and a growing number of high profile court cases.

    I think the negative impact Jehovah's Witnesses have on the global community is even more widespread. Let me explain why.

    My Mum started hanging out with Jehovah’s Witnesses when I was about 10 years old. I couldn’t tell you why and how but within a year, I was completely hooked on the world and the beliefs of this religion. A sense of belonging to something special and greater than me was so intense, it went to my head. 

    Nobody made me do it – at the age of 13, I was thrilled to be baptised as a Jehovah’s Witness in a portable pool set at a sports stadium in Wrocław, Poland. I was wearing a long T-shirt over my swim suit, for modesty.

    I used to believe that everyone who wasn’t a Witness was going to die an awful, ugly apocalyptic death. If I wasn’t conscientious and faithful in every little thing, I was going to die too. 

    The worst lot of all – to be avoided at any cost – was to be disfellowshipped (shunned.) It meant that none of your Jehovah’s Witnesses friends (and family if they were strict enough) would ever speak to you again. They would cross the road if they saw you on the street. And you wouldn’t have anyone else to turn to because having“worldly friends” was also not on.

    To be disfellowshipped meant that your world as you know it explodes and you become a ghost. You’re Bruce Willis in The Sixth Sense.

    In early 2008, on the day I decided I no longer wanted to be a Jehovah's Witness, I felt like I was dying to my life and relationships as I knew them. It was a bit like (I imagine) the experience of being born - naked, terrified, and disconnected from the only safe place you had known - except as an adult.

    In 2018, the number of people baptised as Jehovah's Witnesses around the world was 281,744. However, a statistic that's harder to find is the number of people who got disfellowshipped (kicked out) or who left of their own initiative. That number is estimated at 70,000 - every year.

    Taking into account those who return to the JW organisation, that's still at least a million people in recent years who had to find ways of creating a life from scratch outside of the religion's boundaries.

    In best-case-scenarios, they deal with mental health issues resulting from a lifetime of indoctrination. They have to seek out new friends, relationships, careers and hobbies - all to keep it together outside of the JW world.

    In worst-case-scenarios, they hang themselves in their bathrooms, while their children and spouses watch TV in the living room.

    I deeply believe this is an issue worth talking about. And I hope my film will bring comfort to anyone who experienced shunning - for religious or other reasons. 

     

    What We Need & What You Get

    I'm deeply committed to making the film happen. However, I'm just as committed to giving this story an opportunity to reach the quality it deserves, and for that purpose, I need money.

    My experience as a director and as a production manager on award-winning short films, documentaries and commercials, has taught me that to truly realise a creative vision for the unique medium of film, money is just as critical as passion and talent of the creative team. Hence, with this campaign, it's go big or go home.

    Debutante's budget is €18,500, with the additional €1,500 to account for Indiegogo platform fees, bank transfer fees and currency conversion adjustments for donations from outside Ireland. The budget amount covers:

    1) FIVE SHOOTING DAYS

    • camera & lighting equipment rental
    • modest but reasonable pay rates for cast & crew
    • costume & set design
    • catering
    • location fees
    • insurance

     

    2) POST-PRODUCTION

    • edit
    • sound mix 
    • colour grade
    • original music score
    • cost of clearing original composition rights to a certain very well-known piece of music, which plays a key part in the story (think more 1960s musicals, less Ed Sheeran ;)

     

    3) FILM FESTIVAL ENTRY FEES

     

    We will shoot the film in January 2020, in time for summer start of the film's festival journey. 

    As with my previous films which reached wide audiences globally, my plan for Debutante is to reach as many film festivals as possible, as well as to have it broadcast on RTÉ and other TV networks globally, US cable network ShortsHD, and available for viewing on board of Aer Lingus transatlantic flights. To start with. ;)

    In exchange for your much valued contributions, both big and small, we offer a wide range of perks, from digital downloads of the film, through blooper reels, signed copies of the script, set visits, associate and executive producer credits, premiere invitations and more! 

    To contribute through Indiegogo  you will need a credit card. If you don't have a credit card or Apple Pay set up, you can still donate through PayPal using this link. Please mention in the note which perk you'd like.

    Please note for any perks associated with physical presence in Dublin (set visits, film premiere etc.) no travel & accommodation costs are covered. Thanks for your understanding!

     

    Film Crew Background

    In early 2015, when I was shooting my first film, Testimony, I didn't really have much of a clue what I was doing. I made it happen through obsessive perseverance. 

    Testimony screened in festivals globally and was nominated for multiple awards, including:

    • IMDb's New Filmmaker Award @ Bath Film Festival, UK
    • Best Director @ the BAFTA-qualifying Underwire Film Festival London
    • Best Screenplay & Rising Star Award @ Underground Cinema Awards, Dublin

    My second short film, The Betrayal, featuring music by Nick Cave & Warren Ellis, premiered at the prestigious GAZE International LGBT Film Festival in Dublin, and screened at festivals in Ireland and Canada.

    Both films were broadcast on Irish national TV (RTÉ) and The Irish Times recently included The Betrayal on the list of the week's best TV shows.

     

     

    I'm also lucky - and grateful - to be surrounded by a wonderfully talented team on this project, including:

    • Barry Doyle, Director of Photography. Barry shot sci-fi pilot Rising, critically-acclaimed commercials for Focus Ireland (including I Can't Sleep), music videos and multiple short films. He has extensive experience in various camera departments on productions including Game of Thrones, Handsome Devil, Taken Down, Dark Lies The Island, and Sweetness in the Belly. Click on the video below for an example of Barry's intricate, beautiful cinematography.

     

     

    • Niall Owens, 1st Assistant Director, with many years of experience on short & feature drama, including multi-award-winning Michael Inside and upcoming feature Here Are The Young Men by Eoin Macken. Niall is also an IFTA-nominated producer, writer and director.

     

     

    • Gwen Jeffares, Costume Designer. Gwen collaborated with me on two of my films: on Testimony (for which she received a Best Costume Design nomination at the Underground Cinema Awards, Ireland) and on The Betrayal. She has extensive experience on short & feature films, including the award-winning shorts Gridlock and Five Letters to the Stranger Who Will Dissect My Brain. 

     

     

    • Edwina Kelly, Make Up Artist. Edwina's tremendous experience includes films like Calm With Horses (starring Barry Keoghan), Irish productions Taken Down, Black '47 and The Lodgers, to name a few. Edwina also has extensive experience on commercials (including Guinness, Electric Ireland, Coca Cola, Nissan), and TV (The Mario Rosenstock Show). 

     

       

      Risks & Challenges

      The only risk that could prevent Debutante from being made is, well, raising no money. 

      I'm 100% confident that with the team committed to this project and with my own experience, we will overcome any and all challenges, whether it's a location dropping out last minute (been there!) or being asked for 20 revisions of a Risk Assessment a day before the shoot (also been there) or even dealing with a hurricane during the shoot (no joke, been there too.)

      Our main challenge is funding - we cannot make this film happen without your support, and every little donation counts. 

      If the subject matter resonates with you or you simply think Debutante is a film you'd want to watch, check out our perks and contribute today!

         

        Other Ways You Can Help

        Don't underestimate the power of a simple share on social media or even through email or word of mouth.

        With our target amount of €20,000, we need 4000 people to contribute €5 each in order to reach that target. For 4000 people to contribute, many more people need to hear about this campaign. You can help us get there by contributing but sharing is also valuable!

        Debutante is on Facebook and Twitter - you can also use the sharing tools above. It's quick and painless ;)

        If you know of groups, institutions, organisations, or journalists that might find this project interesting, please share the link with them too!

        Thank you so much for reading!

        Kamila Dydyna

story:
Logline: 

A couple's morning is interrupted when a witch moves in next door with plans to conceive the spawn of Satan during a solar eclipse.

Synopsis:

Amy and Steve are your typical husband and wife getting ready to view a solar eclipse at their local park. However, Steve forgot to pick up the eclipse glasses that his wife reminded him to pick up a hundred times. On his way to the store to pick up the glasses, Steve is persuaded by a mysterious woman, Maria, who promises she has an extra pair of glasses back at her house. Not willing to pass up on saving a couple bucks, Steve agrees to the invitation but quickly finds himself trapped in this woman’s house. What does this woman want with Steve? Will Amy figure out what’s going on in time to save him? Will any of them get to actually watch this awe-inspiring astrological event? 

The Cast

Chris Markle is Steve

 

Actor/writer, CHRIS MARKLE, is from the small town of Millheim, Pennsylvania. His most recent acting credits include American Horror Story 1984, Bulge Bracket, The Crumbs, and Pink Opaque. His latest writing credit is a pilot episode for a dark comedy series called Fraternalings. Check him out! https://pro.imdb.com/name/nm7574457?ref_=nm_nv_...

 

Natalie Polisson is Amy

NATALIE POLISSON was born and raised in northwest Indiana. She has a BFA in musical theatre and worked full time as a theatre actress for 5 years before moving to Los Angeles to focus on film acting. In the past few years, Natalie has also delved into a bit of puppetry (both for stage and film) and continues to sing, act, and dance. Check her out! https://www.imdb.com/name/nm6003075/bio?ref_=nm...

Kristen Vaganos is Maria

KRISTEN VAGANOS is a Greek-American actress, originally from Philly. She is a graduate of NYU Tisch School of the Arts and performs on the Improv LA Mess Hall Team 'Parliament'. You may have seen her in the Lifetime original movie Mommy Would Never Hurt You, in WongFu's newest romcom series Dating After College, or at Trader Joe's buying too many boxes of chocolate covered raisins. Check her out! https://www.imdb.com/name/nm6553508/?ref_=nv_sr...

 

The Crew:

Patrick Murphy - Writer/Director

Writer and director, PATRICK MURPHY, is a Texas/Kansas native with a love for embarrassing his family with big Hollywood dreams and a frightening interest in the horror-comedy genre. He has earned himself two, count em TWO, awards as a WINNER and as a semi finalist for his previous work on the short film Mad Love.  

Patrick has also worked on the set of the smash-hit horror film, Lights Out (2016) and the short horror film The Reaper 3D (2018). In addition, Patrick was the Production Manager and Co-Producer for the indie film Stuck and has brought to life numerous commercial projects as producer, cameraman, and editor. 

Masaki Imai -  Director of Photography

Director of Photography, MASAKI IMAI, is an LA based Japanese-native cinematographer. After finishing high school, he moved to Los Angeles and quickly began working towards his dream of becoming a filmmaker. He graduated from CSU Northridge with a Bachelor of Arts in Film Production, and since then he has been working on variety  of narratives, documentaries, commercials and MV.

Kelby Knapp - Production Designer

Production Designer, KELBY KNAPP, is originally from Orange County  and has collaborated on a wide variety of projects ranging from period pieces to full blown fantasy flicks, as well as on a number of commercial projects with Orange Coast College . She has worked on multiple award winning pieces and has brought them to life with her ambitious ideas and thorough preparation. Kelby is currently studying film production at Cal State Fullerton as she continues to expand her career and takes productions to the next level with her hardworking attitude. 

Chris Newlin - Composer

Composer, CHRIS NEWLIN, is a Houston born and raised music producer and songwriter with a passion for film scoring. He graduated from the University of Texas with a degree in Music Production, and currently works at Record Plant Recording Studios out in Hollywood. Chris spends most of his days making music, surfing, and training his dog Fiona to not poop on the carpet. 

 

What We Need 

We are looking to raise $3,700. Wowza. That's a lotta quiche. Well, Alfred Hitchcock did say, "Make the audience suffer as much as possible," so we're just following in the footsteps of the master. But seriously, we are making a professional film so we are working with professionals which requires real professional type budgets. We are scheduled to shoot three days in November at a beautiful home in beautiful Burbank, CA. The majority of the budget will be going to our groovy crew to make sure this short film gets made correctly and to our magnificent cast since no one really liked my sock puppet idea.  The rest of the budget will be going to make sure our equipment actually works, making sure our insurance keeps cast and crew covered, and making sure no one starves.

Post production (the part that happens after filming, Mom) is also factored into this budget. Once the camera stops rolling, there is a surprising amount of work that still needs to be done. The movie will need to be colored to ensure it looks great, the sound will be mixed and scored so the film will sound appealing to your ears, and the short will need to be edited so you don't have to watch 10 hours of raw footage (that's our silly editors job). 

Exhibition Plan

Where do you even watch a short film like this? After the film is complete, Patrick will submit the project to various genre and short film focused film festivals (Eat it, Sundance) like Fantastic Fest, Screamfest, and Hollywood Comedy Shorts Film Festival in hopes of being chosen and winning awards (That's why we do it, right?). From there, we are hoping to gain prestige and hype for the project, get people talking about it, and then release the film online for all to see. In addition, our main objective for this project is and always will be to bring an original story with new and interesting characters to the screen, but we are also hoping this short will become a "proof of concept" for a feature length film and potentially inspire someone with lots of money to let us make this into a real-life movie that anyone can see in a real-life movie theater. How neat would that be? 

Other Ways You Can Help

Money is expensive! We totally get it. If you are unable to contribute, please feel free to share this page with your friends, family, exes, rich relatives, investment bankers, or on any and all social media feeds! 

We really think this is a original and cool story that begs to be told so spread the word! 

Follow us on our Instagram @theoccultson for updates, behind the scene photos, and more cool stuff that will keep you entertained will we make this movie!
story_txt:
Logline: 
A couple's morning is interrupted when a witch moves in next door with plans to conceive the spawn of Satan during a solar eclipse.

Synopsis:
Amy and Steve are your typical husband and wife getting ready to view a solar eclipse at their local park. However, Steve forgot to pick up the eclipse glasses that his wife reminded him to pick up a hundred times. On his way to the store to pick up the glasses, Steve is persuaded by a mysterious woman, Maria, who promises she has an extra pair of glasses back at her house. Not willing to pass up on saving a couple bucks, Steve agrees to the invitation but quickly finds himself trapped in this woman’s house. What does this woman want with Steve? Will Amy figure out what’s going on in time to save him? Will any of them get to actually watch this awe-inspiring astrological event? 

The Cast
Chris Markle is Steve
 

Actor/writer, CHRIS MARKLE, is from the small town of Millheim, Pennsylvania. His most recent acting credits include American Horror Story 1984, Bulge Bracket, The Crumbs, and Pink Opaque. His latest writing credit is a pilot episode for a dark comedy series called Fraternalings. Check him out! https://pro.imdb.com/name/nm7574457?ref_=nm_nv_...
 
Natalie Polisson is Amy

NATALIE POLISSON was born and raised in northwest Indiana. She has a BFA in musical theatre and worked full time as a theatre actress for 5 years before moving to Los Angeles to focus on film acting. In the past few years, Natalie has also delved into a bit of puppetry (both for stage and film) and continues to sing, act, and dance. Check her out! https://www.imdb.com/name/nm6003075/bio?ref_=nm...
Kristen Vaganos is Maria


KRISTEN VAGANOS is a Greek-American actress, originally from Philly. She is a graduate of NYU Tisch School of the Arts and performs on the Improv LA Mess Hall Team 'Parliament'. You may have seen her in the Lifetime original movie Mommy Would Never Hurt You, in WongFu's newest romcom series Dating After College, or at Trader Joe's buying too many boxes of chocolate covered raisins. Check her out! https://www.imdb.com/name/nm6553508/?ref_=nv_sr...

story:
Short Summary

Contributors fund ideas they can be passionate about and to people they trust. Here are some things to do in this section:

  • We are 128 Productions. Chris and Collin have been making short films together for five years in pursuit of a career in film making.
  • Revelation is the last installment in a series of Post Apocalyptic short films that Chris and Collin have been working on for the past two years. In 2018 we started this story and we want to be able to finish it in the best way we can.
  • With the help of all our backers we will be able to bring the story of Revelation to it's full potential.

What We Need & What You Get

Break it down for folks in more detail:

  • The main part of the campaign will go towards the gear and talent.
  • All of our gear can be found on LensRentals website. We will be renting from May 16th until May 26th which will bring our total to almost $2,000.
  • Another $1,000 will be going towards paying our talent.
  • The last $1,000 of the budget will be going towards location expenses, travel and lodging, food, wardrobe for the characters, and any other miscellaneous items we may need along the way.
  • Your donations to our film would mean everything to us! Our perks range from social media shout outs to signed memorabilia!
  • In the end, if we aren't able to reach our goal all the money will still go into supporting the project. Most of it will go towards our two main concerns, gear and talent.

Risks & Challenges

Revelation is our biggest project yet and with that comes bigger challenges than we have faced in the past. Our biggest challenges for this project would be Time Management and Action Set Pieces.

  • These are new obstacles that we haven't faced before but we believe we can take them head on with your help.
  • Time Management will greatly benefit from having two cameras on set. This will help knock out more shots throughout the day while also giving us the ability to take our time and not rush between takes.
  • Action Set pieces of this size aren't something we have done in the past so Chris and Collin will be bringing in some help with some intense hand to hand fight choreography.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute to our campaign that doesn't mean you can't help!

  • Share our campaign across all your social media platforms and let your friends and family know what we're trying to do.
  • Be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thank you all for taking the time to look and donate to our campaign.

story:
Short Summary

  • My name's Johannah Orwiler, and I'm a filmmaker in Northwest Arkansas. I'm raising money for my short film, Glass Cages. This is my first project post-graduation and it's a chance for me to make a powerful and impactful piece of art.
  • Glass Cages is a sci-fi/dystopia set in the not-too distant future. In the world of the film, the human gene pool has degenerated to a point where scientists, doctors, and the government regulate the gene pool to rectify the situation. Enter Ema Martel, a young woman whose parents have given her the best genes money can buy. One night, she shows up on her parents' doorstep with the news that she has quit college and left her boyfriend after getting pregnant. She also wants to have her baby "the old way," without the standard edits. When Ema learns the risks such a decision involves, she is faced with a terrible choice. Will she go against all she believes and play it safe, or take a risk to give her child the freedom she believes she deserves? 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Last year, I pitched this film at the Fayetteville Film Fest and won $2000 towards making this film. I'm looking to raise about $3000 more.  The funds are going towards paying and feeding my cast and crew. I've got a fantastic team assembled, and I want to be able to thank them for helping me make this film.  Everyone who contributes will get their names in the credits of the film, and will, of course, be invited to see the premiere.

The Impact

Glass Cages is a film that will leave a direct impact on audiences. It's a story about choice, about what defines right and wrong, and what defines humanity. These are important and relevant issues for today's culture. 

I've successfully completed this project before, as my senior thesis film. As it was a student film, it didn't quite live up to my vision. This time, I'm hoping to craft a quality film that I can send to festivals and share with more people. 

Risks & Challenges

I'm an experienced filmmaker, and am confident in my ability to successfully complete this film. Basically the biggest obstacle I'm facing is funding. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you unable to contribute, you can still help by sharing this page. Every bit of support is much appreciated!

story:
Short Summary:

Hi, I’m Peter Barton, an award-winning filmmaker, and 3-time cancer survivor. As I approach my 80th year, in the wake of a global pandemic, I’m turning my attention to Final Chapters. This project, Brief Candle, is essentially a meditation on death, seen through the lens of a therapist who’s come to specialize in treating people with grim diagnoses.

This is going to be an intense experience, charged with joy and anguish, unfolding in the shadow of the pandemic. 

I believe I’m prepared. I’ve taught film at NYU with Marty Scorsese.   Oliver Stone was a student. My work has appeared on Showtime, HBO, WNET, and WCBS. I founded the umbrella for this production, not-for-profit Groundswell Media, with documentary legend, George Stoney, dedicated to amplifying the voices of the disadvantaged. 

My recent film, Women of ’69, Unboxed, has been shown on ninety percent of local PBS stations and received top prize at the Queens World Festival and the NYC Indie Festival, as well as a special audience award at the Woods Hole Festival. 

I am very proud to have two films in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art.

Our cameras will begin our journey by following women at Camp Mak-A-Dream in Goldcreek, Montana. This session is reserved for women with ovarian cancer, a disease that is very hard to beat. With an average mortality rate of nearly 70%, these women are facing a very shaky future. 

My guide on this extraordinary journey is Vivien Weiss, a therapist who over the years, because of her frustrating personal experience with the death of her mother, has come to specialize in accompanying women, over 50 of them to date, on their final journeys. This year, feeling the shadow of the COVID-19 epidemic over her shoulder, Vivien’s work has become increasingly relevant, both at the camp and in her private psychotherapy practice in Northampton, Mass. 

Brief Candle will dissolve our instinctive denial and get viewers thinking about their own final chapters. It should engender sobering reflection and intense empathy since, after all, every one of us will one day walk that same Valley of the Shadow…

We invite you to screen our five-minute preview of the film here: https://youtu.be/qQXBRHlZVRs 

A personal message from myself can be viewed here: https://youtu.be/bu6HJ8KdFeI

 

What We Need & What You Get:

Filming will include a 9-week production and editing schedule with 6 days on location with Weiss in Montana plus sessions with her patients in Northampton.  A comprehensive budget can be found below. Your investment will provide the funding we need to create this unforgettable documentary.  We look forward to partnering with you. In return, we offer mailed gifts, film credits, therapy scessions, and most importantly, the satisfaction of having contributed to a profound, legacy-building project. 

Our Budget: 

Film Length: 56 minutes                                       Budget Total: $95,760

 

Budget Breakdown: 

Shoot:     

Equipment: 8 Days at $1,275/day                                                   $10,200

Director/cameraman 11 days at $1350/day                                $14,850

 

Edit: 

9 weeks director/editor/room at $1850/week                             $16,650

Co-Producer/ Editor: 9 weeks at $1600/week                             $14,400

2nd Cameraperson: 8 days at $1,150/day                                     $9,200

Consultant: Vivien Weiss 6 weeks at $1,500                                 $9,000

Exec Producer/Medical Consultant                                                 $1,600

Local assistant in Montana 5 days at $400/day                          $2,000

Errors and Omissions Insurance                                                       $1,900

Production Insurance                                                                            $2,500

Transportation for Barton, Harmon, and Weiss to/from

 Montana Camp plus ground transport                                          $3,200

Sub-total                                                                                                   $85,500

Contingency  12%                                                                                  $10,260

GRAND TOTAL                                                                            $95,760    

 

The Impact:

Picture this: Five women struggle up a mountain slope in near-darkness. They seem strong, indomitable, cursing lustily. As first light breaks over Montana, we see that two of them are being carried by the other three. Their cancer treatment has taken its toll on their bodies. But it has not extinguished their fiery spirits. They hoot at the fading moon, salute the rising sun with prayers and sighs.  Their joy surges, heightened by the fact that this may be their last howl. Each of the women has ovarian cancer, which is nearly 70% fatal, and are at a week-long workshop and camp-out for women who share this bleak diagnosis.  

Our central character and guide, Vivien Weiss, is there as well, coaching, supporting, encouraging. You could say that a little extra courage is what Viv supplies most for these women - courage, and understanding. What can they teach us about our own paths, our own inevitable demise? 

Vivien is a psychotherapist who, in her long career,  has helped guide, strengthen, and enlighten dozens of women on their final journeys. Her specialty: tough, terminal cases. Viv lost her mother brutally, suddenly, to leukemia when Vivien was quite young. As she moved into treating individuals,  Vivien found herself focusing on those facing terminal illnesses, as well as their significant others/survivors, whose journeys were going to be longer but no less complicated. Viv lives in Northampton, but, because of her special expertise and experience, comes to Montana twice a year to minister to this special population. She’s done this for 16 years.

Viv tells us that the spirit and tone of the camp is FAR from morose. She does individual and group sessions there, helping the women deal with their concerns for their families as well as for their own final paths.  There is heartbreak in abundance, but also lots of love and laughter. 

One trio of friends describes the first item on their Bucket List: a visit to see Cher in Las Vegas. Not only did they see the show, but they managed to get invited backstage and received personal gifts from the performer. Others talk about their pain and heads nod. There are many suggestions about analgesics, meditation, and spirituality. They discuss legal issues, do-not-resuscitate orders, and final resting places. They look back on their lives, especially in individual therapy sessions, and, with Viv's help, find a perspective that may not be sunny, but is steady, both firm and affirming. Tears flow as they describe who they'll leave behind, especially lovers and grandchildren. The women  acknowledge the valued presence of the camera, providing a little bit of immortality even as their futures shrink before their eyes.  Many have had Covid touch their lives and they compare their own very present and concrete fears to the nation’s pervasive anxieties and wounds from the pandemic. 

Barton will give campers a few minutes alone, in their bunks or in a special tent, for video "selfies," to be used as intimate digital legacies that they can completely shape and control, in contrast to the rest of their lives. Barton will also keep open the possible inclusion of interviews of Viv, her current patients, and survivors of her deceased patients in Northampton. . 

Brief Candle promises to help connect terminal patients and their families all over the world and provide psychological wellness resources to viewers who lack local support systems.  Brief Candle will allow all viewers all to feel how precious our own lives are, especially in the shadow of the Virus. We should come away feeling stronger as we face our own exits, armed with some new resources, some fresh courage, and insight, as we contemplate the writing of our own final chapters…

 

Groundswell Media: 

With documentary legend George Stoney, I set up the umbrella for this film, the not-for-profit Groundswell Media, dedicated to amplifying the voices of people who need help being heard, recognized, and respected. 

Groundswell, Inc., based in New York, was founded as a public interest not-for-profit 501(c)3 in 1978. Professor Stoney, considered the dean of American documentarians and the father of community access TV, was on the Board from the beginning and served until his death. Professor Stoney was the former chair of New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, Film, and TV. 

Our mission at Groundswell has always been to "magnify the voices of the disadvantaged using cutting-edge media." We are registered with NY State as well as with the federal government. Our Board meets at least once a year and we file annually with the IRS. 

Our recent production, "Women of '69, Unboxed is currently available on Amazon, Google Play, and iTunes.  And our last crowd-funded documentary can be viewed for free here, thanks to our over 100 generous supporters: https://youtu.be/vSPLF9BxNPQ 

 

The Brief Candle Team: 

Peter Barton (Director)

I worked on my first movie in 1966. I taught at NYU with Marty Scorsese, crewed on Woodstock. Oliver Stone was a student. My work has appeared on Showtime, HBO, WNET, and WCBS. My recent film, Women of ’69, Unboxed, has been shown on ninety percent of local PBS stations and received the top prize at the Queens World Festival and the NYC Indie Festival, as well as a special audience award at the Woods Hole Festival. I am delighted to also have two films I worked on in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art.

I always used to say to my parents that I wanted to be a helping boy.  That's the goal of my movies: to help, highlight, amplify, raise awareness. Why this topic? 

Well because I always assumed I'd live forever, I've been pretty cavalier about my final chapter.  Then it dawned on me that I'm writing it right now. I turn 80 next year. I'm a 3-time cancer survivor - prostate cancer.  I've had blood clots on my lungs, a burst appendix, high blood pressure. This year, I developed a problem with my retina that required a needle to be stuck into my eyeball. Makes a good story. People gasp.  I assure you it was just at horrible as it sounds. And I have a couple more treatments to go. But I feel great. Why worry? Because I'm curious. Because I believe in being prepared.  Somehow. Because I think people will want to know and understand this road that we're all traveling on. 

This is perhaps my most profound project, one made painfully relevant by the grim presence of COVID-19 in our lives. We need your help to bring to a wide audience. 

 

Vivien Weiss (Lead Subject) 

When I learned that my longtime friend Vivien has built a therapy practice around patients who are facing very tough odds it occurred to me that we could all learn something from her experiences and from her patients. 

It turns out that a lot of them have ovarian cancer, which is as much as 70% fatal. Over the years, Viv has lost about a hundred of them. She developed this specialty, in part, because her mother died suddenly at the hands of an opaque, uncaring medical establishment. In the spring and fall, Vivien works for a week at a special camp in Montana where women with cancer gather from all over the country. She's done this for 16 years. The filmed experiences of that week will be the heart of our movie. 

We will also feature a woman with cancer who is working with Viv in Northampton, their hometown. And we will highlight the experiences of a man, also a patient of Viv, who lost his wife recently and is being guided through his grieving by Viv. She plays a moving part in our five-minute trailer: https://youtu.be/qQXBRHlZVRs 

 

Ella Harmon (Co-Producer) 

Ella is a documentary filmmaker and an alumna of Sarah Lawrence and Oxford University.  She has worked with Groundswell on a number of projects; including Parkinson’s Third Wind, The Brew Angels, Determined to Dance, and The Suicide Auditions.  She has served as both a film and script editor on my team for about a year now and has been deeply involved with the development of Brief Candle.  Her role as a creative co-producer is to oversee production details, collaborate with me creatively, and act as a second interviewer at Camp-Mak-A-Dream.  I know that having a young woman behind one of our cameras at the camp will encourage the women to open up, confide, and share their most intense feelings. 

 

Risks & Challenges:

With any film project, investment entails some risk. Anxieties are understandable, particularly in the time of COVID-19, when everything has grown a bit more uncertain. That said, Groundswell Media is a long-established organization with a strong track record. We have produced dozens of films since our founding in 1987 and we will carefully ensure the completion and distribution of this film. We have budgeted for production and Errors and Omissions insurance to mitigate any unforeseen challenges.  

 

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you are unable to contribute financially, you can still be a part of our mission!

Help us create a buzz about this campaign on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter!  Share this Indiegogo page with your followers across platforms! 

You can also contribute by ‘phoning a friend,’ or sending this campaign link directly to someone you know who might be interested. 

We greatly appreciate you and your time!
story_txt:
Short Summary:
Hi, I’m Peter Barton, an award-winning filmmaker, and 3-time cancer survivor. As I approach my 80th year, in the wake of a global pandemic, I’m turning my attention to Final Chapters. This project, Brief Candle, is essentially a meditation on death, seen through the lens of a therapist who’s come to specialize in treating people with grim diagnoses.
This is going to be an intense experience, charged with joy and anguish, unfolding in the shadow of the pandemic. 
I believe I’m prepared. I’ve taught film at NYU with Marty Scorsese.   Oliver Stone was a student. My work has appeared on Showtime, HBO, WNET, and WCBS. I founded the umbrella for this production, not-for-profit Groundswell Media, with documentary legend, George Stoney, dedicated to amplifying the voices of the disadvantaged. 
My recent film, Women of ’69, Unboxed, has been shown on ninety percent of local PBS stations and received top prize at the Queens World Festival and the NYC Indie Festival, as well as a special audience award at the Woods Hole Festival. 
I am very proud to have two films in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art.
Our cameras will begin our journey by following women at Camp Mak-A-Dream in Goldcreek, Montana. This session is reserved for women with ovarian cancer, a disease that is very hard to beat. With an average mortality rate of nearly 70%, these women are facing a very shaky future. 
My guide on this extraordinary journey is Vivien Weiss, a therapist who over the years, because of her frustrating personal experience with the death of her mother, has come to specialize in accompanying women, over 50 of them to date, on their final journeys. This year, feeling the shadow of the COVID-19 epidemic over her shoulder, Vivien’s work has become increasingly relevant, both at the camp and in her private psychotherapy practice in Northampton, Mass. 
Brief Candle will dissolve our instinctive denial and get viewers thinking about their own final chapters. It should engender sobering reflection and intense empathy since, after all, every one of us will one day walk that same Valley of the Shadow…
We invite you to screen our five-minute preview of the film here: https://youtu.be/qQXBRHlZVRs 
A personal message from myself can be viewed here: https://youtu.be/bu6HJ8KdFeI What We Need & What You Get:
Filming will include a 9-week production and editing schedule with 6 days on location with Weiss in Montana plus sessions with her patients in Northampton.  A comprehensive budget can be found below. Your investment will provide the funding we need to create this unforgettable documentary.  We look forward to partnering with you. In return, we offer mailed gifts, film credits, therapy scessions, and most importantly, the satisfaction of having contributed to a profound, legacy-building project. 
Our Budget: 
Film Length: 56 minutes                                       Budget Total: $95,760 Budget Breakdown: 
Shoot:     
Equipment: 8 Days at $1,275/day                                                   $10,200
Director/cameraman 11 days at $1350/day                                $14,850 Edit: 
9 weeks director/editor/room at $1850/week                             $16,650
Co-Producer/ Editor: 9 weeks at $1600/week                             $14,400
2nd Cameraperson: 8 days at $1,150/day                                     $9,200
Consultant: Vivien Weiss 6 weeks at $1,500                                 $9,000
Exec Producer/Medical Consultant                                                 $1,600
Local assistant in Montana 5 days at $400/day                          $2,000
Errors and Omissions Insurance                                                       $1,900
Production Insurance                                                                            $2,500
Transportation for Barton, Harmon, and Weiss to/from
 Montana Camp plus ground transport                                          $3,200
Sub-total                                                                                                   $85,500
Contingency  12%                                                                                  $10,260
GRAND TOTAL                                                                            $95,760     The Impact:
Picture this: Five women struggle up a mountain slope in near-darkness. They seem strong, indomitable, cursing lustily. As first light breaks over Montana, we see that two of them are being carried by the other three. Their cancer treatment has taken its toll on their bodies. But it has not extinguished their fiery spirits. They hoot at the fading moon, salute the rising sun with prayers and sighs.  Their joy surges, heightened by the fact that this may be their last howl. Each of the women has ovarian cancer, which is nearly 70% fatal, and are at a week-long workshop and camp-out for women who share this bleak diagnosis.  
Our central character and guide, Vivien Weiss, is there as well, coaching, supporting, encouraging. You could say that a little extra courage is what Viv supplies most for these women - courage, and understanding. What can they teach us about our own paths, our own inevitable demise? 
Vivien is a psychotherapist who, in her long career,  has helped guide, strengthen, and enlighten dozens of women on their final journeys. Her specialty: tough, terminal cases. Viv lost her mother brutally, suddenly, to leukemia when Vivien was quite young. As she moved into treating individuals,  Vivien found herself focusing on those facing terminal illnesses, as well as their significant others/survivors, whose journeys were going to be longer but no less complicated. Viv lives in Northampton, but, because of her special expertise and experience, comes to Montana twice a year to minister to this special population. She’s done this for 16 years.
Viv tells us that the spirit and tone of the camp is FAR from morose. She does individual and group sessions there, helping the women deal with their concerns for their families as well as for their own final paths.  There is heartbreak in abundance, but also lots of love and laughter. 
One trio of friends describes the first item on their Bucket List: a visit to see Cher in Las Vegas. Not only did they see the show, but they managed to get invited backstage and received personal gifts from the performer. Others talk about their pain and heads nod. There are many suggestions about analgesics, meditation, and spirituality. They discuss legal issues, do-not-resuscitate orders, and final resting places. They look back on their lives, especially in individual therapy sessions, and, with Viv's help, find a perspective that may not be sunny, but is steady, both firm and affirming. Tears flow as they describe who they'll leave behind, especially lovers and grandchildren. The women  acknowledge the valued presence of the camera, providing a little bit of immortality even as their futures shrink before their eyes.  Many have had Covid touch their lives and they compare their own very present and concrete fears to the nation’s pervasive anxieties and wounds from the pandemic. 
Barton will give campers a few minutes alone, in their bunks or in a special tent, for video "selfies," to be used as intimate digital legacies that they can completely shape and control, in contrast to the rest of their lives. Barton will also keep open the possible inclusion of interviews of Viv, her current patients, and survivors of her deceased patients in Northampton. . 
Brief Candle promises to help connect terminal patients and their families all over the world and provide psychological wellness resources to viewers who lack local support systems.  Brief Candle will allow all viewers all to feel how precious our own lives are, especially in the shadow of the Virus. We should come away feeling stronger as we face our own exits, armed with some new resources, some fresh courage, and insight, as we contemplate the writing of our own final chapters… Groundswell Media: 
With documentary legend George Stoney, I set up the umbrella for this film, the not-for-profit Groundswell Media, dedicated to amplifying the voices of people who need help being heard, recognized, and respected. 
Groundswell, Inc., based in New York, was founded as a public interest not-for-profit 501(c)3 in 1978. Professor Stoney, considered the dean of American documentarians and the father of community access TV, was on the Board from the beginning and served until his death. Professor Stoney was the former chair of New York University's Tisch School of the Arts, Film, and TV. 
Our mission at Groundswell has always been to "magnify the voices of the disadvantaged using cutting-edge media." We are registered with NY State as well as with the federal government. Our Board meets at least once a year and we file annually with the IRS. 
Our recent production, "Women of '69, Unboxed is currently available on Amazon, Google Play, and iTunes.  And our last crowd-funded documentary can be viewed for free here, thanks to our over 100 generous supporters: https://youtu.be/vSPLF9BxNPQ 
 
The Brief Candle Team: 
Peter Barton (Director)
I worked on my first movie in 1966. I taught at NYU with Marty Scorsese, crewed on Woodstock. Oliver Stone was a student. My work has appeared on Showtime, HBO, WNET, and WCBS. My recent film, Women of ’69, Unboxed, has been shown on ninety percent of local PBS stations and received the top prize at the Queens World Festival and the NYC Indie Festival, as well as a special audience award at the Woods Hole Festival. I am delighted to also have two films I worked on in the permanent collection of the Museum of Modern Art.
I always used to say to my parents that I wanted to be a helping boy.  That's the goal of my movies: to help, highlight, amplify, raise awareness. Why this topic? 
Well because I always assumed I'd live forever, I've been pretty cavalier about my final chapter.  Then it dawned on me that I'm writing it right now. I turn 80 next year. I'm a 3-time cancer survivor - prostate cancer.  I've had blood clots on my lungs, a burst appendix, high blood pressure. This year, I developed a problem with my retina that required a needle to be stuck into my eyeball. Makes a good story. People gasp.  I assure you it was just at horrible as it sounds. And I have a couple more treatments to go. But I feel great. Why worry? Because I'm curious. Because I believe in being prepared.  Somehow. Because I think people will want to know and understand this road that we're all traveling on. 
This is perhaps my most profound project, one made painfully relevant by the grim presence of COVID-19 in our lives. We need your help to bring to a wide audience.  Vivien Weiss (Lead Subject) 
When I learned that my longtime friend Vivien has built a therapy practice around patients who are facing very tough odds it occurred to me that we could all learn something from her experiences and from her patients. 
It turns out that a lot of them have ovarian cancer, which is as much as 70% fatal. Over the years, Viv has lost about a hundred of them. She developed this specialty, in part, because her mother died suddenly at the hands of an opaque, uncaring medical establishment. In the spring and fall, Vivien works for a week at a special camp in Montana where women with cancer gather from all over the country. She's done this for 16 years. The filmed experiences of that week will be the heart of our movie. 
We will also feature a woman with cancer who is working with Viv in Northampton, their hometown. And we will highlight the experiences of a man, also a patient of Viv, who lost his wife recently and is being guided through his grieving by Viv. She plays a moving part in our five-minute trailer: https://youtu.be/qQXBRHlZVRs  Ella Harmon (Co-Producer) 
Ella is a documentary filmmaker and an alumna of Sarah Lawrence and Oxford University.  She has worked with Groundswell on a number of projects; including Parkinson’s Third Wind, The Brew Angels, Determined to Dance, and The Suicide Auditions.  She has served as both a film and script editor on my team for about a year now and has been deeply involved with the development of Brief Candle.  Her role as a creative co-producer is to oversee production details, collaborate with me creatively, and act as a second interviewer at Camp-Mak-A-Dream.  I know that having a young woman behind one of our cameras at the camp will encourage the women to open up, confide, and share their most intense feelings.  Risks & Challenges:
With any film project, investment entails some risk. Anxieties are understandable, particularly in the time of COVID-19, when everything has grown a bit more uncertain. That said, Groundswell Media is a long-established organization with a strong track record. We have produced dozens of films since our founding in 1987 and we will carefully ensure the completion and distribution of this film. We have budgeted for production and Errors and Omissions insurance to mitigate any unforeseen challenges.  
 
Other Ways You Can Help:
If you are unable to contribute financially, you can still be a part of our mission!
Help us create a buzz about this campaign on Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter!  Share this Indiegogo page with your followers across platforms! 
You can also contribute by ‘phoning a friend,’ or sending this campaign link directly to someone you know who might be interested. 
We greatly appreciate you and your time!

story:
We are a group of dedicated & hardworking student filmmakers from SCAD, Atlanta and are working on Jahi Trotter's Thesis Film, The Last Job. 

The Last Job is a dramatic action comedy film. This film will also serve as a proof of concept for a feature film. But the story we are focusing on will be about a young man, Isiah, and his crew who break into real estate tycoon, Simon Silver’s, office to steal the last bit of information they need to expose him for his crooked ways.

The story is about family and redemption. It's about the bond shared by a father and a son and the need to do the right the thing. 

 

 

 

 

Production

  • Locations - We need to pay location fees to be able to film on the perfect locations.
  • Hair & Makeup - Our actors need wardrobe as well as hair and make.
  • Set Decorations - Props and set decoration are the details that drive home our vision.
  • Food - Keeping a happy cast and crew requires food...a lot of food.
  • Insurance - Covering our butts is essential to a successful shoot.
  • Transport - We need to be able to transport our cast and crew to and from set



Post Production

  • Sound - Great sound brings a film to life.
  • Original Music - Sometimes that perfect song just makes the film.
  • Festival Submissions - What's the point in making a film if you can't get it out to the world?
  • Editing, Colour - The film is made on set but completed in the edit!
  • Our incredible team includes top notch editor & colourist. 



 

 

 

Our biggest risk is the stunts we have - but not to worry, we have a kickass stunt coordinator helping us choreograph and safely film all the action sequences in this film. 

The key action sequence is the brawl between Isiah and Clark, the bodyguard, which takes place in Simon Silver's Office. To pull this off to the highest level of competency, we will be ensuring all necessary safety precautions are taken, we conduct sufficient rehearsals to get the action right and have our stunt coordinator supervise the sequences while we film it. 

 

 

If you can't pledge towards our film by:

  • Sharing the campaign on your social media platforms
  • Share the campaign with friends and family who would be interested and able to pledge
  • Follow our social media handles - @thelastjobfilm on Instagram & 'The Last Job' on Facebook.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
"A woman courageously faces every battle that comes her way with an unwavering faith that touches the lives of everyone she knows."

A small-town farm in Thompson Falls, Montana. 13-year-old Tina is diagnosed with Stage 4 Hodgkin’s Lymphoma with less than two months to live. The news does nothing to dull her bright outlook on life and only strengthens her resolve to live. However, her adopted parents Marge & Lonnie grow bitter at the growing attention on Tina’s health and the stranglehold of bills hanging over her and her husband’s finances. Tina finds solace from the unrelenting abuse in her fairytales and her unwavering faith that things will get better.

Now in remission, Tina meets her high school sweetheart Craig, but what should be a new beginning for Tina spirals out of control with the worsening threats from her increasingly abusive parents. As Tina’s relationship with Craig continues to blossom, so does her willpower to fight back against her parents, causing her to navigate a tricky balance of rebellion and keeping her love with Craig safe before she graduates high school, escapes her parents and marries Craig.

Tina, now 44, is living the life of her dreams with a flourishing career and loving husband. But she is thrust into battle and her faith tested yet again when diagnosed with Stage 4 Breast Cancer. Drawing on childhood experience and the support of family and friends, Tina embarks on a final journey of courage, hope, and faith with a strength that touches everyone around her.

Sunshine Girl is inspired by the life of Tina MacLachlan and written by her husband Craig MacLachlan. Tina met Craig in high school not long after entering remission from Stage 4 Hodgkin's Lymphoma. Their relationship continued to flourish throughout high school despite having to keep the true nature of their love and commitment to one another downplayed and hidden from Tina’s adoptive parents.

The pair married at age 21 where they spent the next twenty-three years living together, laughing together and overcoming every battle together. Tina became an addictions counselor at STARS (Spokane Treatment & Recovery Services) and moved her way up within the company to become the Clinical Supervisor and Department Head of Karen’s House where she compassionately helped treat women with co-occurring disorders. When Tina was diagnosed with Stage 4 Breast Cancer at age 44, she never lost faith, even when it threatened to steal her away from work. Her colleagues donated their vacation and sick time so that Tina could make all her chemotherapy appointments and treatments and take needed time off from her job even when she didn’t want to.

Below is a clip from Tina's interview with KHQ News. 

1 in 2 people get cancer in their life. Tina was diagnosed with Hodgkin's Lymphoma at 13 and then Breast Cancer at 44. We are committed to not only raising awareness of cancer research but also those living with this disease and their close family and friends. Cancer treatment and therapy can put a huge financial strain on families which on top of the emotional pressure is simply too much to handle without external support. That is why 50% of any profits made from Sunshine Girl will be donated and split between three cancer charities.

In reality, Tina was not adopted and lived happily with her parents Frances and Donald. As an adult, Tina focused on her work as a mental health counselor and discovered before she passed a relationship between abused children with life-threatening illnesses and their parents who exhibited mental health and/or drug and alcoholism. Craig decided to intertwine this passion and ambition of Tina’s to help those who suffered into our film. We are using Tina’s story as a vehicle to raise awareness of child abuse by having her birth parents pass away as a baby and being adopted by Marge and Lonnie. It's really important that we depict this realistically, whilst also sensitively, to show that abuse rarely starts physically. We want people to be able to pick up on the signs before it develops into something far more dangerous.

At its heart, Sunshine Girl is a Christian film. Tina's faith was tested multiple times throughout her life but never once did she lose hope. Her love and devotion to Christ is what kept the smile on her face throughout every battle she faced. Tina touched everyone she met with her compassion and kindness. Her heart was the size of the ocean and she had time for everyone. As a young girl, Tina found solace in nature when she was left isolated on the farm. She would read her fairytales to the farm animals in the barn and confided in them like best friends.

Our budget for Sunshine Girl is $50,000.  We are fundraising for 30% or more of that goal which is $15,000. The remaining 70% we are sourcing through personal investment and private sponsorship from some extremely kind and generous individuals and small businesses. 

$50,000 seems like a LOT of money, we know, it really it is! But the average independent feature's budget is just under one million. We're really cutting costs wherever we can and are so fortunate to have such a generous team on board, donating their talent and hard work. We're hoping that by donating some of your hard-earned money, sharing our campaign on your social media, talking to family and friends and colleagues, that you truly feel you are apart of creating and bringing this film to fruition. Because you are. None of this would be possible without you and we truly thank you from the bottom of our hearts. 

Filmmaking is not a cheap process! There are so many elements to consider when budgeting a feature film. The crew costs, kit hire, expenses (travel, catering and lodging) and of course the locations, props and costume.

So much of Tina's story revolves around her battles with cancer and it is important that we depict this truthfully on all levels. This involves hiring hair & make-up artists experienced with bald cap work and hospital locations that fit the demands of cancer treatment. We also set ourselves the additional challenge of following Tina's life from childhood. This means that 2/3rds of our film is set in the 1980-90s so we are going about arranging for props & costume that fit in with this time period. 

CREW:

CAST:

We need you to come and be a part of our Sunshine Girl film family. Help us tell this important story. We can't do this without you. Tina's story can't be told without you. We have several exciting perks that we hope will grab your attention, but please don't hesitate to drop us a line if there is a perk you would like to see. The magnitude of what you can help all of us achieve is indescribable. What we can create together can truly be a gamechanger. Come and be a part of this!

If you really can't donate, which we completely understand after the year we've all had, there are so many other ways for you to be a part of this. 

1. Donate your time: If you are a local and have a few days to spare in September/October then we would be so grateful if you could come on board as a runner to help us out (no experience required!). 

2. Share on Social Media: Please share our campaign (www.igg,me/at/sunshinegirl) all over social media with friends and family. We would be so extremely grateful if you could help us spread the word!

Thank you so much for your time - we can't wait to welcome you on board. Please don't hesitate to ask any questions that you may have!

This involves hiring hair & make-up artists experienced with bald cap work and hospital locations that fit the demands of cancer treatment. We also set ourselves the additional challenge of following Tina's life from childhood. This means that 2/3rds of our film is set in the 1980-90s so we are going about arranging for props & costume that fit in with this time period. CREW:

CAST:We need you to come and be a part of our Sunshine Girl film family. Help us tell this important story. We can't do this without you. Tina's story can't be told without you. We have several exciting perks that we hope will grab your attention, but please don't hesitate to drop us a line if there is a perk you would like to see. The magnitude of what you can help all of us achieve is indescribable. What we can create together can truly be a gamechanger. Come and be a part of this!If you really can't donate, which we completely understand after the year we've all had, there are so many other ways for you to be a part of this. 1. Donate your time: If you are a local and have a few days to spare in September/October then we would be so grateful if you could come on board as a runner to help us out (no experience required!). 2. Share on Social Media: Please share our campaign (www.igg,me/at/sunshinegirl) all over social media with friends and family. We would be so extremely grateful if you could help us spread the word!Thank you so much for your time - we can't wait to welcome you on board. Please don't hesitate to ask any questions that you may have!

story:
Yermo's Story 

When discussing Watsonville murals and muralists one name is widely referenced amongst many, and that name is Guillermo Aranda or Yermo. Yermo creates his murals through an inclusive community process that involves mentoring young children and adults who want to learn and assist with painting. Those who attend not only learn about the skills and techniques behind large-scale murals, but they also learn about the rich culture and history that inspired each character and symbol that lives within the mural. Yermo’s murals act as a mirror and a vibrant visual archive of the surrounding area, reminding us where we are and where we've been. 

This past year Yermo was awarded Artist of the Year by the Santa Cruz County Arts Commission. Unfortunately, due to the pandemic, the commission was unable to host a celebration in honor of Yermo's artistry, mentorship, and impact. And just recently his mural at Watsonville High School was removed. He is now in the process of repainting the original mural, and will be inviting the group of painters who participated nearly 20 years ago. 

We want to bring Yermo's story to you through a short documentary film that will showcase his hard work and dedication to the arts, his community, and his cultura. We will be working with Calavera Media to create this project.

 

Project Budget

We need your support raising funding to help us create a short documentary film about Yermo's story. Your contributions will go towards the following:

Pre-Production [$630.00]

This is where we will be developing the road map to the film! The team will interview Yermo and Paul to start structuring the story. We want to make sure that we are creating an interesting, impactful, and visually appealing film. After, our team will develop a pitch deck that will give a visual example as to what the film will appear as. Once the pitch deck is ready, the Producer will be setting up interviews, and securing times to film during production. 

Production [$2420.00]

This is where the magic happens! The crew will come onto location over a span of 32 hours to start capturing interviews and footage for the film.

Post-Production [$2225.00]

Our post-production team kicks in to shape the story, handle color-correction, record any voice overs, clean up the audio, add music, and create graphics for the film. 

Distribution [$390.00]

Once the film is complete we will be submitting it to several film festivals. We want to share Yermo's story with as many people across the U.S. as possible. 

 

Additional funds raised will go towards compensating Yermo, promoting the short film, submitting the short film into film festivals, creating merchandise, and any additional costs that may arise.

story:
Short Summary

Hi everyone! I am an award-winning filmmaker with a passion to tell black stories outside of stereotypical narratives.  Our campaign, Blue Night, tells the story of Ebony, a conflicted girl who must confront the police officer that murdered her brother. As a contributor, you will help with the filming budget, marketing budget and pursuit of telling authentic black stories!

 

The Impact

As a filmmaker, my priority is to tell compelling black narratives outside of the stereotypical lens (slave/gangster/etc). Blue Night is telling an intimate perspective of black families that do not have a clear path after experiencing pain with police brutality.

Our last tv pilot, Vessel, tells the story of Benjamin, a black screenwriter attempting to pitch his black story to the white-dominant entertainment industry, and extra-terrestrials make it that much harder. Vessel was selected into 13 film festivals worldwide, won 3 and received a non-exclusive distribution deal with P.Diddy’s television network, Revolt TV. With $5,000 saved and a dedicated small crew, we were able to accomplish a lot. With your help, we would like to make an even bigger impact!

 

 

Budget

This is the part every creative filmmaker hates talking about but we are keeping it entirely transparent with all of you. Here is a projected breakdown of Production & Post-Production:

 

Rental Equipment - $2,500.00

Director - $1,000.00

Production Manager - $1,750.00

Director of Photography - $1,000.00

Gaffer - $600.00

Sound - $600.00

DIT - $500.00

Hair & MUA (makeup artist) - $500.00

P.A. - $200.00 

Craft Services - $250.00

Props - $1,350

Contingency - $500.00

Insurance - $1,000.00

Location - $2,000.00

Location Permit - $800.00
---

POST-PRODUCTION SERVICES (editing, sound mixing, etc.) - $1,500.00

Post-Production Colorist - $1,000.00

Storage - $600.00

 

TOTAL:

$ 17,650

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share with your circles and communities! 

Also you can use the Indiegogo share tools as well. 

 

Thank you for your help!

story:
Hello Everybody. This is yet another short film fundraising campaign.

Now look I know how it is. Normally when money exchanges hands a product or service does as well. Short film fundraisers are... different. Yes I am making a product, a short film, but having been the contributor to many campaigns, I know that you're probably not particularly interested in  seeing the content I am creating. You have billion dollar companies creating content curated for you that you still have yet to catch up on, so why would my short film rank as more important?

The truth of the matter is that I have the utmost faith in the film I am creating and believe it will be something special. However, I understand that for you the real incentive to donate is as a means of showing interest or kindness to me and the other folk working very hard to make it.

This is why I've decided to structure the campaign a little differently than my contemporaries. The incentives will range in nature. Some will be serious regular perks, others will be gag humor, while still more will simply make me suffer for your enjoyment. I want the creation process of this film to be fun for everyone, including those that contribute monetarily to its creation!

So take a look below! See what incentives might interest you and feel free to reach out on any of our social media! We'll be creating content up to the release that will detail the production process and be funny in its own right.

 

STRETCH GOAL:

$10,000 – I will find a way to make this film regardless of what is raised, but if we raise this amount I'll have enough to make the film comfortably. To celebrate I’ll dye my hair any color that y’all vote for. I’ll setup a twitter poll and everyone who has donated will get the chance to vote on a color for how my hair gets dyed.
