story:
Enongo is a forthcoming feature-length documentary and the inspiring story of rapper/producer/Ph.D. candidate Enongo Lumumba-Kasongo, a.k.a. Sammus.  Through her compelling and honest music, Enongo/Sammus tackles various subjects including (but certainly not limited to) race, feminism, video games, the music industry, mental health, growing up, and relationships.  Inspired by the feminist bounty hunter protagonist of Nintendo's Metroid video game series, Enongo adopted the stage persona "Sammus" to tell her story and experiences through her music.

 

Enongo is many things.  She is relatable, complicated, funny, passionate, and unique.  She is an artist, a musician, a producer of her own beats, a master lyricist, a Black woman, a first-generation American of West African descent, an introvert, a gamer, a self-described "weirdo," a teacher, and a friend. 

 

Chronicling everything from Sammus touring across North America to creating her latest album to her origins and upbringing, this documentary aims to share the emotional, inspiring journey of a polymath and genuine artist... but this will only be possible with your help!

 

 

 

Filming is nearing completion, and editing is well underway.  We have all of the funds we need for final sound mix, color correction, and our original musical score.  Almost everything we need is there.  BUT, during the process of editing the film, we noticed that there was something extremely vital missing.  Enongo herself is a fantastic orator and storyteller, but many essential anecdotes and experiences in her life were absent from our narrative on a cinematic level.  We had little visual record of her past in the way we needed, and no way of visually showing what is going on inside her mind.  Thus, we realized how to bring those separate but crucial chapters of her journey to life: through animation.


While the film mostly follows our protagonist with contemporary footage of her performing across North America, in the intimacy of her home, and behind-the-scenes access of the artist creating her next album, we are also producing over ten minutes of original, frame-by-frame, hand-drawn animation — conceived, designed, storyboarded, and brought to life by a team of eight young, Black women animators across the country — which will help tell Enongo's story.  These animation sequences will shed light on Enongo's complicated upbringing as a child of West-African immigrants living in mostly-white Upstate New York, her battles with mental health, how the feminist icon of video game heroine Samus Aran inspired her, and other key aspects of her narrative.  The animation not only fills in the narrative gaps, but expands the experience of the viewer, making a more engaging, creatively-satisfying, and moving work of cinematic storytelling.

 

The animation style will embrace the tradition of hand-drawn "pencil tests,” showing the artistry of the animators’ craft and personal visions behind the drawings in each frame.  Each sequence will have a unique aesthetic to it, as well, with each animation artist cast to scenes that will exemplify her vision and creative strengths.  This will also be the very first feature-length film of any genre in which all of the animators are Black women. All of our storyboards are timed as animatics, and rough animation is already underway.  Now, we just need to bring all of these drawings to life.

 

Making a feature-length documentary is a lot of work and very expensive.  Making a very good, polished feature-length documentary shown around the world with lots of original, hand-drawn animation is even more work and is even more expensive.

 

This is where you come in.

 

By reaching our minimum goal of at least $20,000 (and hopefully surpassing it!), we will use those funds to finish roughing out, drawing, and clean-up on our amazing animation sequences.  If we can surpass that goal, we hope to use additional funds on any essential animation backgrounds, shading, and other elements.  

Enongo's story is relatable, universal, and deeply moving.  How this story is told, and by whom, is what makes this movie really special...

 

 

 

Each team member on the film is assigned to a position based on their strengths and connection to the material.  Like an actor cast to a specific role or like the animation masters of the old hand-drawn days working at Disney or Warner Bros., the animators on our film, in particular, are creating, designing, and animating their own sequences based on anecdotes from our protagonist's life that they most personally connect with and based on their aesthetic sensibilities and skill sets.  Their unique sequences tied together in our documentary function as an anthology of animated sequences, each with their own unique styles and subject matters, telling one big story.  Their contributions tell the story in a way that only animation can.  Here are just a few of the many people helping to make Enongo into a reality...

 

Photo Credit: José Ginarte

Enongo Lumumba-Kasongo

Enongo Lumumba-Kasongo (a.k.a., SAMMUS) is an Ithaca-raised, Philadelphia-based rap artist, producer, and Ph.D. student in the Department of Science & Technology Studies at Cornell University.  Known as much for her rousing stage presence as she is for her prowess as a beatmaker and lyricist, Enongo has spent the past several years cultivating a strong following of activists, hip hop heads, punks, and self-identified nerds and geeks, among others. As noted by the Los Angeles Times, Enongo “has a gift for getting a message across.” Having recently made her Don Giovanni debut (while remaining tied to NuBlack Music Group), she is poised to cement herself as an artist who consistently thinks outside boxes and dances across lines (and does other neat things with geometrical figures).

In addition to managing a full-time music career, Enongo has spent the past eight years as a public-school and college level educator. After graduating from Cornell University in 2008 with a double BA in Sociology and Science & Technology Studies, she was accepted into the national teaching program Teach for America and placed in Houston, Texas, where she taught elementary math and science between 2008 to 2010. In the fall semester of 2011, she returned to Cornell as a Ph.D. candidate to pursue an interest a wide array of sound studies topics, including sound and gaming as well as the identity politics of community studios.  As an academic and very-vocal feminist, Enongo has produced articles for publications such as Bitch, For Harriet, Sounding Out!, and The Mary Sue related to issues of race, hip-hop, gaming, and feminism.

Enongo has given us a tremendous gift in allowing us to document her journey as our passion project.  We cannot thank her enough for her generosity, trust, and kindness.

For more information on Enongo/Sammus, check out her official website: www.sammusmusic.com

 

 

Dan Haskett — Senior Character Designer & Animation Mentor

Dan Haskett is a veteran animator, director, and character designer who has been in the industry for over 50 years, and is a pioneering African-American artist in the field.  He is best known as the designer of two of Disney’s classic female leads, Ariel from The Little Mermaid (1989) and Belle from Beauty and the Beast (1991).  Dan is also responsible for designing key characters from The Simpsons (including Moe the bartender, Barney the drunk, and Bart's teacher, Mrs. Krabappel) and various characters in Toy Story (1995).  Dan’s first job in animation was at the age of 17, and was hired as an assistant animator on master animator Richard Williams’ New York-based production, Raggedy Ann & Andy: A Musical Adventure (1977) at just 23 years old.  He has since worked for virtually every major animation company across. North America, including (but not limited to) Disney, Pixar, Warner Bros., DreamWorks Animation, and Hanna-Barbera. He has also directed original animated shorts for Sesame Street.

 

Initial character design sketches for Enongo by Dan Haskett, December 2018.  He still works exclusively on pencil and animation paper to this day.

Dan’s five decades of knowledge and experience have laid a creative foundation for our young animation team by providing the initial character designs of our protagonist.  You can see Dan’s designs of her above and on our Instagram, @EnongoMovie: https://www.instagram.com/p/Br3glgFlDxM/

 

 

Christa Carr — Animation Artist & Animator

Christa is a Los Angeles-based animator, character designer, and color stylist.  She graduated from the renowned Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, New York, with highest honors, and also had the opportunity of studying abroad for a semester at the Musashino Art University in Japan, where she honed her skills in design and personality-based animation.  A gamer herself, Christa is designing, storyboarding, and animating a scene about how primitive video games and their music inspired Enongo at a young age. 

"A major goal in my career as an artist is to provide representation for Black women and show the multiplicity of our stories. Enongo has such a unique voice in hip hop music and I'm really looking forward to visualizing her journey."
– Christa Carr

More at www.christa-carr.com

 

 

Leah Coleman — Animation Artist & Animator

Leah is currently seeking her Master’s in Animation at Ohio State University.  Previously, she attended Miami University and studied at Griffith University in Brisbane, Australia.  Inspired by her appreciation for both classic Western and Asian traditional animation masters, Leah has a refined talent for fluid, feature-quality character animation.   Leah’s sequence explores Enongo’s anxieties over her relationships, career, and academic obligations, which parallels Leah's own life. 

“It is truly an exciting opportunity to not only work on this documentary about a black woman and her journey through life, but also working with other Black women animators. I always talked about not having a chance to meet or find many women like me in a field dominated by the majority. Enongo will be an emotional journey for all of us, I think, because we are all going through that struggle of life, trying to figure out who we are, what our purpose is, and Enongo shows that in both her personal life and music. To have the opportunity to express her life through animation, is something I will do my best to reflect as best to her character as I possibly can!”
– Leah Coleman

More at www.leahcoleman15.com

 

Jessica Honore — Animator

Located in Queens, New York, Jessica graduated from the prestigious School of Visual Arts in 2011.  Since then, she has worked with animation studios such as Cartuna and Titmouse, bringing to life such shows as China, IL, Superjail!, and Ballmastrz 9009 for [adult swim], and DreamWorks Animation's Home: Adventures with Tip & Oh on Netflix.  Jessica (a big fan of video games) is animating a sequence of young Enongo imagining the dark and thrilling video game world of Super Metroid.  

"As soon as I heard of Enongo, I was intrigued. It's not every day you hear of someone with so many talents and skills. I'm excited to be a part of the team that helps bring her story to life for the masses!"
– Jessica Honore

You can see Jessica's superb character animation reel here: https://vimeo.com/259947808

 

 

Brooklyn Lee — Animation Artist & Animator

Brooklyn is a Baltimore-based animator with a tremendous talent in charismatic character design and illustration.  After working on numerous commercial assignments, Enongo will be her well-deserved feature-length debut.  Brooklyn is designing, storyboarding, and animating a sequence about Enongo’s childhood, and how she felt like an outsider in Upstate New York as a daughter of West African immigrants.

“Working on a film about a fellow Black female artist fills me with so much joy. Enongo’s music is so inspiring and I can’t wait to share her story through my art.”
– Brooklyn Lee

More at www.bmoranlee.art

 

 

Shammah McVay — Associate Producer / Animation Artist & Animator

Shammah is an animator and designer living in Columbus, Ohio, and has studied at the Columbus College of Art & Design.  Her work often explores themes of identity and representation in media.  Shammah’s animated sequence concerns a deadly battle with depression, an experience that mirrors her own.  In addition to being an animator and animation artist, Shammah is working on Enongo as an associate producer, aiding in outreach and fundraising.  

“Once I heard [Sammus' song] 'Mighty Morphing' for the first time, it resonated on a spiritual level; it was me described so eloquently.  Enongo is unapologetically Black, yet not afraid to be vulnerable.  Her story is inspiring and I'm honored to work on this project. This film is needed.”
– Shammah McVay

More at https://www.instagram.com/shashestar/

 

Ruby Myles — Animator

Ruby is a Columbus, Ohio-based illustrator, animator and visual development artist who studied at the Columbus College of Art and Design.  With a strong film and theatre background, she has been allowed the opportunity to work on a wide variety of projects and hone her skills.  Ruby will be animating with Shammah McVay on one of the film's most challenging and important sequences. 

"Growing up as a singer myself, it was so incredibly easy to connect with Enongo.  To have that initial connection, as well as feel and understand the story of a woman who looks like myself, and thousands of other Black girls in the world, was enough to feel I HAD to take part in whatever way I could. I am so excited and honored to be a part of such a history-making project!"
– Ruby Myles

More at www.rubymyles.com & https://www.instagram.com/ruemarieart/

 

 

Ariel Paxton — Animation Artist & Animator

After completing her Bachelor of Fine Arts at the Art Institute of Atlanta, Ariel is now in her final quarter of achieving her Master's Degree of Fine Arts in Animation at the acclaimed Savannah College of Art & Design.  Ariel is a prolific and talented 2D animator and storyboard artist with a remarkable visual flair for design.  Ariel is animating a sequence about how becoming a teacher for underserved students eventually led Enongo to discover the power of music.  Ariel herself has been an art teacher to young children, and is applying this experience to her sequence. 

"I wanted to be a part of this project because I love the style and feel of the documentary. Since I'm a 2D animator, I wanted to provide great visuals to go with this great film."
– Ariel Paxton

More at https://www.arielpaxton.com/

 

 

Anaiyah Tatiana — Animation Artist & Animator

Born and raised in The Bronx, Anaiyah is an emerging character animator with an astonishing skill at personality-driven, fluid animation. She has worked on animated TV shows including Livespots and Astronots and Monologue. She was also the lead animator on the documentary-animation hybrid short, Ballet After Dark, which had its world premiere at the 2019 Tribeca Film Festival and was presented by Queen Latifah and Dee Rees. Anaiyah is working on a sequence about the relationship between Enongo Lumumba-Kasongo and her fiancé, author Lanre Akinsiku.

"I’m really excited about this project because I love traditional animation and for a while I was afraid the hand-drawn style would die out. It’s so exciting being part of a resurgence in appreciation for this style. I’m also looking forward to participating in this new wave of filmmaking where, not only are people of color being represented on screen, but we also have the chance to work behind the scenes, too, and help with the accuracy of that representation."

– Anaiyah Tatiana

More at https://www.instagram.com/anaiyahtatiana/

 

 

Patricia Battles — Motion Graphics Artist

Inspired by a myriad of art styles from the Disney animation renaissance of the 1990s and retro video games including Tomb Raider and Sonic the Hedgehog to graffiti art and Lisa Frank aesthetics, Patricia is a talented animator, illustrator, and motion graphics artist who has a phenomenal sense of color, design, and motion permeating all of her art.  She studied at the School of Visual Arts (SVA) in New York CIty and later transferred to The University of the Arts in Philadelphia on a Presidential Scholarship majoring in animation, and has since become a verified artist on Giphy.

"Being a part of the Enongo team feels too surreal: like being drafted into the NBA All Star League guided by 2 of the most amazing coaches on the planet (Dan Haskett & Kevin Schreck) with the MVP being Sammus! Being able to collaborate with a super talented crew of black women animators that I've gotten to know and admire feels very comforting; a sisterhood I never thought I would experience during my lifetime. With the current political climate, the BLM movement making a huge resurgence & the global pandemic affecting everyone's life in 2020, I'm extremely thankful and grateful to share with the crew and the world the very thing that has motivated me at a tender age and has been a constant source of therapy to get through hard times: creating art from the soul <3"

– Patricia Battles

More at: https://www.patriciabattles.com/

 

 

 

 

EmmoLei Sankofa — Composer

EmmoLei is an American composer, singer-songwriter, record producer, sound artist, and multi-instrumentalist based in Los Angeles, CA.  Her work stretches across music, visual media, and fine art.  EmmoLei founded Bèl Son, a creative audio collective, in which she has worked with some of the best emerging filmmakers on a wide variety of award-winning films and visual media projects for top brands.  Her discography encompasses over sixteen independently released albums, EP’s and singles collectively.  EmmoLei has honed her craft as a mentee under renowned composer Michael Abels (celebrated for his work on Jordan Peele's acclaimed films, Get Out and Us).  Enongo will be EmmoLei’s first feature-length film, and connects deeply to our protagonist's creative ambitions and struggles in the music industry.  (She is also a long-time Sammus fan.)

"What's most exciting to me about being able to work on this documentary is that I feel deeply connected to Enongo's journey. I can relate to her in quite a few ways and am honored to channel that energy musically. Additionally, this will be my first feature film, so I am thrilled to push and stretch my creative muscles alongside a host of other talented artists."
– EmmoLei Sankofa

More at www.e-sankofa.com

 

 

Kevin Schreck — Director / Producer / Editor

Originally from Minneapolis, Minnesota, Kevin Schreck is an award-winning documentary filmmaker currently living and working in Brooklyn, New York.  Kevin received both the Jerome Hill Award for Exceptional Work in the Documentary Tradition and the Award for Contribution to the Film and Electronic Arts Department of Bard College in 2011.  His first major feature-length documentary, Persistence of Vision, was about the life of master animator Richard Williams (Who Framed Roger Rabbit) and his 30-year quest to create his ultimately ill-fated magnum opus, The Thief and the Cobbler.  Persistence of Vision screened at over 70 international film festivals and other venues on five continents to virtually universal acclaim, and became the first film to win both of the top prizes at the 2013 Buffalo International Film Festival: the Audience Award for Best of Festival and the Audience Award for Best Documentary. 

"I wanted to make this film because I'm drawn to stories about creative people.  But I rarely see stories about artists like Enongo spotlighted in mainstream movies.  So, I wanted to amplify Enongo's incredible story while simultaneously giving an opportunity to artists who can tell it best, based on their unique talents and visions.  I am honored and humbled to collaborate with an extraordinary team of animators and artists who deeply connect with Enongo's journey.  We're all excited to help give Enongo's story the presentation it deserves."
– Kevin Schreck

More at www.KevinSchreck.com

 

 

 

We hope that supporting this inspiring story about an exciting, original, and relevant young artist and her fascinating personal journey will be a perk itself, but we love to reward our backers for their tremendous generosity and immense enthusiasm, too!  You'll be eligible to receive tons of exciting perks for your contributions to this Indiegogo campaign, such as:

 

The Fan Level: “Thank You!” Drawing - $10

A special digital “Thank You” drawing from one of our animators, plus first access to behind-the-scenes updates and artwork.

 

The Supporter Level: Your Name in the Film's Credits - $20

You get your name in the film's end credits, plus the following bonus rewards:


+ “Thank You” drawing from one of our animators

+ First access to behind-the-scenes updates and artwork

 

The Movie Package: See the Film - $25

You get streaming online access to the completed documentary, plus the following bonus rewards:


+ Your name in the film's end credits
+ “Thank You” drawing from one of our animators

+ First access to behind-the-scenes updates and artwork

story_txt: Enongo is a forthcoming feature-length documentary and the inspiring story of rapper/producer/Ph.D. candidate Enongo Lumumba-Kasongo, a.k.a. Sammus.  Through her compelling and honest music, Enongo/Sammus tackles various subjects including (but certainly not limited to) race, feminism, video games, the music industry, mental health, growing up, and relationships.  Inspired by the feminist bounty hunter protagonist of Nintendo's Metroid video game series, Enongo adopted the stage persona "Sammus" to tell her story and experiences through her music. Enongo is many things.  She is relatable, complicated, funny, passionate, and unique.  She is an artist, a musician, a producer of her own beats, a master lyricist, a Black woman, a first-generation American of West African descent, an introvert, a gamer, a self-described "weirdo," a teacher, and a friend.  Chronicling everything from Sammus touring across North America to creating her latest album to her origins and upbringing, this documentary aims to share the emotional, inspiring journey of a polymath and genuine artist... but this will only be possible with your help!   Filming is nearing completion, and editing is well underway.  We have all of the funds we need for final sound mix, color correction, and our original musical score.  Almost everything we need is there.  BUT, during the process of editing the film, we noticed that there was something extremely vital missing.  Enongo herself is a fantastic orator and storyteller, but many essential anecdotes and experiences in her life were absent from our narrative on a cinematic level.  We had little visual record of her past in the way we needed, and no way of visually showing what is going on inside her mind.  Thus, we realized how to bring those separate but crucial chapters of her journey to life: through animation.While the film mostly follows our protagonist with contemporary footage of her performing across North America, in the intimacy of her home, and behind-the-scenes access of the artist creating her next album, we are also producing over ten minutes of original, frame-by-frame, hand-drawn animation — conceived, designed, storyboarded, and brought to life by a team of eight young, Black women animators across the country — which will help tell Enongo's story.  These animation sequences will shed light on Enongo's complicated upbringing as a child of West-African immigrants living in mostly-white Upstate New York, her battles with mental health, how the feminist icon of video game heroine Samus Aran inspired her, and other key aspects of her narrative.  The animation not only fills in the narrative gaps, but expands the experience of the viewer, making a more engaging, creatively-satisfying, and moving work of cinematic storytelling. The animation style will embrace the tradition of hand-drawn "pencil tests,” showing the artistry of the animators’ craft and personal visions behind the drawings in each frame.  Each sequence will have a unique aesthetic to it, as well, with each animation artist cast to scenes that will exemplify her vision and creative strengths.  This will also be the very first feature-length film of any genre in which all of the animators are Black women. All of our storyboards are timed as animatics, and rough animation is already underway.  Now, we just need to bring all of these drawings to life. Making a feature-length documentary is a lot of work and very expensive.  Making a very good, polished feature-length documentary shown around the world with lots of original, hand-drawn animation is even more work and is even more expensive. This is where you come in. By reaching our minimum goal of at least $20,000 (and hopefully surpassing it!), we will use those funds to finish roughing out, drawing, and clean-up on our amazing animation sequences.  If we can surpass that goal, we hope to use additional funds on any essential animation backgrounds, shading, and other elements.  Enongo's story is relatable, universal, and deeply moving.  How this story is told, and by whom, is what makes this movie really special...   Each team member on the film is assigned to a position based on their strengths and connection to the material.  Like an actor cast to a specific role or like the animation masters of the old hand-drawn days working at Disney or Warner Bros., the animators on our film, in particular, are creating, designing, and animating their own sequences based on anecdotes from our protagonist's life that they most personally connect with and based on their aesthetic sensibilities and skill sets.  Their unique sequences tied together in our documentary function as an anthology of animated sequences, each with their own unique styles and subject matters, telling one big story.  Their contributions tell the story in a way that only animation can.  Here are just a few of the many people helping to make Enongo into a reality... Photo Credit: José GinarteEnongo Lumumba-KasongoEnongo Lumumba-Kasongo (a.k.a., SAMMUS) is an Ithaca-raised, Philadelphia-based rap artist, producer, and Ph.D. student in the Department of Science & Technology Studies at Cornell University.  Known as much for her rousing stage presence as she is for her prowess as a beatmaker and lyricist, Enongo has spent the past several years cultivating a strong following of activists, hip hop heads, punks, and self-identified nerds and geeks, among others. As noted by the Los Angeles Times, Enongo “has a gift for getting a message across.” Having recently made her Don Giovanni debut (while remaining tied to NuBlack Music Group), she is poised to cement herself as an artist who consistently thinks outside boxes and dances across lines (and does other neat things with geometrical figures).In addition to managing a full-time music career, Enongo has spent the past eight years as a public-school and college level educator. After graduating from Cornell University in 2008 with a double BA in Sociology and Science & Technology Studies, she was accepted into the national teaching program Teach for America and placed in Houston, Texas, where she taught elementary math and science between 2008 to 2010. In the fall semester of 2011, she returned to Cornell as a Ph.D. candidate to pursue an interest a wide array of sound studies topics, including sound and gaming as well as the identity politics of community studios.  As an academic and very-vocal feminist, Enongo has produced articles for publications such as Bitch, For Harriet, Sounding Out!, and The Mary Sue related to issues of race, hip-hop, gaming, and feminism.Enongo has given us a tremendous gift in allowing us to document her journey as our passion project.  We cannot thank her enough for her generosity, trust, and kindness.For more information on Enongo/Sammus, check out her official website: www.sammusmusic.com  Dan Haskett — Senior Character Designer & Animation MentorDan Haskett is a veteran animator, director, and character designer who has been in the industry for over 50 years, and is a pioneering African-American artist in the field.  He is best known as the designer of two of Disney’s classic female leads, Ariel from The Little Mermaid (1989) and Belle from Beauty and the Beast (1991).  Dan is also responsible for designing key characters from The Simpsons (including Moe the bartender, Barney the drunk, and Bart's teacher, Mrs. Krabappel) and various characters in Toy Story (1995).  Dan’s first job in animation was at the age of 17, and was hired as an assistant animator on master animator Richard Williams’ New York-based production, Raggedy Ann & Andy: A Musical Adventure (1977) at just 23 years old.  He has since worked for virtually every major animation company across. North America, including (but not limited to) Disney, Pixar, Warner Bros., DreamWorks Animation, and Hanna-Barbera. He has also directed original animated shorts for Sesame Street. Initial character design sketches for Enongo by Dan Haskett, December 2018.  He still works exclusively on pencil and animation paper to this day.Dan’s five decades of knowledge and experience have laid a creative foundation for our young animation team by providing the initial character designs of our protagonist.  You can see Dan’s designs of her above and on our Instagram, @EnongoMovie: https://www.instagram.com/p/Br3glgFlDxM/  Christa Carr — Animation Artist & AnimatorChrista is a Los Angeles-based animator, character designer, and color stylist.  She graduated from the renowned Pratt Institute in Brooklyn, New York, with highest honors, and also had the opportunity of studying abroad for a semester at the Musashino Art University in Japan, where she honed her skills in design and personality-based animation.  A gamer herself, Christa is designing, storyboarding, and animating a scene about how primitive video games and their music inspired Enongo at a young age. "A major goal in my career as an artist is to provide representation for Black women and show the multiplicity of our stories. Enongo has such a unique voice in hip hop music and I'm really looking forward to visualizing her journey."– Christa CarrMore at www.christa-carr.com  Leah Coleman — Animation Artist & AnimatorLeah is currently seeking her Master’s in Animation at Ohio State University.  Previously, she attended Miami University and studied at Griffith University in Brisbane, Australia.  Inspired by her appreciation for both classic Western and Asian traditional animation masters, Leah has a refined talent for fluid, feature-quality character animation.   Leah’s sequence explores Enongo’s anxieties over her relationships, career, and academic obligations, which parallels Leah's own life. “It is truly an exciting opportunity to not only work on this documentary about a black woman and her journey through life, but also working with other Black women animators. I always talked about not having a chance to meet or find many women like me in a field dominated by the majority. Enongo will be an emotional journey for all of us, I think, because we are all going through that struggle of life, trying to figure out who we are, what our purpose is, and Enongo shows that in both her personal life and music. To have the opportunity to express her life through animation, is something I will do my best to reflect as best to her character as I possibly can!”– Leah ColemanMore at www.leahcoleman15.com Jessica Honore — AnimatorLocated in Queens, New York, Jessica graduated from the prestigious School of Visual Arts in 2011.  Since then, she has worked with animation studios such as Cartuna and Titmouse, bringing to life such shows as China, IL, Superjail!, and Ballmastrz 9009 for [adult swim], and DreamWorks Animation's Home: Adventures with Tip & Oh on Netflix.  Jessica (a big fan of video games) is animating a sequence of young Enongo imagining the dark and thrilling video game world of Super Metroid.  "As soon as I heard of Enongo, I was intrigued. It's not every day you hear of someone with so many talents and skills. I'm excited to be a part of the team that helps bring her story to life for the masses!"– Jessica HonoreYou can see Jessica's superb character animation reel here: https://vimeo.com/259947808  Brooklyn Lee — Animation Artist & AnimatorBrooklyn is a Baltimore-based animator with a tremendous talent in charismatic character design and illustration.  After working on numerous commercial assignments, Enongo will be her well-deserved feature-length debut.  Brooklyn is designing, storyboarding, and animating a sequence about Enongo’s childhood, and how she felt like an outsider in Upstate New York as a daughter of West African immigrants.“Working on a film about a fellow Black female artist fills me with so much joy. Enongo’s music is so inspiring and I can’t wait to share her story through my art.”– Brooklyn LeeMore at www.bmoranlee.art  Shammah McVay — Associate Producer / Animation Artist & AnimatorShammah is an animator and designer living in Columbus, Ohio, and has studied at the Columbus College of Art & Design.  Her work often explores themes of identity and representation in media.  Shammah’s animated sequence concerns a deadly battle with depression, an experience that mirrors her own.  In addition to being an animator and animation artist, Shammah is working on Enongo as an associate producer, aiding in outreach and fundraising.  “Once I heard [Sammus' song] 'Mighty Morphing' for the first time, it resonated on a spiritual level; it was me described so eloquently.  Enongo is unapologetically Black, yet not afraid to be vulnerable.  Her story is inspiring and I'm honored to work on this project. This film is needed.”– Shammah McVayMore at https://www.instagram.com/shashestar/ Ruby Myles — AnimatorRuby is a Columbus, Ohio-based illustrator, animator and visual development artist who studied at the Columbus College of Art and Design.  With a strong film and theatre background, she has been allowed the opportunity to work on a wide variety of projects and hone her skills.  Ruby will be animating with Shammah McVay on one of the film's most challenging and important sequences. "Growing up as a singer myself, it was so incredibly easy to connect with Enongo.  To have that initial connection, as well as feel and understand the story of a woman who looks like myself, and thousands of other Black girls in the world, was enough to feel I HAD to take part in whatever way I could. I am so excited and honored to be a part of such a history-making project!"– Ruby MylesMore at www.rubymyles.com & https://www.instagram.com/ruemarieart/  Ariel Paxton — Animation Artist & AnimatorAfter completing her Bachelor of Fine Arts at the Art Institute of Atlanta, Ariel is now in her final quarter of achieving her Master's Degree of Fine Arts in Animation at the acclaimed Savannah College of Art & Design.  Ariel is a prolific and talented 2D animator and storyboard artist with a remarkable visual flair for design.  Ariel is animating a sequence about how becoming a teacher for underserved students eventually led Enongo to discover the power of music.  Ariel herself has been an art teacher to young children, and is applying this experience to her sequence. "I wanted to be a part of this project because I love the style and feel of the documentary. Since I'm a 2D animator, I wanted to provide great visuals to go with this great film."– Ariel PaxtonMore at https://www.arielpaxton.com/  Anaiyah Tatiana — Animation Artist & AnimatorBorn and raised in The Bronx, Anaiyah is an emerging character animator with an astonishing skill at personality-driven, fluid animation. She has worked on animated TV shows including Livespots and Astronots and Monologue. She was also the lead animator on the documentary-animation hybrid short, Ballet After Dark, which had its world premiere at the 2019 Tribeca Film Festival and was presented by Queen Latifah and Dee Rees. Anaiyah is working on a sequence about the relationship between Enongo Lumumba-Kasongo and her fiancé, author Lanre Akinsiku."I’m really excited about this project because I love traditional animation and for a while I was afraid the hand-drawn style would die out. It’s so exciting being part of a resurgence in appreciation for this style. I’m also looking forward to participating in this new wave of filmmaking where, not only are people of color being represented on screen, but we also have the chance to work behind the scenes, too, and help with the accuracy of that representation."– Anaiyah TatianaMore at https://www.instagram.com/anaiyahtatiana/  Patricia Battles — Motion Graphics ArtistInspired by a myriad of art styles from the Disney animation renaissance of the 1990s and retro video games including Tomb Raider and Sonic the Hedgehog to graffiti art and Lisa Frank aesthetics, Patricia is a talented animator, illustrator, and motion graphics artist who has a phenomenal sense of color, design, and motion permeating all of her art.  She studied at the School of Visual Arts (SVA) in New York CIty and later transferred to The University of the Arts in Philadelphia on a Presidential Scholarship majoring in animation, and has since become a verified artist on Giphy."Being a part of the Enongo team feels too surreal: like being drafted into the NBA All Star League guided by 2 of the most amazing coaches on the planet (Dan Haskett & Kevin Schreck) with the MVP being Sammus! Being able to collaborate with a super talented crew of black women animators that I've gotten to know and admire feels very comforting; a sisterhood I never thought I would experience during my lifetime. With the current political climate, the BLM movement making a huge resurgence & the global pandemic affecting everyone's life in 2020, I'm extremely thankful and grateful to share with the crew and the world the very thing that has motivated me at a tender age and has been a constant source of therapy to get through hard times: creating art from the soul <3"– Patricia BattlesMore at: https://www.patriciabattles.com/    EmmoLei Sankofa — ComposerEmmoLei is an American composer, singer-songwriter, record producer, sound artist, and multi-instrumentalist based in Los Angeles, CA.  Her work stretches across music, visual media, and fine art.  EmmoLei founded Bèl Son, a creative audio collective, in which she has worked with some of the best emerging filmmakers on a wide variety of award-winning films and visual media projects for top brands.  Her discography encompasses over sixteen independently released albums, EP’s and singles collectively.  EmmoLei has honed her craft as a mentee under renowned composer Michael Abels (celebrated for his work on Jordan Peele's acclaimed films, Get Out and Us).  Enongo will be EmmoLei’s first feature-length film, and connects deeply to our protagonist's creative ambitions and struggles in the music industry.  (She is also a long-time Sammus fan.)"What's most exciting to me about being able to work on this documentary is that I feel deeply connected to Enongo's journey. I can relate to her in quite a few ways and am honored to channel that energy musically. Additionally, this will be my first feature film, so I am thrilled to push and stretch my creative muscles alongside a host of other talented artists."– EmmoLei SankofaMore at www.e-sankofa.com  Kevin Schreck — Director / Producer / EditorOriginally from Minneapolis, Minnesota, Kevin Schreck is an award-winning documentary filmmaker currently living and working in Brooklyn, New York.  Kevin received both the Jerome Hill Award for Exceptional Work in the Documentary Tradition and the Award for Contribution to the Film and Electronic Arts Department of Bard College in 2011.  His first major feature-length documentary, Persistence of Vision, was about the life of master animator Richard Williams (Who Framed Roger Rabbit) and his 30-year quest to create his ultimately ill-fated magnum opus, The Thief and the Cobbler.  Persistence of Vision screened at over 70 international film festivals and other venues on five continents to virtually universal acclaim, and became the first film to win both of the top prizes at the 2013 Buffalo International Film Festival: the Audience Award for Best of Festival and the Audience Award for Best Documentary. "I wanted to make this film because I'm drawn to stories about creative people.  But I rarely see stories about artists like Enongo spotlighted in mainstream movies.  So, I wanted to amplify Enongo's incredible story while simultaneously giving an opportunity to artists who can tell it best, based on their unique talents and visions.  I am honored and humbled to collaborate with an extraordinary team of animators and artists who deeply connect with Enongo's journey.  We're all excited to help give Enongo's story the presentation it deserves."– Kevin SchreckMore at www.KevinSchreck.com   We hope that supporting physical prizes):+ Be the first to see all of our animation sequences completed+ FOUR (4) tickets to either the world premiere or a screening near you of our documentary, Enongo + Skype Q&A with the director and one of our animators+ A portrait of you (or a loved one) drawn by one of our animation artists+ ALL (yes, ALL) of Sammus' CDs signed by the artist herself+ The ENTIRE Sammus discography (including the newest album!)+ BOTH Sammus t-shirt designs in your size+ DVD/Blu-Ray of the completed documentary signed by director Kevin Schreck+ Sammus sprite pin+ Persistence of Vision DVD set signed by the director+ “The Art of Enongo” eBook (PDF download)+ Digital copy of the documentary's soundtrack, featuring songs by Sammus and the composer's original score+ Streaming online access to the completed documentary+ Your name in the film's end credits+ “Thank You” drawing from one of our animators+ First access to behind-the-scenes updates and artwork! All proceeds go to the making of this documentary, fees to Indiegogo (lame!), and buying all of this amazing merch from Sammus/Enongo herself.  Support independent artists and DONATE TODAY!   Every single dollar counts, but so do social media interactions!  We hope that you help spread the word and keep this project alive throughout its campaign.  In this day and age, online awareness is absolutely vital.  So whether you can donate or not, please share this project with your friends and followers!: Official Website: www.EnongoMovie.comFacebook: www.Facebook.com/EnongoMovieInstagram: www.Instagram.com/EnongoMovieTumblr: www.enongomovie.tumblr.comTwitter: www.twitter.com/EnongoMovie And use the following nifty little tools: #Enongo@EnongoMovie  Thank you for your tremendous support and wonderful enthusiasm.  With your help, we look forward to finally sharing this remarkable, inspiring story with you... – K.S.

story:
Short Summary

  • Bloodshed Brothers have been in business for 5 years.
  • Bringing the FIRST haunted house to Temecula Valley!
  • Need a little support to get everything done in less than (1) week.

 

What We Need & What You Get

Everyone who donates (volunteering during build, acting, and monetary donations) will be given a PERSONAL shout out on the viral vlog and our eternal gratitude.  

Those who donate over $100 we will happily refund your donation at the end of the season, November 5th if you would like us to please be sure to let us know.

  • DONATE $100 
    • (2) General Admission Tickets to the Hyde Street Massacre Haunted Attraction
  • DONATE $200 and You Can Pick To Receive 
    •  (2) VIP Tickets Hyde Street Massacre Haunted Attraction or (1) Bloodshed Brother T-Shirt in the size of your choice.​

  • DONATE $500 or More and You'll Receive 

    •  (4) VIP Tickets Hyde Street Massacre Haunted Attraction

    •  (4) Bloodshed Brother T-Shirt in the size of your choice.​

    •  YOUR NAME listed as a VIP Sponsor of the Hyde Street Haunted Attraction on our website and social media pages. Plus a special shout out on the vlog

 

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that some people just can't contribute financially and that's totally ok, but we'd still love your support, kind words, hugs and positive thoughts. Plus, if you could share this with your friends, family and co-workers .... that would be GREAT!

story:
Short Summary

 

Hello Drew Errington and Lance Romano here. We are two independent filmmakers from the great city of New Orleans. We hold our degrees in filmmaking from the University of New Orleans. Through the last couple years we have work to advance our skills in the lighting, camera and directing to name a few areas of filmmaking, in order to produce great works of film art. We have done ENG at New Orleans Voodoo Fest, different music videos short and feature films we have really worked hard to strengthen our skill sets. Drew Errington started I See Productions LLC two years ago, Lance has been in various cameramen positions and holds employment at Panavision.

 

When looking at writing a screenplay that could carry weight of characters, ability to shoot something with an artistic flair and to have the ability to work with talented cast and crew is what really brought about Zippo Girl. We are trying to start this campaign to raise the funds necessary in order to finish strong with this shoot. As you can see from the short teaser we have shot some of the movie, but still have a couple more weekends left to finish. We also want to get this into the film festival circuits. Zippo Girl for us is important to get out there to show a very dark compelling story and the collective talents of all working on it and hope to earn awards for its finish product.

 

With each donation you are helping us reach our goal of completion of this film. We are shooting to have it done by the first of the year so we can start putting it out there for all to view. From the smallest donation to full on reach of our goal together you are becoming part of this projects success. Your donations are helping with cost of cast and crew as well as the other needed items that we have to purchase or rent for this film. 

 

What We Need & What You Get

 

As you can see from our goal that we are trying to reach, $11,000 is what we are working towards. The cast and crew are carving out time and dedication to making this film and with your contribution it helps us secure there time to be on the shoot which in turn means dedicated and quality from those working on this film. We also have needs that have to be paid for such as food, gas, rentals of equipment and even items such as costumes, makeup etc. For those willing to invest at the higher tiers we will be more than willing to submit a full budget breakdown.

 

But giving is also receiving we have many perks to give back to you with each of your donations. We have big media shoutout and updates, movie script, posters, zippo lighters, t-shirts, movie credits, potential return on investments as an executive producer from festival winnings. We want you to feel that you are not just giving the money but also getting the feel and excitement from what this movie has to offer.

 

Now we know that this goal is a high number to reach, our cast and crew are committed to this project because they can see the beauty of what this film is about and want to be a part of it. If we don’t completely reach our goal don’t think that the money you have put up is gone, we will start by paying for the needs to finish the film first, followed by paying our cast, paying our crew and lastly paying for post production editing and getting it into festivals. So 4 levels we are trying to reach with this amount of money, and excited to have you interested in joining us!

 

 

The Impact

 

This story is not just some cheesy off the cuff story. We are all working to put out a story about illegal prostitution of young women. When Hans Christen Anderson wrote the Little Matchstick girl it was to tell a story about girl forced into child labor. If he were to be writing today the topic at hand would not be too far off from what is Zippo Girl. Telling compelling stories like this might help people to take the time to look at those women they might see out on the streets and help stand for making the change for the future of their lives. Each women was once a little girl and may have had very lovely memories of a loved one who did care deeply for them. This film helps put that into prospective. Through film festivals both here in the United States and also other countries we will be able to tell this very universal story.

 

We have help produce and assistant in directing projects that have gone on to many film festivals. Each proving to bring about a level of success. I find that dramatic films carry a great deal of weight to them and seem to hold in peoples minds for a lot longer than just in the moment. We have been recognize by many we have worked with that we possess the eye and skills in capturing the essence of what we put in front of the camera.

 

What you are doing is creating the opportunity to give the in making such an impactful film. What we have brought to the table and what you will help make happen only will make us all part of something bigger. I know that if you stick with us through to the end you will see a masterpiece in its place!

 

 

Risks & Challenges

 

With filmmaking there comes both risks and challenges. Short films fall under the risk side of it because its investing money only into peoples talents and skills with the most of the time only the turn on investment being its success in being selected to a film festival here or there. Challenge we have been facing so far is that of not having the fund needed to help lock in and secure cast and crew, which is why we have had to start this campaign to help make sure we can. Other challenges are the elements of nature, most of this takes place outside so we are right now fighting against time when the temperature are starting to turn off a bit

 

We have worked on many different short films in the past and a lot of these risks and challenges we have faced. But with full surety we have come out successful in completing the works and seeing them go on to be seen by mean in the festivals around the country. Both Lance and Drew are very committed to this project and believe in its success over all.

 

For our risks, we plan on using the success of the short to help us launch a feature film. That in turn is worth its weight in gold as they say. We have plans to show how as filmmakers we can both write and film high quality pieces that all can enjoy. The plans to get over the challenges starts with your help and ends with a fully committed team to make this vision come to pass. Each one of us is making this happen, its not just a Drew and Lance show its a Zippo Girl team effort. 

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

 

With your contribution that you put down, like us, lets get the word out about this campaign, this story and the future success of this film. We have a Facebook page that you can follow us on as we work on making this film you can see the updates happen. Feel free to send comments, pictures and most important other friends, family and loved ones to also become a part of making this movie happen. There is a great IndieGoGo share tool that makes it easy to pass this campaign on to others. Share, Like and LOVE what we are making happen and lets do this all together!

story:
Please start from reading these articles:

Sashka's Story at sashkatennis.com

Keep On, Keepin’ On: The Story of Sashka Oliynykova at The Tennis Island

"Dear miracle, please come to our family" at OKTennis.it

---
Do you love tennis?

Do you love watching it and playing it?

While you were watching tennis either on TV or at a tournament, have you ever thought to yourself, “Man, I wish I could just tell that player one little thing. I really think it would benefit them?”

Have you ever wondered what being behind-the-scenes at tennis tournaments is like?

Have you ever wondered how professional players and elite-level junior players train? What do they work on? How do they practice forehands, backhands, and serves? What physiotherapy routines do they partake in? Do they follow particular diets? (We know Novak Djokovic enjoys a gluten-free diet :))

But in general, what does the picture of achieving one’s dreams look like? What sort of dedication does it take? What does real passion for something look like? If there were a good portrayal of that somewhere, wouldn’t you like to be reminded of and exposed to that every day? Wouldn’t you like to be reminded on a regular basis of what it’s like to devote yourself to a dream? Wouldn’t you want to be a part of that?

Because all too often, we are reminded of all of the reasons why dreams will remain just that – contemplations for another lifetime. But we’re saying that today, it doesn’t have to be that way.

Sashka and her family have been uprooted from their home (more on her story here) and currently don’t have the resources to fund her dream. Tennis is a costly sport. They’re seeking your help and support to keep her dream and goal of playing professional tennis alive.

What we offer is an insider look into the life of a young aspiring professional tennis player.

We offer a behind-the-scenes account of her journey to living out a lifelong dream. The peaks. The valleys. The wins and the losses. Think Hoop Dreams, but if the star in Hoop Dreams was Derrick Rose.

Even more, we offer the opportunity to provide input and feedback to Sashka throughout her journey. If you’ve ever wanted to be a part of a professional tennis player’s team, but you lack the connections to other pros, here’s your chance!

We HAVE: a promising junior female tennis player aspiring to the professional ranks.

We NEED: real tennis fans to be our supporters, mentors, and team members.

We want you to be a backer for the world's first crowdfunded tennis player. She could be YOUR player!

...Crowdfunding has already had an impact on just about every other industry. Now it is time to add professional sports to that list. We are offering you the chance to be an influential member of a global team aiding the development of a real professional tennis player.

Here are some of the benefits:

  • You can have access to practices through web streams; you can discuss your opinions with other team members; and you have the ability to provide your insight and opinion to the player and coaches on court in real time. You will be heard!
  • You can visit tournaments to support your player and even visit VIP lounges and boxes (upon availability of tickets and seats)
  • You can participate in tournament planning in order to help Sashka build her game and improve her ranking
  • You can watch Sashka’s matches and help the team analyze and assess what they see
  • You can develop media contacts and sponsor relations
  • Or, you can choose to do none of these things and simply have someone to cheer for on a daily basis.


We’ll keep you updated! It’d be really cool to have a close relationship with someone you’re watching play in the U.S. Open.

Now is the time to join us. We aim to unite people around the (crazy) idea of growing and developing a junior tennis player through a crowdfunding community. We want to put all of our efforts, resources, and energy into our player’s development.

And without further ado, here is our player, Oleksandra “Sashka” Oliynykova.



Sashka is a promising junior tennis player in the very beginning of her professional tennis career. She is a 3-time junior champion of Croatia in doubles and 2-time semi-finalist in singles. She is a winner/runner-up of many international junior championships in singles and doubles, including the highly regarded junior Sweden Open. She is a member of the Croatia Junior National Team.

A very open-minded, positive, and hard-working personality, Sashka has a very touching story. She and her family were forced to flee from their home in Ukraine, leaving them in a distant country without any possessions or solid income streams. You can read the whole story in detail here.

Sashka & her coaches are truly ready to cooperate with a global support team. She is a "tabula rasa", a blank slate. We can develop the ideal player together!

What We Need & What You Get

We are aiming to raise $60,000 USD. It is a complete training and expense budget for 2 seasons (2017-2018).

How it is going to be distributed (yearly model):

  • $18,000 USD (or $1,500 USD monthly): "all-covered" training at our base in Porec, Croatia. This will include 4-5 hours/day of on-court training, 1-2 hours/day of fitness and conditioning, mental training, and tactical exercises and match analysis as per needed. It will also cover recovery and physiotherapy.
  • $10,000 USD (or about $835 USD monthly): the travel budget. This sum will cover tickets and tournament fees for both tournaments providing hospitality (room and board paid by a tournament) and tournaments not providing hospitality. We will optimize our travel budget by using low cost airlines and by sharing apartments/hotels with other players. We will also try to include as many tournaments with provided hospitality as possible.
  • $2,000 USD: the yearly equipment budget. It includes rackets, strings, shoes, garments, bags, sport foods, drinks & vitamins.

We will regularly publish a financial report open for all backers. You will see how we spend the budget and will be able to suggest or comment any different ways to improve efficiency.

We have prepared special rewards for every backer - really EVERYONE who wants to participate in this exciting pro tennis travel. From a "thank you" note on our web site & social media, through team baseball caps & t-shirts, to your name/logo on a player's t-shirt during a real junior & pro tennis tournament!

Our main offering, though, is INVOLVEMENT. You have a chance to be part of the Sashka team. Support our project and join a BIG TENNIS INNOVATION: the world’s first crowdfunded tennis player.

If we raise more funds than our target, we will add it to current player's budget - so our player will get a competitve edge.

If we raise less, we will attract financing from other sources (sponsors, merchandise sales etc.).

Why it is important?

For two reasons. First, a successful campaign means Sashka’s dream and goal of playing professional tennis stays alive. Two, it shows us that possibility is only limited to what you can conceive and all that is needed is a dream big enough and a little bit of creativity. A successful campaign here potentially enables countless others with similarly challenging circumstances and stories to keep their dreams and goals alive.

Keeping the dream alive is what crowdfunding is all about. Viewers see projects that they’d like to see in existence, and they back those projects. Oftentimes, it’s not about what backers get in return. It’s about seeing something in existence and knowing that you were part of the building process.

We’d like to see Sashka continue her ascension to the professional ranks and with some help make it to the top, but without some help, whether it’s here or somewhere else, the venture will die before even having a chance.

You have dreamed of being a part of the game, and now we are offering you the opportunity.

Sashka, a teenage girl from a low-income refugee family, could not finance this long and costly travel to tennis success on her own. But with your help, she can.



Millions of people worldwide are limited by boundaries of cost and time. A successful campaign here opens the door for so many others, proving that "the sky is the limit". If you want to dance - dance. If you want to play tennis - do it. If you want to be a pro sport manager/agent - join us & try it out!

We can not guarantee that Sashka will win Grand Slams or the Olympic Games. But we do guarantee that we will be together with our backers throughout her professional career. It will be an exciting trip!

Risks & Challenges

Tennis is a highly competitive sport. Thousands of players from all over the world compete to enter the world top-200 list, where most attention & public visibility are concentrated.

We have a highly professional team here – Sashka, her coaches, and her parents. But we hope to make the team even stronger by adding you to the team. Join us!

Sashka’s tennis career will surely include both sides of the coin – wins and losses, victories and defeat, milestones and setbacks. We understand that is part of the process. We are to be patient and take it one challenge at a time. Knowing that she will achieve her tennis goals, we are to work with the intent of bringing that belief to fruition. She wants to play professional tennis and make a living at it. Now it’s about the steady climb to make that dream a reality.

We wouldn’t be here, running a crowdfunding campaign, if Sashka didn’t believe she could make it. And right now, this crowdfunding campaign is a part of that steady climb.

There is always risk of injury. It is elite-level athletics, after all. But with the proper care and attentiveness – physical training, recovery, and quality physiotherapy – that risk can be minimized. And in the instance of an injury, it can be well managed and healed.

More ways to support

You can also support Sashka in many different ways outside of crowdfunding. Visit Sashka's website to learn more about her story and why it’s worth considering backing her.

If you want to be a private sponsor (this means that you or your company alone invest a significant amount in our player), please click here.

If you would like to invite Sashka to play for your country or tennis club, please follow this link.

Finally, you can always help us by spreading the word amongst your friends, readers & followers. On this page you will find a full list of links to our social media pages along with Sashka’s profile on the International Tennis Federation website. There you can see her rankings and tournament schedules.

Thank you & WELCOME ON BOARD!

She is a 3-time junior champion of Croatia in doubles and 2-time semi-finalist in singles. She is a member of the Croatia Junior National Team.A very open-minded, positive, and hard-working personality, Sashka has a very touching story. She and her family were forced to flee from their home in Ukraine, leaving them in a distant country without any possessions or solid income streams. You can read the whole story in detail here.
Sashka & her coaches are truly ready to cooperate with a global support team. She is a "tabula rasa", a blank slate. We can develop the ideal player together!
What We Need & What You Get
We are aiming to raise $60,000 USD. It is a complete training and expense budget for 2 seasons (2017-2018).
How it is going to be distributed (yearly model):

$18,000 USD (or $1,500 USD monthly): "all-covered" training at our base in Porec, Croatia. This will include 4-5 hours/day of on-court training, 1-2 hours/day of fitness and conditioning, mental training, and tactical exercises and match analysis as per needed. It will also cover recovery and physiotherapy.
$10,000 USD (or about $835 USD monthly): the travel budget. This sum will cover tickets and tournament fees for both tournaments providing hospitality (room and board paid by a tournament) and tournaments not providing hospitality. We will optimize our travel budget by using low cost airlines and by sharing apartments/hotels with other players. We will also try to include as many tournaments with provided hospitality as possible.
$2,000 USD: the yearly equipment budget. It includes rackets, strings, shoes, garments, bags, sport foods, drinks & vitamins.

We will regularly publish a financial report open for all backers. You will see how we spend the budget and will be able to suggest or comment any different ways to improve efficiency.We have prepared special rewards for every backer - really EVERYONE who wants to participate in this exciting pro tennis travel. From a "thank you" note on our web site & social media, through team baseball caps & t-shirts, to your name/logo on a player's t-shirt during a real junior & pro tennis tournament!Our main offering, though, is INVOLVEMENT. You have a chance to be part of the Sashka team. Support our project and join a BIG TENNIS INNOVATION: the world’s first crowdfunded tennis player.
If we raise more funds than our target, we will add it to current player's budget - so our player will get a competitve edge.If we raise less, we will attract financing from other sources (sponsors, merchandise sales etc.).
Why it is important?
For two reasons. First, a successful campaign means Sashka’s dream and goal of playing professional tennis stays alive. Two, it shows us that possibility is only limited to what you can conceive and all that is needed is a dream big enough and a little bit of creativity. A successful campaign here potentially enables countless others with similarly challenging circumstances and stories to keep their dreams and goals alive.
Keeping the dream alive is what crowdfunding is all about. Viewers see projects that they’d like to see in existence, and they back those projects. Oftentimes, it’s not about what backers get in return. It’s about seeing something in existence and knowing that you were part of the building process.We’d like to see Sashka continue her ascension to the professional ranks and with some help make it to the top, but without some help, whether it’s here or somewhere else, the venture will die before even having a chance.You have dreamed of being a part of the game, and now we are offering you the opportunity.Sashka, a teenage girl from a low-income refugee family, could not finance this long and costly travel to tennis success on her own. But with your help, she can.Millions of people worldwide are limited by boundaries of cost and time. A successful campaign here opens the door for so many others, proving that "the sky is the limit". If you want to dance - dance. If you want to play tennis - do it. If you want to be a pro sport manager/agent - join us & try it out!
We can not guarantee that Sashka will win Grand Slams or the Olympic Games. But we do guarantee that we will be together with our backers throughout her professional career. It will be an exciting trip!
Risks & Challenges
Tennis is a highly competitive sport. Thousands of players from all over the world compete to enter the world top-200 list, where most attention & public visibility are concentrated.We have a highly professional team here – Sashka, her coaches, and her parents. But we hope to make the team even stronger by adding you to the team. Join us!
Sashka’s tennis career will surely include both sides of the coin – wins and losses, victories and defeat, milestones and setbacks. We understand that is part of the process. We are to be patient and take it one challenge at a time. Knowing that she will achieve her tennis goals, we are to work with the intent of bringing that belief to fruition. She wants to play professional tennis and make a living at it. Now it’s about the steady climb to make that dream a reality.We wouldn’t be here, running a crowdfunding campaign, if Sashka didn’t believe she could make it. And right now, this crowdfunding campaign is a part of that steady climb.
There is always risk of injury. It is elite-level athletics, after all. But with the proper care and attentiveness – physical training, recovery, and quality physiotherapy – that risk can be minimized. And in the instance of an injury, it can be well managed and healed.
More ways to support
You can also support Sashka in many different ways outside of crowdfunding. Visit Sashka's website to learn more about her story and why it’s worth considering backing her.If you want to be a private sponsor (this means that you or your company alone invest a significant amount in our player), please click here.If you would like to invite Sashka to play for your country or tennis club, please follow this link.Finally, you can always help us by spreading the word amongst your friends, readers & followers. On this page you will find a full list of links to our social media pages along with Sashka’s profile on the International Tennis Federation website. There you can see her rankings and tournament schedules.Thank you & WELCOME ON BOARD!

story: NA

Watch our sampler of the project above!


The Project 

Since January 2014 I've been documenting the life of British Muay Thai superstar Greg Wootton. Capturing his rise and journey to becoming a 2 time World Champion and one of the most feared fighters in the sport. Now on the 20th of November he takes to the international stage - fighting for his 3rd World Title in the United States & we need your help to get out there and capture this amazing moment in his career which will be the perfect ending to our film.

Greg is a humble champion that has dedicated his life to Muay Thai and is now reaping the rewards. At the same time he is keen to pass on his knowledge to the next generation. The film adopts a split narrative following Greg as he prepares himself to take on some of the best fighters in the world and also captures the journey of 9 year old Jimmy Clarke who Greg takes under his wing and guides to his first title. 

Greg and Jimmy both train out of the world famous KO Gym in Bethnal Green. The film captures the unique atmosphere of the gym and shows the fighters philosophy of always helping the next person behind you, resulting in the gym producing over 20 world champions.

I've been friends with Greg for 20 years which has allowed me to capture an intimate unflinching look at what he goes through physically & mentally to fight at the top level. 



Why Greg? 

Greg is achieving unprecedented things in Muay Thai. A sport usually dominated by Thais he's made the transition from fighting the best in the UK to fighting the best in the world and claimed high profile victories over pound for pound champion Petchboonchu & Rungrat recently.

This is a real passion project for myself as I've know Greg for such a long time and up until this point I've self financed the film myself but with this world title fight only being scheduled in the last week it hasn't allowed me and the crew to put money aside to hire equipment and travel to the United States. Once the film is completed we have exciting plans of showing the film at Greg's gym in Bethnal Green and at film festivals around the world. 



Where is the money going?

We're asking for £2000 because thats exactly the amount we need to make this happen and complete the project. £1,210 will be spent on Travel & Accommodation. The crew will be flying into New York and then taking trains to the venue in Connecticut. The remaining £790 will be spent on hiring cameras, lenses & sound kit. Currently the film is being edited and almost finished but we need to shoot this fight for the ending.


The Crew

Director / Camera - Dhillon Shukla - 

Dhillon is a Independant filmmaker from London who has worked on a wide range of projects. Mainly working within the music industry creating music videos and documentary's. He's directed projects with Grammy Award nominated artists Disclosure and Brit Award Nominated singer Jessie Ware on a number of occasions. 


Camera - Steve Dunn -

Steve is a experienced camera operator who mainly works within the advertising field. He has also shot music videos and documentaries throughout his career and is comfortable working on high end productions as well as more verite style projects. 


Producer - Hannah Bailey

Hannah is a  documentary producer who recently won 1st prize at the RTS awards for her acclaimed documentary 'The Invisible School'. She has also just directed and produced a short film funded by the arts council which is set to be released early next year. 


Talent - Greg Wootton

Had 30 pro fights with 28 wins and 2 losses. Lost his first fight and one other to a Thai. Along the way won some minor titles then most notable am now ranked no.1 in the UK at 63.5kg or light-welterweight won a W.M.C world title and an Enfusion world title. Also previously held European and British titles. Represented England as an amateur at a couple of tournaments too won a bronze as a junior Lived in Thailand in a gym for 7 months fought in both the main stadiums in Bangkok. 


Please help us complete this amazing project!

Many Thanks, Greg & Dhillon

story:
Hi my name is Chris and I love film and i am seeking $2.1M dollars for my Amazing Film called THE Hidden Talent which I believe will change many peoples hearts and change so many peoples lives. Lives really do matter and I believe that this film will have a voice for those people to speak up for themselves.



The Hidden Talent Film

This movie is about a girl who parents were killed when she was at the age of 5 years old. After she was found next to her parents she was then sent to a foster home, While in this foster she was being molested and abused. As She grows up she runs away from home going into a even harder lifestyle As a stripper. Surviving to make it on her own, Until she meets this guy who changed her whole life around, this guy took her out of the her lifestyle because he seen what she didn't see in herself which was her hidden talent.

NOTE: I WILL NOT REVEAL WHAT HER HIDDEN TALENT IS YOU HAVE TO WAIT.

I myself have been trying to make this film for 3 years but, every time i try to get funded i never succeed. All my life family and people i associated myself with would always say that i would never succeed. i would hear the words ever since i was in grammar school, I would be bullied everyday praying to god, asking to make my dream come true. I spent 24/7 writing this film. That's how dedicated i am

This film is a very heart felt film and my goal for this film is it to have a voice. I wake up everyday seeing people on television and in person who have been hurt, abused, and molested and no one does anything about it. It even happens to people in there own homes blood related.

All my life i always wanted to help people and i know that this film is going to change so many lives. I cry for people because i feel there pain and i see there hurt and its like i want to do something for them and i believe that this film will be perfect.

I mean filming is my life and i would die for it. It saved my life, one day as a child i was bullied so bad after being jumped by 15 people because i smiled to much and because i was always happy. I wanted to commit suicide because i was tired of being invisible or a target. Students wasn't just doing this teachers would also do this. I remember as a child i told my teacher i wanted to be a movie director and she said, that i will never be anything and put a L on my forehead and whole class began to laugh. I was humiliated i didn't know what to do.

I remember being home alone and the tv turned on i was crying so bad. If i had a bag it would be full of tears i cried so much because i didn't understand why people didn't like me.

When the TV turned on a movie made by Steven Spielberg came on called Jaws and it motivated me so much i wanted to make films. I wanted to tell people about my life i wanted to be a voice for people. So at the age of 10 i went to the library and got 10 books about film and i read everyday even during school about film. I begin to see the world different as art, i begin to see beauty and it took me into world we know as the film world where every dream comes true, every fear that i have is placed in one genre such as horror, every laughing moment goes into the genre of comedy, every part of love that was in my life goes into the genre of romance. I build this world around me to understand the meaning of my imagination. When i write i begin to turn into a kid again and just begin to imagine everything. Steven Spielberg has truly inspired me and i want to show the world my world.


I will never stop dreaming, dreaming is what changed me and dreaming is what can change you

I will never stop believing because without believing i cant dream

Film is my life and i will never forget it

Help make my dream come true so i can open my imagination to the world. Now in my world there is peace, there is kindness, creativity the eyes could never imagine. Everything in this world is a genre and this is where the magic begin to happen.
